sentence_text: Rudolph II (1552-1612) was the son of the Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian II.
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: He became King of Hungary in 1572 and King of Bohemia in 1575.
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: Following the death of his father he also became Holy Roman Emperor and Archduke of Austria.
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: His reign was a troubled time of great religious conflicts coupled with the external menace of the Turks.
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: Unfortunately, politics was not a great interest of his.
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: Instead he was familiar with a number of languages and was devoted to art and science, the latter including alchemy and astrology, a highly fashionable preoccupation at that time.
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: He was also fascinated by magic and the occult.
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: At the end of the 1590s mental illness rendered him incapable of governing his empire, which by that time was torn by disputes between Reformation and Counter-Reformation movements.
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: As a result, in 1611, he was forced to cede the crown of Bohemia to his brother Matthias and he died soon afterwards
title: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II
author: Hans von AACHEN

sentence_text: From 1772 Abildgaard spent five years in Rome thanks to a scholarship granted by the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts in Copenhagen.

sentence_text: Mucius Scaevola (Livy 2:12-13) was a hero of Roman legend.
title: Mucius Scaevola
author: Hans BALDUNG GRIEN

sentence_text: When the Etruscan forces, led by Lars Porsena, king of Clusium, were besieging Rome, a young Roman nobleman, Caius Mucius, succeeded in penetrating the enemy lines in disguise, meaning to kill Porsena.
title: Mucius Scaevola
author: Hans BALDUNG GRIEN

sentence_text: By mistake he killed the king's secretary who was sitting beside him.
title: Mucius Scaevola
author: Hans BALDUNG GRIEN

sentence_text: Mucius was seized but, to show how cheaply he held his life, thrust his right hand into the flames of an altar fire and let it burn.
title: Mucius Scaevola
author: Hans BALDUNG GRIEN

sentence_text: Porsena, amazed by his endurance, set him free.
title: Mucius Scaevola
author: Hans BALDUNG GRIEN

sentence_text: He was thereafter called Scaevola, meaning 'left-handed'.In painting, of the Renaissance and later, Mucius stands for the virtues of patience and constancy.
title: Mucius Scaevola
author: Hans BALDUNG GRIEN

sentence_text: His sacrifice was also held to be a prefiguration of Christ's sacrifice
title: Mucius Scaevola
author: Hans BALDUNG GRIEN

author: Hendrick van BALEN

sentence_text: 2:708-832) tells how three sisters, returning from the festival of Minerva and carrying her sacred baskets on their heads, were espied by Mercury who immediately fell in love with the most beautiful of them, Herse.
title: Herse and her Sisters with Mercury
author: Hendrick van BALEN

sentence_text: Another of the sisters, Aglauros, was consumed with envy, and tried to prevent Mercury entering Herse's chamber when he came to her one night.
title: Herse and her Sisters with Mercury
author: Hendrick van BALEN

sentence_text: He touched Aglauros with his wand and she turned to black stone, the colour of her thoughts.The present playful and sensuous representation of the story is similar both in style and theme to a number of others executed by van Balen and his circle.
title: Herse and her Sisters with Mercury
author: Hendrick van BALEN

sentence_text: Van Balen was specialised in small cabinet pictures which often depicted mythological scenes.

sentence_text: Federico Barrocci's Aeneas' Flight from Troy with Anchises, his son Ascanius and his wife Creusa is the second version painted in 1598 of a picture executed ten years earlier for Emperor Rudolf II of Austria.
title: Aeneas' Flight from Troy
author: Federico Fiori BAROCCI

sentence_text: Cardinal Giuliano della Rovere presented Cardinal Scipione with this second version, which entered the Borghese collection before 1613.
title: Aeneas' Flight from Troy
author: Federico Fiori BAROCCI

sentence_text: It was this painting that inspired Cardinal Scipione to commission a large marble group on the same subject from Gian Lorenzo Bernini (also in the Borghese Gallery).
title: Aeneas' Flight from Troy
author: Federico Fiori BAROCCI

sentence_text: The myth of Aeneas, ancestor of Romulus and Remus, referred to the birth of Rome and thus confirmed the Borghese family's high status in the city.Barrocci's many drawings of nature led him to achieve a spontaneity and naturalness in movement, colour and airy effects, and a silvery luminosity that was to influence the 17th-century masters, particularly Rubens.
title: Aeneas' Flight from Troy
author: Federico Fiori BAROCCI

sentence_text: Never before had flames been painted so close to, with an energy suggesting even the crackle of the fire, from which Ascanius seems to be protecting himself by covering his ears.
title: Aeneas' Flight from Troy
author: Federico Fiori BAROCCI

sentence_text: But the human delicacy of Barrocci's anti-heroic and anti-rhetorical figures was not to be really appreciated in Rome, because it could not compete with the classical antique statuary
title: Aeneas' Flight from Troy
author: Federico Fiori BAROCCI

sentence_text: The Collegiata Santa Maria Assunta, directly adjacent to the Palazzo Comunale, is San Gimignano's main church.

sentence_text: The decoration encompassed New Testament scenes in the north aisle by Lippo Memmi (c. 1340), Old Testament scenes in the south aisle by Bartolo di Fredi (1367), and a depiction of the Last Judgment on the east wall and in the first bay of the nave.

sentence_text: by Taddeo di Bartolo (c. 1413).The picture shows four scenes from the Old Testament, located in the fourth bay of the south aisle.

sentence_text: The scenes are: The Departure of Abraham and Lot (above left), Abraham and Lot Separate (above right), God and Satan Agree on the Temptation of Job (below left), Sabeans and Chaldeans Kill Job's Servants.You can find a description of the frescoes in the north aisle in the section of Lippo Memmi

sentence_text: It can be considered his masterpiece because it reaches a degree of lyricism only achieved previously by Piero della Francesca.The painting was moved into the Church of St Dominic in 1788 where the Servants of Mary, who used to run the church, repainted the two Benedictine saints in the foreground, St Benedict and St Scolastica, transforming them into Filippo Benizzi and Giuliana Falconeri, two saints of their religious order.

sentence_text: Marco Basaiti, an admirer of Antonello da Messina and Giovanni Bellini found himself fascinated at the beginning of the sixteenth century by the new artistic manner pioneered by Giorgione.

author: Marco BASAITI

sentence_text: Already in 'Christ Praying in the Garden' which adorned the first altar on the right in the Church of San Giobbe and which belonged to the family of Francesco Foscari, the influence of the style of Antonello (visible in the integrity of colour of the figures and the arrangement of saints at the sides of the portico, of the apostles, and of Christ absorbed in prayer) gives way in the landscape to lyrically dreaming passages clearly drawing their spirit from Giorgione.
title: Christ Praying in the Garden
author: Marco BASAITI

sentence_text: Though this panel may not exactly offer a complete synthesis of the late fifteenth century world with the dazzling innovations of the early years of the sixteenth century, it is nevertheless emblematic of the meeting-point of two of the finest ages of Venetian painting.The doubt over the date derive from a faded inscription.

sentence_text: Because he was in holy orders, Baschenis is sometimes referred to as Father Evaristo.

sentence_text: The Bergamese Baschenis was, more than anything else, the perfect example of a "specialist" painter.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: In fact nearly all his oeuvre was dedicated to painting musical instruments, sometimes his pictures being finished by other painters who added figures (as in the case of two paintings that have recently been found in the Brera in Milan).
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: From this specific point of view, Baschenis is one of the most fascinating and focused painters of the whole of the seventeenth century.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: His use of realism and light is reminiscent of Caravaggio.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: His canvases had an intense quality which was dominated by his exceptional technical ability (one thing that stands out is the way in which he depicted dust on the back of stringed instruments).But Baschenis' work never degenerated into a mere display of virtuoso talent.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: It was rather directed to convey a sense of almost severe moral purpose.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: Baschenis' success with still-life gave rise, especially in Bergamo itself, to a real fashion for the genre, with other painters following his example.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: Evaristo Baschenis is universally acknowledged as the inventor of the musical instrument still-life and its most celebrated practitioner.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments in an Interior
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: He was himself a practicing musician who clearly had a deep understanding of the instruments that he painted.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments in an Interior
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: The instruments in the present painting are: a theorbo; below it a mandolino; a Venetian lute; a pentagonal spinet; a violin; an ebony inlaid guitar, and a harp.
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments in an Interior
author: Evaristo BASCHENIS

sentence_text: The red damask cloth and the richly embroidered drapery overhead recur in other works by Baschenis
title: Still-Life with Musical Instruments in an Interior

sentence_text: In 1516 to 1518 the Sienese brotherhood of Mary and Bernardino commissioned Girolamo del Pacchia, Sodoma, and Domenico Beccafumi to fresco the walls of their oratory with a cycle on the life of Mary, The artists painted two stories each: Pacchia, the Birth of Mary and the Annunciation; Sodoma, the Presentation of the Virgin and the Coronation of Mary; and Beccafumi, the Betrothal of Mary and the Death of the Virgin.
title: View of the Oratory
author: Domenico BECCAFUMI

sentence_text: The missing scenes on the right-hand longitudinal wall, the Visitation and the Assumption of the Virgin were not painted by Sodoma until the late 1520s, and Baccafumi's altarpiece still later, between 1535 and 1537.
title: View of the Oratory

sentence_text: The cycle begins on the left wall (The Birth of Mary to THe Betrothal of Mary), and continues above the altar wall (Annunciation) and the right longitudinal wall (Visitation to Assumption of the Virgin) through the second of the short walls (The Coronation of Mary).

sentence_text: Over the traditional preparatory ground (gypsum and animal glue) he had sketched out the preliminary drawing, marking in with extreme precision even the chiaroscuro with subtle and highly regular criss-cross strokes which can be seen in infra-red photography.

sentence_text: This technique used by Bellini must have been famous if Paolo Pino in his Dialogo di pittura (1548) writes that "drawing the painting with such extreme diligence, composing it with chiaro and scuro as Giovanni Bellino was wont to do" was to be discouraged "for it is work thrown away since everything must be covered with the colours".This type of drawing shows similarities with the rigorous Flemish constructive technique, though under closer scrutiny it appears to be aimed at a search for a much more solid and volumetrically constructed plastic quality.

sentence_text: Priapus, his pride wounded, took revenge by demanding the annual sacrifice of a donkey.The ass stands next to Silenus, a woodland deity who used the beast to carry wood, thus wears a keg on his belt because he was a follower of Bacchus, god of wine.
title: The Feast of the Gods
author: Giovanni BELLINI

sentence_text: Bacchus himself, seen as an infant, kneels before them while decanting wine into a crystal pitcher.Reading from left to right, the principal figures are:Silenus, a woodland god attended by his donkeyBacchus, the infant god of wine crowned with grape leavesFaunus or Silvanus, an old forest god wearing a wreath of pine needlesMercury, the messenger of the gods carrying his caduceus or herald's staffJupiter, the king of the gods accompanied by an eagleAn unidentified goddess holding a quince, a fruit associated in the ancient world with marriagePan, a satyr with a grape wreath who blows on his shepherd's pipesNeptune, the god of the sea sitting beside his trident harpoonCeres, the goddess of cereal grains with a wreath of wheatApollo, god of the sun and the arts, crowned by laurel and holding a Renaissance stringed musical instrument, the lira da braccio, in lieu of a classical lyrePriapus, the god of virility and of vineyards with a scythe, used to prune orchards, hanging from the tree above himLotis, one of the naiads, a nymph of fresh waters who represents chastity.These deities are waited upon by three naiads, nymphs of streams and brooks, and two satyrs, goat-footed inhabitants of the wilderness.
title: The Feast of the Gods

sentence_text: The picture shows the choir vault and apse with illusionistic architecture and scenes from the life of the Virgin (Annunciation, Assumption).The most important setting for the fictive dissolution of ceilings and walls with painting intended to evoke and illustrate heavenly sphere was the church, with its choir tribunes, inner façades, vaults and cupolas.

sentence_text: The vaulted, single-aisle nave flanked by chapels, transepts flooded by light from the centre cupola, and a spacious choir made possible a sophisticated structuring of the pictorial program in conformity with the architecture.The painterly redecoration of the church of Santissima Annunziata del Vastato in Genoa following its modernization in the style of the Counter-Reformation began around 1625 with the vaults of the aisles.
title: Choir vault and apse decoration

author: Giulio BENSO

sentence_text: The Annunciation to the Virgin, central to the church's iconography, takes place in the vault, shifted to heavenly spheres with the help of quadratura.

sentence_text: The drama of the Annunciation - Mary receives the angel's message in an airy loggia, while God floats down in glory above her - is then outdone by the ecstasy of the choir calotte's Assumption.This theatrical staging is considered one of the most successful combinations, with respect to foreshortening of quadratura and figural painting with the actual architecture

author: Nicolaes BERCHEM

sentence_text: While in Italy, Berchem made many drawings of the landscape of the Roman Campagna, its cattle and peasants.On his return to Haarlem Berchem quarried this rich material throughout a long and extremely productive career, painting (and etching) hundreds of Italianate pastoral scenes.
title: Peasants with Cattle by a Ruined Aqueduct

sentence_text: As is evident from this painting, he interpreted the Italian landscape and the life of its peasants in an idyllic manner, emphasizing its timeless continuity by the inclusion of antique monuments.

sentence_text: Berchem uses a bright, highly-coloured palette and applies the paint in short, stabbing brush strokes.In seventeenth-century Holland there was a constant demand for exotic landscapes of this type and Berchem was a highly successful artist.
title: Peasants with Cattle by a Ruined Aqueduct

sentence_text: Joachim Beuckelaer, the nephew and pupil of Pieter Aertsen, specialised in market scenes and genre paintings.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: Following the path opened up by his uncle, he responded to the growing demand of a prosperous bourgeoisie that wished to decorate their houses with works that reflected the lay character of their surroundings, whilst retaining a moral and religious significance.Jesus' visit to the house of Martha and Mary, taken from St Luke's Gospel, formed the basis of several representations from the mid-16th century onwards.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: In the religious context of the time, this scene illustrated one of the fundamental differences opposing Catholics and Protestants.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: The latter sought salvation in action whilst the former placed greater value on the contemplative life.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: Here the artist relegates the teaching of the divine word to the back of the painting, devoting the entire foreground to active life, incarnated by Martha, and in so doing juxtaposing a genre scene and a still-life.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: Like Aertsen, he assembles the domestic scene in his studio, drawing from a repertory of standard objects and utensils that he was to constantly reproduce elsewhere in various combinations.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: Again like Aertsen, he has borrowed from Serlio's treatise the Renaissance architecture in which he places his composition.However, it would be unfair to dismiss Beuckelaer as a mere follower.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: Rather the artist stands out by his extraordinary ability to reproduce textures in their full sensuousness, using a light and subtle stroke and a delicately gradated palette.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: With considerable virtuosity and delight he precisely depicts the varnished terracotta of the crocks, the flaccid skin of the plucked fowl, the starched but still supple serviettes, and the fragility of the hair drawn back over the kitchen-maid's temples.
title: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
author: Joachim BEUCKELAER

sentence_text: The soft greasiness of the meat or the velvety softness of the mallard duck are set against the flat glint of the tin pot and the glazed transparency of the cabochon glasses or berkemeier.

sentence_text: His paintings are full of allusions to sensuality, sexuality and fertility, with vegetables, fruit, fish, meat and cooking utensils piled up around a few figures.

sentence_text: In his best works, Beuckelaer mixes a strong sense of space and detail on the one hand, with unity of composition on the other

sentence_text: Albert Bierstadt, a native of Germany, stood in the tradition of the Hudson River School, founded by the English-born Thomas Cole, which marked the beginning of a genuinely American landscape painting.

title: Yosemite Valley at Sunset

sentence_text: The artist captured these impressions in a series of large-format panoramas that made him the founder of the Rocky Mountain School.Yosemite Valley at Sunset was a preliminary study for one of these large paintings.

sentence_text: Later, in 1514 Boccaccino received the commission to begin a fresco cycle of the life of Mary and Christ on the walls of the nave.

sentence_text: They begin on the left wall, running from the façade to the apse and then on the right wall from the apse back to the façade.

sentence_text: The left wall is dedicated to Mary and Christ's childhood; the right to the Passion.Boccaccino divided the rectangular sections above the arcades of the nave into two fields by painted pilasters.

sentence_text: The scenes of the fresco cycle were placed into these sections.

sentence_text: In 1514-15 Boccaccino began with the first four scenes of the story of Mary above the first and second arches of the arcade: Annunciation to Joachim; Meeting at the Golden Gate; Birth of Mary; Betrothal of Mary.
title: Meeting at the Golden Gate
author: Boccaccio BOCCACCINO

sentence_text: Boccaccino painted the next four scenes of the cycle in 1515-17 above the third and fourth arches: Annunciation to Mary; Visitation; Adoration of the Shepherds; Circumcision of Christ.In designing the cycle Boccaccino followed a famous model, Albrecht Dürer's woodcut series Life of the Virgin.
title: Meeting at the Golden Gate

title: Meeting at the Golden Gate

sentence_text: For the individual motifs, the formal language of the details, and the shaping of the whole, Boccaccino followed Italian traditions.In the Meeting at the Golden Gate, the tender embrace of Joachim and Anna is united by the arch of the gate over their heads.

sentence_text: During his lifetime Bonzi was particularly renowned for his still-lifes, but, like Filippo Napoletano, he was also active as a painter of landscapes.

sentence_text: His output in this genre became entangled with that of Agostino Tassi, even though the two do not really have much in common.

sentence_text: In addition to this canvas, Bonzi's certain works include The Martyrdom of St Sebastian and The Rest of Hercules (both in the Pinacoteca Capitolina, Rome), Nymph and Faun (Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica di Palazzo Barberini, Rome) and Latona and the Frogs (Musée du Louvre, Paris).Bonzi was clearly influenced by Annibale Carracci and to an even greater extent by Domenichino, but his compositions are more open on both sides and his terrain much flatter.

sentence_text: Establishing a chronology for Bonzi's landscapes is almost impossible, but this work is perhaps not too far in date from the Pallavicini-Rospigliosi frescoes.

sentence_text: In 1377 Pope Gregory XI returned to Rome and the magnificent palace of Avignon became only the residence of antipopes.

author: Lluis BORRASSA

sentence_text: The popes' "captivity in Babylon" had terminated, but Avignon continued to act as a channel through which Italian Gothic art gradually penetrated further and further into the rest of Europe.
title: St Peter is Walking on the Water
author: Lluis BORRASSA

sentence_text: It was in Avignon that Luis Borrassá first came into contact with 'court' Gothic, in the period around 1400, when this style was widely adopted in numbers of countries; it became in fact an international style founded upon all that Borrassá has learned from the brothers Serra.The painting in the church of Santa Maria in Terrasa illustrates the text from St. Matthew: 'And Jesus, walking by the sea of Galilee, saw two brethren, Simon called Peter and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea; for they were fishers.

sentence_text: And he saith unto them: Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men.

sentence_text: And they straightway left their nets, and followed him' (4, 19-20).
title: St Peter is Walking on the Water
author: Lluis BORRASSA

sentence_text: This scene is connected with another one from the Gospel: 'Jesus constrained his disciples to get into a ship... the ship was now in the midst of the sea... Jesus went unto them, walking on the sea.

sentence_text: And when the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were troubled... And Peter said, Lord, if it be thou, bid me come unto thee on the water.

sentence_text: In the midst of a luxuriant summer landscape, a surgeon removes an object from the head of a man tied to a chair; a monk and a nun look on.

author: Hieronymus BOSCH

sentence_text: This little picture may not be entirely by Bosch; the awkward and inexpressive figures are perhaps by an inferior hand, but only Bosch could have been responsible for the landscape background whose delicately painted forms recall the vista in his early Epiphany.

author: Hieronymus BOSCH

sentence_text: The open-air operation, its circular shape suggesting a mirror, is set within a framework of elaborate calligraphical decoration containing the inscription: "Master, cut the stone out, my name is Lubbert Das.
title: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)
author: Hieronymus BOSCH

sentence_text: "In Bosch's day, the stone operation was a piece of quackery in which the patient was supposedly cured of his stupidity through the removal of the stone of folly from his forehead.
title: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)
author: Hieronymus BOSCH

sentence_text: Fortunately, it was performed only in fiction, not in fact, for in literary examples of this theme it generally left the patient worse off than before.
title: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)
author: Hieronymus BOSCH

sentence_text: The name "Lubbert", on the other hand, frequently appears in Dutch literature to designate persons exhibiting an unusually high degree of human stupidity.
title: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)
author: Hieronymus BOSCH

sentence_text: The stone operation was occasionally represented by later Netherlandish artists, including Pieter Bruegel the Elder.
title: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)
author: Hieronymus BOSCH

sentence_text: This subject undoubtedly inspired Bosch's picture, but no extant version of it accounts for the funnel and the book perched on the heads of two of the characters, nor does it explain the presence of the monk and the nun, although their apparent acquiescence in the quackery certainly places them in an unfavourable light.
title: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)
author: Hieronymus BOSCH

sentence_text: It will be noted, too, that what the surgeon extracts from Lubbert's head is not a stone, but a flower; another flower of the same species lies on the table at the right.

sentence_text: The flowers has identified as tulips and their presence is explained as a play on the Dutch word for tulip which in the sixteenth century also carried the connotation of stupidity and folly.

sentence_text: The Magician belonging to Bosch's early paintings is now lost but it is known through a faithful copy at Saint-Germain-en-Laye.

sentence_text: The myopic gaze of the thief and the stupid amazement of the frog-spitting victim are superbly played off against the amused reactions of the bystanders, while the slyness of the mountebank is well conveyed in his sharp-nosed physiognomy.

sentence_text: The triptych of the Last Judgment is a fascinating work of art which comes surprisingly close to the unmistakable style of the strange moralist from 's-Hertogenbosch.

sentence_text: The emphasis in the development of the theme is on the all-besetting evil and perennial human stupidity that render the world a hell even before the day of divine jjudgment.
title: Last Judgment

sentence_text: The extraordinary combination of motifs is often derived from vernacular symbolism and imagery: The inventive use of colours and the sharp, supple brushwork have persuaded many critics that Bosch himself was the author of this painting.
title: Last Judgment

sentence_text: In spite of the work's pictorial qualities, several factors seem to undermine this attribution.

sentence_text: Nevertheless, the triptych remains an important example of Boschian invention.

sentence_text: It dates from the early sixteenth century.At the time of his death, Bosch was internationally celebrated as an eccentric painter of religious visions who dealt in particular with the torments of hell.
title: Last Judgment

sentence_text: During his lifetime Bosch's works were in the inventories of noble families of the Netherlands, Austria, and Spain, and they were imitated in a number of paintings and prints throughout the 16th century, especially in the works of Pieter Bruegel the Elder.

sentence_text: The left wing of the triptych represents the Paradise.Here, across the three inner panels, appear the First and Last Things, beginning with the Fall of Man on the left wing.The story recounted in the second and third chapters of Genesis has been placed in a lush garden; in the foreground we see the creation of Eve, followed by the temptation of the First Couple.

sentence_text: In the middle distance they are driven from the garden by an angel.

sentence_text: Although the revolt of proud Lucifer and his followers is not mentioned in Genesis, it appears in Jewish legends and entered Christian doctrine at an early age.

sentence_text: These were the angels who sinned and whose prince, envying Adam, caused him to sin in turn.

sentence_text: It was further believed that Adam and Eve had been created by God in order that their offspring might fill the places left vacant by the fallen angels.

sentence_text: In this panel, Bosch thus depicted the entrance of sin into the world and accounted for the necessity of the Last Judgment.The inclusion of the Fall of Adam and Eve in a representation of the Last Judgment is unusual; the other two panels of the Vienna triptych depart even more from traditional iconography
title: Last Judgment Triptych (left wing)

sentence_text: The right wing represents St Anthony in Meditation.The powerful evocation of a corrupt and stinking world is no less apparent in the right wing, where Bosch used as his starting point the story of the Devil-Queen, a subject he had already depicted in the Hermit Saints altarpiece.

sentence_text: The open-air table, the cloth slung tent-like over the tree stump beside the temptress, and the servants pouring wine seem like a grotesque parody of the traditional Garden of Love.

sentence_text: In this work and its companion picture (Capriccio: A Palladian Design for the Rialto Bridge, also in Parma) Canaletto created two of his most complex and intriguing capricci.

sentence_text: He had already depicted an unrealised scheme for the Rialto Bridge, but in these works went one stage further and painted alternatives to the actual bridge surrounded by a sophisticated and extensive group of invented buildings.The bridge and extraordinary circular temple at the left appear to be almost entirely imaginary.
title: Capriccio: The Grand Canal, with an Imaginary Rialto Bridge and Other Buildings

sentence_text: Canaletto is first recorded in England in spring 1746, and his earliest paintings of London are depictions of the new Westminster Bridge, a subject he was to portray from various vantage points.

sentence_text: The celebrations accompanied the appointment of the new Lord Mayor of London.

sentence_text: The Venetian artist is thought to have spent some time in Rome, where he could have become familiar with Lingelbach's work.Carlevaris's town views are also deeply rooted in the Venetian tradition of depicting historic or festive events.

sentence_text: 6 of the series of nine large paintings "Stories from the Life of St Ursula".The same colour tone and mood as in the Apotheosis, but used in a much more self-assured perspective composition, appears again in the Meeting between Pope Cyriacus and the Pilgrims.
title: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope
author: Vittore CARPACCIO

sentence_text: Scholars do not agree on the dating of this canvas and suggestions go from 1491, the same year as the Apotheosis of St Ursula, to 1493, the year of the Martyrdom of the Pilgrims and the Funeral of St Ursula.
title: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope
author: Vittore CARPACCIO

sentence_text: Even the question of the identification of the character in red standing next to Pope Cyriacus as Ermolao Barbaro, an eminent Humanist and the Venetian ambassador to the Vatican who died in 1493 after having fallen out of grace in Venice, is used in different ways by the advocates of the various chronological theories.
title: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope
author: Vittore CARPACCIO

sentence_text: The style of the canvas would appear to suggest a more mature period than the Pilgrims' Arrival in Cologne canvas, which dates from 1490.The scene of the meeting takes place in the bright afternoon light: to the left, the retinue of virgins is shown approaching along the path, while the English Prince and Ursula, in the centre, kneel in front of Pope Cyriacus; and to the right the procession of bishops, prelates and dignitaries unfolds in the bright, sunlit meadow outside the walls of Rome.
title: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope
author: Vittore CARPACCIO

sentence_text: Each figure projects its own shadow to emphasize the hour of the day in which the historic meeting is taking place; like a brilliant colour prism it revolves slowly in an atmosphere of absolute enchantment.
title: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope
author: Vittore CARPACCIO

sentence_text: The calculated stage-like arrangement of the characters is echoed in the setting of the eight standards, the white mitres, the regular geometric shapes of the huge construction of Castel Sant'Angelo.
title: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope
author: Vittore CARPACCIO

sentence_text: Not even the tiniest of details is lost on this enormous stage: the lavish ornamentation of the damask copes, or the group of clarion players standing out against the sky on the castle's bastions, or the ivy clinging to the walls
title: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

sentence_text: Its construction began in 1542, at the behest of Losco Caldogno, an aristocrat and silk merchant from Vicenza, who had inherited an agricultural complex and fields in Caldogno the year before.
title: View of the Pastor Fido camerino
author: Giulio CARPIONI

sentence_text: Construction of the building and the decoration of the interiors extended over a long period of time, brought to completion only in 1570.The fresco decoration of the loggia, the Central Hall, and two other rooms (Room of Scipio and Room of Sofonisba) was completed by Giovanni Antonio Fasolo and Giovanni Battista Zelotti by 1570.
title: View of the Pastor Fido camerino
author: Giulio CARPIONI

sentence_text: In 1646, the interior distribution of the space was modified and a new small room (camerino), connecting the Room of Scipio and the Room of Sofonisba, was frescoed by the young Venetian painter Giulio Carpioni.
title: View of the Pastor Fido camerino
author: Giulio CARPIONI

sentence_text: These frescoes illustrate scenes from Guarino Guarini's Pastor Fido (The Faithful Shepherd).
title: View of the Pastor Fido camerino
author: Giulio CARPIONI

sentence_text: The room was partly frescoed earlier by an unidentified sixteenth-century painter with some episodes taken from Torquato Tasso's Aminta.Carpioni's paintings in the camerino unfold in three compartments on the walls, each containing an episode from the poem; the compartments are embellished along the side edges with refined, colourful floral festoons.
title: View of the Pastor Fido camerino
author: Giulio CARPIONI

sentence_text: The scenes depict: The Coronation of the Nymph Amaryllis, Winner of the Kissing Competition; The Pursuit of Corsica by a Satyr; and the Wounding of Dorinda, Mistaken by the Shepherd Silvio for One of His Prey.
title: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

sentence_text: In the corners of the room, as a connective element, are two unusual, extremely lively candelabra.

sentence_text: Completing the cycle, above the two doors are the scenes Cupid Taming the Lion and The Struggle between Erote and Anterote

sentence_text: During his years in Rome, Annibale was an enthusiastic exponent of a cleansed classical art.

author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: On this, and also on the large landscape lunettes in the Galleria Doria Pamphilj, Annibale was helped by young assistants, nearly all from Emilia, who subsequently established the classical style there that proved to be so successful.
title: Rest on Flight into Egypt
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: Annibale Carracci's reputation as an "academic artist" and the fact that for over three centuries he has been regarded as a paradigm of classical style, has meant that for too long we have overlooked his no less fascinating handling of nature, evident in his Landscape with the Flight into Egypt.
title: Rest on Flight into Egypt
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: But the melancholy which can be glimpsed in that landscape, whose symmetry almost anticipates Poussin's, overwhelmed Annibale as a man and he stopped painting toward the end of his life.
title: Rest on Flight into Egypt
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: Fortunately, his true place in art has been recognized by recent critical works
title: Rest on Flight into Egypt
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: In 1597 Cardinal Odoardo Farnese commissioned Annibale Carracci's great masterpiece, the ceiling of the Galleria Farnese in the Palazzo Farnese, the most splendid and influential ceiling decoration in Rome since that of the Sistine Chapel.
title: The Galleria Farnese
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: Annibale's brother Agostino assisted him on at least two of the scenes until they quarrelled and Agostino left Rome.
title: The Galleria Farnese
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: In contrast to the earlier interpretation which saw them as a Neoplatonic allegory of the victory of Celestial Love over physical passion, in recent years Annibale's frescoes have generally been regarded as a witty and joyous celebration of the classical gods in love.During the 1570s and 1580s fresco cycles with mythological subjects had been relatively unfashionable in Rome, since the climate of the Counter Reformation favoured religious decoration, even in secular buildings such as palaces and villas.
title: The Galleria Farnese
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: It may be a measure of the Catholic Church's confidence in winning the battle for souls that it could increasingly tolerate such overtly erotic decoration, even in a cardinal's palace, albeit in what was probably one of the more private rooms.
title: The Galleria Farnese
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: Besides celebrating love's power to conquer, it is likely that the frescoes were intended to complement the antique statues, some of the finest in one of Rome's most magnificent collection of antiquities, which were displayed there
title: The Galleria Farnese
author: Annibale CARRACCI

sentence_text: Each scene is accompanied by a motto written on a scroll beneath each box.One of the most famous of all Roman myths, is the story of Romulus and Remus, the twins who were suckled by a she-wolf.

sentence_text: The twin brothers were purported to be sons of the Rhea Silvia and Mars, the god of war.

sentence_text: Because of a prophecy that they would overthrow their murderous uncle, they were abandoned at birth and put into a basket that was then placed into the River Tiber.

sentence_text: The basket ran aground and the twins were discovered by a female wolf.

sentence_text: The shepherd then brought up the twins.When Romulus and Remus became adults, they decided to found a city where the wolf had found them.

sentence_text: The brothers quarrelled over where the site should be and Remus was killed by his brother.

sentence_text: This left Romulus the sole founder of the new city and he gave his name to it – Rome.

sentence_text: These were done in pastel and in them she explored the finest shadings of her subjects' characters, the most fleeting of their moods.

author: Rosalba CARRIERA

sentence_text: Thus, without falling either into the dangers of the encomiastic portrait or of the documentary, Rosalba matches the immediacy of pastel technique to the freshness of her psychological and social penetration of her subjects, offering an unrivalled picture of the society of her time.
title: Young Lady of the Le Blond Family
author: Rosalba CARRIERA

sentence_text: In the Elderly Lady the mature beauty of the noblewoman and her serene good-natured existence are conveyed with incomparable skill.
title: Young Lady of the Le Blond Family
author: Rosalba CARRIERA

sentence_text: No less typical of her work is the portrait of Cardinal Melchior de Polignac with its superb rendering of the physical features of the subject, catching immediately the wilful character of the prelate.The artist uses her pastels with consummate skill in conveying the fresh innocence of the Young Lady of the Le Blond Family

sentence_text: The picture shows the south wall of the Salone Terreno (Room of Giovanni da San Giovanni) on the ground floor of the Palazzo Pitti.The Palazzo Pitti in Florence, purchased from the Pitti family by the wife of Duke CosimoI de' Medici in 1549 and renovated and expanded by Bartolommeo Ammanati, served as a residence of royal proportions for roughly 350 years.
title: View of the south wall

sentence_text: It was occupied by the dynasties of the Medici, the Habsburgs, and finally the Savoyards, and subjected to constant adaptations and alterations.
title: View of the south wall
author: CECCO BRAVO

sentence_text: Intensive use by ruling families resulted in the lavish decoration of all floors.
title: View of the south wall
author: CECCO BRAVO

sentence_text: Fresco painters from three centuries  contributed to the fixed decor of the public rooms and living quarters.
title: View of the south wall
author: CECCO BRAVO

sentence_text: Of its numerous apartments two suites of rooms stand out because of their decoration, function and size.
title: View of the south wall
author: CECCO BRAVO

sentence_text: These took their present form under Grand Duke Ferdinando II de' Medici (1610-1670), and for the most part they were spared later encroachments owing to their high-quality frescoes.
title: View of the south wall
author: CECCO BRAVO

sentence_text: These are the reception rooms in the left (north) wing used by Ferdinando II.
title: View of the south wall
author: CECCO BRAVO

sentence_text: The rooms on the cooler ground floor, directly connected with the Boboli Gardens by way of a loggia and a terrace, served him as a summer apartment (Appartamento d'Estate); his winter quarters (Appartamento d'Inverno), reached by way of a large staircase and capable of being heated, lie directly above these on the piano nobile.Several different painters worked on the decoration of the large hall on the ground floor (Salone Terreno).
title: View of the south wall
author: CECCO BRAVO

sentence_text: Its virtuoso wealth of forms, the scenographic bravura of its architectural painting, and its strikingly original programmatic concept, makes the room an outstanding example of seventeenth-century Florentine painting, standing as it does between tradition and modernism.

sentence_text: The east wall of the Salone and the ceiling was painted by Giovanni da San Giovanni in 1635-36, the south wall by Cecco Bravo in 1638, the west wall by Ottavio Vannini in 1639-41, and the north wall by Francesco Furini in 1640-42.The wall paintings deal with Lorenzo de' Medici and the return of the Golden Age under his rule.

sentence_text: According to Cigoli's nephew, Giovanni Battista Cardi, the picture was painted while his uncle was working for Cardinal Pompeo Arrigoni in Frascati just outside Rome.

sentence_text: Cigoli, a Florentine, is documented in Rome between 1606-07, a date which accords well with the style of The Sacrifice of Isaac.

sentence_text: There are several preparatory studies for the painting, one of which is on the verso of a drawing for Massimo Massimi's Ecce Homo of 1607, making it safe to assume that Cigoli was working on both pictures at the same time.Although The Sacrifice of Isaac was painted in Rome, the composition clearly recalls the Florentine tradition of Lorenzo Ghiberti and Andrea del Sarto.

sentence_text: Isaac's sensuous nude body, however, reflects the artist's first-hand experience of classical sculpture.

sentence_text: Despite the inherent suspense of the narrative, the picture itself lacks dramatic tension.

sentence_text: Abraham's massive red tunic serves as a foil for Isaac's unblemished adolescent body, shifting the emphasis to the work's more lascivious characteristics.

sentence_text: Most of the frescoes in the transept of the upper church of San Francesco, as well as in the apse, were executed all at once by Cimabue and his workshop.
title: View of the transept and apse from the east

sentence_text: Cimabue, who came from Florence, is the first of the mural painters active in Assisi who can be identified by name.

sentence_text: The subject matter of the extensive pictorial program that was executed under Cimabue's direction in the transept and the apse is based for the most part on the dedications of the altars in the western section of the church.
title: View of the transept and apse from the east
author: CIMABUE

sentence_text: A thirteenth-century inscription indicates that the altar in the south transept was dedicated to the archangel Michael; the high altar, to the birth of the Virgin; and the altar in the north transept, to the apostles or to Peter and Paul.
title: View of the transept and apse from the east
author: CIMABUE

sentence_text: Accordingly, the apse had scenes from the life of the Virgin, culminating in the Assumption; the south transept had motifs from the Apocalypse and a large Crucifixion on the east wall; the north transept arm had scenes from the lives of the apostles and another large Crucifixion; and the crossing vault had the evangelists.The scenes from the life of the Virgin in the apse of the Upper Church represent the first large program dedicated to Mary in the history of Italian painting.
title: View of the transept and apse from the east
author: CIMABUE

sentence_text: The paintings of the upper registers are almost entirely destroyed.

sentence_text: The four large fields of the basamento to the left and right of the papal throne are dedicated to the death and glorification of the Virgin.

title: Reclining River Nymph at the Fountain
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: There exists several copy of this painting made by the workshop of Cranach.
title: Reclining River Nymph at the Fountain
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The original painting is in Leipzig
title: Reclining River Nymph at the Fountain
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The provenance of this picture is unknown.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: It is one of a series of paintings in various sizes, representing Venus or a female nude, turned out in quantities by Cranach and his studio; these were popular among the clientele of humanists for whom he worked.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: However, this conception of Venus belongs to a German tradition which derives its inspiration from Gothic art.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The juvenile air, the slender forms, the tiny breasts an narrow hips, the rounded forehead, all go to make up the physical characteristics of the women (including the Virgins) represented in German art since the fourteenth century.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: This is quite unlike the conception of Dürer's Eve (1504), which was based on an objective and scientific study of the proportions of the human body.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The strange pirouetting movements of the legs, crossed over one another, occurs frequently in the engravings of Master E.S.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: As indicated in the romances and the books of sermons, a swaying walk was one of the ways of expressing worldly elegance for women of this Gothic world from the fourteenth century; but here this Gothic mannerism meets and contributes to another kind - the 'Mannerism' of art history.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Mannerist painters and sculptors, whether Italian, German, or French, all admired what Italian aestheticians called 'la linea serpentina', which seemed to them the most beautiful of all forms.The Venus is clad only in a provocatively transparent veil; in some paintings this is a subsequent addition, but here it is original.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The better to set off the ivory whiteness of her body, Cranach has shown it silhouetted against a sombre background of foliage.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The landscape conveys in a few strokes an intense impression of the Germanic conception of nature.
title: Venus Standing in a Landscape
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Cranach painted many slant-eyed, narrow-waisted, high-breasted nudes with highly charged eroticism.
title: Lucretia
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: These nudes - depicted to order or almost mass-produced - came in life-size as this Venus and Cupid, or practically pocket-size
title: Lucretia
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Cranach's painting is about the human yearning for immortality and eternal youth.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Human beings dream of being young again, of leaving the worn outer shell and exchanging it for a new one.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The notion of the cleansing power of the elements, especially of water, is as old as humankind itself.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The centre of the scene is a pool filled with water.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Some steps lead down to the pool, which is surrounded by a fantastic landscape far from civilisation.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: People have undertaken arduous journeys to reach this solitary spot and bathe in the miraculous waters.In the left half of the picture wrinkled and frail old women are brought up on carts and stretchers.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: They are undressed and examined by a doctor before stepping into the water where the gradual process of rejuvenation takes place.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Their wrinkles and old sallow skin disappear, their flesh becomes rosy and smooth, and they turn into young girls.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: As they emerge from the water they are welcomed by a cavalier who shows them to a tent where they receive new clothes.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Old peasant women are transformed into young ladies of the court who indulge in the carefree pleasures of life.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The jollifications at the festive table, the dancing, music and lovemaking, all take place in a lush flowering landscape.
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: These are the realms of eternal youth, to which the hardships of old age, set in a barren rocky landscape on the left side of the picture, form a stark contrast.The fountain spouting water from the spring into the pool bears the statues of Venus and Cupid - evidence that this is actually a fountain of love rather than youth, and that the power of love is the true source of immortality
title: The Fountain of Youth
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Johannes Spiessheimer (Cuspinian) was a scholar in the court of the Emperor Maximilian I, himself a writer, who made Vienna, through its chancellery and university, the leading humanist city in Germany.
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Cranach painted the double portrait of the Viennese humanist Dr. Cuspinian and his wife Anna, daughter of an official of the Emperor on the occasion of their marriage.
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Cranach composed these portraits as a pair.
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: This is apparent in the continuity of the landscape behind the elegantly dressed couple.
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The trees at the edges of the painting, on the left and right of the figures, are placed so that their branches form an arch, imparting an air of grandeur to the sitters.The background was evidently composed with a distinct purpose in mind: nothing here is arbitrary.
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The landscape is full of erudite symbolism, probably devised by Cuspinian himself.
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The various images disguise hieroglyphic allusions to the cabbala.
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: However, it would be quite unsatisfactory merely to decipher the landscape background symbol by symbol without seeing its significance as a whole.
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Beyond a system of occult signs, the landscape allows a generous framework for the couple's understanding of themselves, providing a medium for the new cult of sensitivity and awareness of nature which some humanists were propagating in literary form through the Classical topos of the pleasance, or pleasure-park
title: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The painting can be dated around 1520, the date 1517 in the top left corner is a later addition.

sentence_text: Both half-length figures are placed close to the picture surface against a bright green background.
title: Portrait of a Young Woman

title: Portrait of a Young Woman

title: Portrait of a Young Woman

sentence_text: John the Steadfast (1468—1532) was a member of the Ernestine line of the House of Wettin.
title: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: During the lifetime of his brother, Elector Frederick the Wise, he became involved in the business of government.
title: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: After his brother's death in 1525, John the Steadfast inherited the position of Elector and became Cranach's new master, in which role he proved no less benevolent than Frederick the Wise.One of Cranach's main duties as court painter consisted in portraying the Saxon princes as well as their families and allies.
title: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The portraits were not only intended as documentation of the line of descent for royal ancestral galleries, but also as gifts.
title: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The mutual exchange of portraits was a court custom, with the result that we know what John the Steadfast looked like from a number of paintings by Cranach.The present half-length portrait shows John the Steadfast in semi-profile at the age of 58.
title: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: His arms are elided on the left and right edges of the painting, but the work's narrow format lends the portrait an expression of monumental immediacy.
title: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Moreover, the sitter stands out by virtue of the signet ring on his left hand, the chain around his neck bearing several rings and a small cross, and above all the rich embroidery on his shirt collar and the precious fur trim on his gown.
title: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: The garland of carnations in his hair, traditionally worn at weddings, indicates that the portrait might have been painted on the occasion of the betrothal of the sitter's son, John Frederick the Magnanimous, to Sibylle of Cloves in 1526, and that the Elector is depicted here as the father of the groom
title: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
author: Lucas the Elder CRANACH

sentence_text: Philipp Melanchthon (1497-1560) was a German reformer, collaborator with Martin Luther, the first systematic theologian of the Protestant Reformation, intellectual leader of the Lutheran Reformation, and an influential designer of educational systems.
title: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon
author: Lucas the Younger CRANACH

sentence_text: He stands next to Luther and Calvin as a reformer, theologian, and molder of Protestantism.Melanchthon had his portrait painted on numerous occasions, but he only sat to four artists: Albrecht Dürer (in an engraving of 1526); Hans Holbein the Younger (whose portrait of circa 1535 is in the Niedersächsisches Landesmuseums, Hannover); and both Lucas Cranach the Elder and his son Lucas Cranach the Younger.Cranach the Younger painted several portraits of Melanchthon, probably from the mid 1540s onwards.
title: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon
author: Lucas the Younger CRANACH

sentence_text: The earliest would seem to be that dated 1544, in Östra Ryd, Sweden, and the last painted from life is that signed and dated 1559 in the Städel Museum, Frankfurt am Main, finished just one year before Melanchthon's death at the age of 63.
title: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon
author: Lucas the Younger CRANACH

sentence_text: Such was the demand for portraits of Luther and Melanchthon that several posthumous works were produced by Cranach the Younger and his studio
title: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon

sentence_text: Cuyp's earliest dated landscapes of 1639 are astonishingly eclectic, but by 1641 he was painting panoramic views of the Dutch countryside in the monochromatic mode of van Goyen.
title: River-bank with Cows
author: Aelbert CUYP

sentence_text: The young Cuyp, however, favoured a distinct yellow tonality as against van Goyen greyish and brown hues.
title: River-bank with Cows
author: Aelbert CUYP

sentence_text: More important for Cuyp's subsequent development was the impact of Dutch landscapists who brought an Italianate style from Rome back to Holland; Cuyp himself never travelled to the south.Since very few of Cuyp's landscapes are dated, and none is dated after 1645, it is difficult to say precisely when the characteristic golden light, reminiscent of the Campagna the artist never saw, replaces the earlier paler one, and when mountain ranges, herds of cattle, and figures conspicuously set off against a sky begin to play an important role in his compositions.
title: River-bank with Cows
author: Aelbert CUYP

sentence_text: But by 1645 distinct traces of the style of Cornelis Poelenburgh, a member of the first generation of Italianate painters, and Jan Both, the leading artist of the following generation of Italianate landscapists, are evident.
title: River-bank with Cows
author: Aelbert CUYP

sentence_text: Jan Both became Cuyp's principal source of inspiration.
title: River-bank with Cows
author: Aelbert CUYP

sentence_text: The River-bank with Cows shows how rapidly he assimilated Both's motifs and sun-drenched light.
title: River-bank with Cows
author: Aelbert CUYP

sentence_text: From this time onward golden sunlight becomes the all-pervading element in Cuyp's paintings.
title: River-bank with Cows
author: Aelbert CUYP

sentence_text: It spreads warmth and beauty over the Dutch countryside, where sturdy animals - most often cows - take place of human heroes
title: River-bank with Cows

sentence_text: The picture has a complicated and symbolic message, in fact, the painter attempted to sum up the history of christianity.

sentence_text: He portrayed the Old Testament on the left and the New Testament on the right: the former  being represented by Moses and the tables of the Testament, and the New Testament by Jesus' sermon, payer, and desciples, the tree symbolizing the cross, and the mourners with a stone suggesting a grave.There are symbolic objects and scenes on both sides.

sentence_text: After working as a decorative painter in his home town of Bergen, Norway, Dahl studied landscape painting at the Copenhagen Academy from 1811 to 1818.
title: Cloud Study with Horizon
author: Johan Christian Clausen DAHL

sentence_text: Here he was impressed by the work of Jens Juel and Christoffer Wilhelm Eckersberg, but the crucial influence came with a study of the seventeenth-century Dutch masters of landscape.
title: Cloud Study with Horizon
author: Johan Christian Clausen DAHL

sentence_text: One of them, Allaert Everdingen, had visited Norway and subsequently developed a type of "Nordic landscape" based on his impressions.
title: Cloud Study with Horizon
author: Johan Christian Clausen DAHL

sentence_text: This style was later taken up by the Norwegian national movement in the nineteenth century.
title: Cloud Study with Horizon
author: Johan Christian Clausen DAHL

sentence_text: Alongside the "Italian landscape," the "Nordic landscape" also became established on the Continent early in the century.Stimulated by his first extensive travels through Norway in 1826, Dahl supplemented his previous range of motifs - waterfalls, moving clouds, and windswept trees - with depictions of the bare plateaus of the high mountain regions and their cloud formations, becoming an innovator in Norwegian as well as German landscape painting.
title: Cloud Study with Horizon
author: Johan Christian Clausen DAHL

sentence_text: In 1818, he settled at Dresden, where he associated with Caspar David Friedrich and Carl Gustav Carus.
title: Cloud Study with Horizon
author: Johan Christian Clausen DAHL

sentence_text: In 1824, like Friedrich, he was appointed professor at the Dresden Academy.
title: Cloud Study with Horizon
author: Johan Christian Clausen DAHL

sentence_text: Dresden and its environs began to feature frequently in his compositions, in which the sky often occupied the larger part of the canvas
title: Cloud Study with Horizon
author: Johan Christian Clausen DAHL
