author: Francis DANBY

sentence_text: His oils, ink drawings, and watercolours, focussing on lyrically romantic landscapes, represents one of the most significant contributions made by any artist to nineteenth-century British landscape painting.
title: Scene from the Apocalypse
author: Francis DANBY

sentence_text: He also concerned himself with religious themes, treated in a visionary manner.The present painting is presumably one of four depicting scenes from the Apocalypse.
title: Scene from the Apocalypse
author: Francis DANBY

sentence_text: In a Romantic nocturnal landscape evoking the infinity of the cosmos appears a vision of the giant angel described in Chapter 10 of the Apocalypse, descending in a cloud from heaven with a rainbow over his head and legs like columns of fire.
title: Scene from the Apocalypse
author: Francis DANBY

sentence_text: The natural scene in which the visionary apparition is set evinces a coloration and sophisticated painterly handling that explain Danby's rank as one of the finest British landscapists of the nineteenth century
title: Scene from the Apocalypse
author: Francis DANBY

sentence_text: This image of objective scientific representation was consistent with Medici interests
title: Two Hanged Teals
author: Cesare DANDINI

sentence_text: The sitter of this three-quarter length portrait is probably Anne, eldest daughter of Sir Jacob de Bouverie, 1st Viscount Folkestone
title: Portrait of a Girl
author: Bartholomew DANDRIDGE

sentence_text: Konrad Graf (1782-1851) was one of Vienna's most outstanding piano-manufacturers of the early nineteenth century.
title: Portrait of the Piano-Manufcturer Konrad Graf
author: Josef Franz DANHAUSER

sentence_text: He owned a veritable collection of paintings and was patron of contemporary artists like Josef Danhauser, from whom he commissioned his portrait in 1840.
title: Portrait of the Piano-Manufcturer Konrad Graf
author: Josef Franz DANHAUSER

sentence_text: Robert Campin, who is generally identified as the Master of Flémalle, had a workshop in Tournai from 1406 at the latest, and, as we know from several documents, it received many commissions from the city, various institutions, and private individuals.
title: Visitation
author: Jacques DARET

sentence_text: According to a document (which is a copy of old records of the painters' guild, dating from around 1482, that is to say some 50 years later) a certain Jacques Daret was an "apprentice" in the workshop at about the same time as Rogier van der Weyden; he joined it on 12 April 1427 and became a master on 18 October 1432.
title: Visitation
author: Jacques DARET

sentence_text: We do know, however, that Daret had already been working with Campin for over ten years, so he must have learned his trade as a painter long before 1427; the description "apprenticeship" cannot therefore be correct for him at this period.
title: Visitation
author: Jacques DARET

sentence_text: We may assume that both Daret and Van der Weyden completed their real apprenticeship earlier and they must have worked together in Campin's workshop around 1430 as trained painters.Four paintings executed by Campin's pupil Jacques Daret in 1434-35 for Jean du Clercq, abbot of St. Vaast in Arras, are extant and are unusually well documented.
title: Visitation
author: Jacques DARET

sentence_text: They originally ornamented the wings of an altar shrine decorated with alabaster sculptures.
title: Visitation
author: Jacques DARET

sentence_text: In these panels Daret shows himself a capable if not particularly innovative or sensitive artist, very closely related to Rogier and in particular to the Master of Flémalle.
title: Visitation
author: Jacques DARET

sentence_text: Daret's Visitation of Mary is so similar to Rogier's painting of the same subject (Museum der Bildende Künste, Leipzig)), which is certainly later, that we have to assume they had a common model.
title: Visitation
author: Jacques DARET

sentence_text: And Daret follows one picture from the "Flémalle group" so closely, the Nativity now in Dijon Museum, that it can almost be called a free copy.This kind of painting, which now appears mediocre in comparison with the works of masters such as Rogier van der Weyden, was still so new and unusual in its time that a chronicler tells us how the donor, Jean de Clercq, seen here kneeling on the left with his abbot's insignia, proudly showed this altarpiece wing to the participants in the peace conference negotiating the Treaty of Arras in 1435
title: Visitation
author: Jacques DARET

sentence_text: This painting is a typical example of the artist's late period, when he was travelling in his floating studio along the rivers Oise and Seine
title: River Bank
author: Charles-François DAUBIGNY

sentence_text: This is an incisive work with the emphasis on the lighting.
title: The Drama
author: Honoré DAUMIER

sentence_text: Daumier used the same subject in an 1864 lithograph
title: The Drama
author: Honoré DAUMIER

sentence_text: This type of Pietà, whether or not accompanied by other holy women, appears more than once in Gerard David's oeuvre and was adopted on various occasions by painters of his circle such as Adriaan Isenbrant or Ambrosius Benson.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: A model drawing may have existed in David's studio or perhaps there was another prototype by his hand which is now lost.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: On closer examination David seems here to have built on both Hugo van der Goes and Hans Memling.The composition of the scene is a kind of reprise of Memling's Reins triptych (Memlingmuseum, Bruges).
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: Here too, the scene is set in front of a landscape with on the left buildings intended to represent Jerusalem and on the right a group of rocks which serves as a repoussoir.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The tomb of Joseph of Arimathea, which he placed at Christ's disposal, has been hewn out of the rocks here.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: Wearing a turban and exotic clothing he stands in profile before the tombstone, while Nicodemus enters the tomb.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: With Memling it is a Roman sarcophagus which stands in front of the rock and which is being opened by Joseph and Nicodemus.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The composition itself, with the body held almost upright under the armpits and the head nodding to one side, derives from the right wing of Hugo van der Goes' Lamentation diptych (Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna).
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The figure of the Virgin placed parallel along Christ's body with her arm diagonally across it is an adaptation in reverse of the Virgin's posture in Van der Goes.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The same is probably also the case with the position of the squatting Mary Magdalene.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The St John, with his right knee and foot in frontal view, is also borrowed from Memling's Reins triptych.
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The spire in the landscape is probably intended to suggest Bruges' Our Lady's Church
title: Lamentation
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The left wing of the diptych depicts the Virgin and Child in the Church, while the right wing the donor Antonio Siciliano and St Anthony.The diptych was commissioned by Antonio Siciliano who served as chamberlain and secretary to Massimiliano Sforza, the Duke of Milan.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: In 1513 he was dispatched to Margaret of Austria in Mechelen on a diplomatic mission.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: It is assumed that Siciliano commissioned the painting from Gossart, who about 1513 worked at Margaret's court in Mechelen.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: However, the authorship of the diptych is debated, especially that of the donor (right) wing.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: Several alternative suggestions were proposed, the authorship being connected to the Antwerp Mannerists or to the artists contributing to the Grimani Breviary.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: Presently the right wing is attributed to Jan Gossart.The left panel is attributed to Gerard David.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: This attribution is supported by recent technical examination.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: More than any other Bruges painter, David inherited Jan van Eyck's legacy.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The left panel of the diptych is an adaptation of van Eyck's Madonna in the Church.
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: David made adjustments to the earlier model: he centred the Virgin in a wider view of the nave, added a third arch to the choir screen, and closed off the composition at the right with a series of columns matching those of the bays opposite
title: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: Gerard David interpreted with great originality the theme of Rest during the Flight to Egypt.
title: Rest during the Flight to Egypt
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The Virgin and Child are placed in the centre in a landscape.
title: Rest during the Flight to Egypt
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: A tiny depiction of the Holy Family on its way to Egypt can be seen in the background on the right.
title: Rest during the Flight to Egypt
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The influence of Renaissance art, especially Leonardo, is clearly visible, notably in the use of sfumato and the atmospheric variations of the background
title: Rest during the Flight to Egypt
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The work of Gerard David, another foreigner drawn to the wealthy city of Bruges, offers a final summary of the technical and spiritual tradition of the fifteenth century.
title: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: David was born in Oudewater in Holland, but worked mostly in Bruges between 1484 and 1523, where, in a manner of speaking, he became Memling's successor.
title: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: Two of his masterpieces, The Judgment of Cambyses (1498) and the Triptych of Jan des Trompes, belong to the Groeninge Museum in Bruges.
title: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: In both works, Memling's flawless precision and cool smoothness are combined with the anatomical realism and seriousness of Van der Goes.The triptych with the Baptism of Christ, even though it was probably done after the Judgment of Cambyses, still breathes the quiet, ethereal atmosphere so characteristic of the Flemish Primitives.
title: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: It is also one of the period's most remarkable artistic evocations of landscape and flora.
title: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: It was commissioned by Jan des Trompes, a leading civil servant in Bruges, who appears in the painting with his first and second wives (front and rear of the right wing).
title: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: His third wife donated it to the Chapel of the Vierschaar tribunal in Saint Basil's Church after his death
title: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The Baptism of Christ forms the central section of a triptych commissioned by the treasurer of the city of Bruges, Jean Trompes.
title: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The wings show the donor's family and patron saints on the inside, and the Virgin and Child and the donor's first wife with St Elizabeth on the outside.Nowhere does the artist demonstrate more clearly both his talents and his limitations.
title: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The present scene contains virtually no action.
title: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The kneeling figures of John the Baptist and the angel dressed in a sumptuous cope reveal a mutual correspondence in their approximate symmetry and subtly differentiated positions.
title: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The panel's central axis is strongly emphasized by the figure of Christ, the dove of the Holy Ghost and the apparition of God the Father.In David's paintings the landscape forming the background to religious scenes takes on the motionless and precious look of something whose serenity opposes it to the tragedy of what is happening in the picture.
title: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: One has only to look at the forest in the background of the Baptism of Christ, with its huge ivy-covered trunks, the strong rhythm of its escarpments and its foliage standing out against the blue of the distance.
title: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The still life of flowers in the foreground is characterized by a dazzling wealth of minute detail.This altarpiece was at one time considered one of the best works of Memling.
title: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: The study of its wing panels was rightly recommended to landscape painters as the work of a marvellous painter of foliage
title: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)
author: Gerard DAVID

sentence_text: David discovered the dramatically lit and forceful canvases of Caravaggio and his followers, and his full-length male nude and semi-nude studies such as Hector of 1778 and Patroclus of 1780 show how he had begun to use light and shadow to give weight and density to his figures
title: Patroclus
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: If little else were known of David, the self-portrait that he painted in May 1791 certainly looks the image of a Romantic.
title: Self-Portrait
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: Painted rapidly, with a spontaneous touch, it shows an excited, even wild young man, with freely curling hair, eyes aglow with almost visionary zeal.
title: Self-Portrait
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: He is looking slightly dishevelled and with a piercing gaze, very different from the normally relaxed pose of his sitters and perhaps an indication of the internal conflicts that eventually led him to become a fully committed Republican
title: Self-Portrait
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: When David was released from the Luxembourg prison at the end of December 1794, he became ill and so requested permission from the Convention to visit his wife's sister and her husband, Emilie and Pierre Sériziat, at their country house in Saint Ouen, near Tournan-en-Brie, about 32 km (20 miles) east of Paris.
title: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: This visit was cut short by the accusations of May 1795 and arrest, but he returned there, accompanied by a guard, to recuperate after his second and final release in August.
title: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: He then painted the portraits of his hosts.
title: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: Madame Sériziat is shown in an interior setting with her young son, having just returned from a walk.
title: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: Her cheeks are ruddy and she carries a recently picked bunch of wild flowers which are painted in a lively but meticulous manner.These two portraits were testaments of friendship and, by showing them at the 1795 Salon, he could prove that he was still able to paint after his ordeals
title: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: While Pope Pius VII remained in Paris after the consecration, David also painted his portrait and thereby joined an illustrious band of past artists - Raphael, Titian and Velázquez - as the painter of a pontiff.
title: Portrait of Pope Pius VII
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: David broke with protocol by sitting down while he worked, as previously tradition had dictated that the humble artist should kneel to paint the Pope.
title: Portrait of Pope Pius VII
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: David, though, did appreciate the honour bestowed upon him and apparently put on fine clothes and wore a sword as he worked.
title: Portrait of Pope Pius VII
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: He responded warmly to the venerable old pontiff and was both delighted and moved by the benediction that he received from the hand of Pius
title: Portrait of Pope Pius VII
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: David's first history painting in exile was an extremely original and disturbing interpretation of the late antique myth of Cupid and Psyche.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: It was painted for the wealthy Italian patron and connoisseur Count Giovanni Battista Sommariva and, although planned in Paris, it was only finished in Brussels in 1817.As related by the Roman writer Lucius Apuleius in The Golden Ass (late second century AD), Cupid, the god of love, fell in love with the beautiful Psyche and brought her to his palace, where he visited her every night without ever letting her see his face.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: But curiosity got the better of her, and one night Psyche looked at Cupid while he was asleep.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: Unfortunately a drop of hot oil fell from her lamp and awakened him, whereupon he abandoned her and the palace disappeared.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: From then on Psyche was condemned to wander the earth and perform impossible tasks in the vain hope of winning her lover back.Many other artists saw the lovers as innocent, tender and poetic, but David deliberately drew attention to the sexual aspect of the relationship.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: Normally Cupid was shown as a beautiful young man, but David depicted him as a grinning adolescent who seems proud of his recent conquest.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: A great contrast is set up between Cupid's coarse ruddy features and awkward angular limbs, and the pale, smooth and languid beauty of the sleeping Psyche.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: Unusually for David, the colours are bright and intense; in Brussels he looked at the colours used by Flemish Renaissance artists such as Jan van Eyck.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Jacques-Louis DAVID

sentence_text: Beside portraiture, Degas's early work was also centred on historical themes drawn from religious tradition or mythology.
title: Young Spartans Exercising
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Between 1860 and 1865 he painted five historical paintings, for which there are several sketches and versions: Young Spartans Exercising, Semiramis Founding a City, Alexander and Bucephalus, Jephthah's Daughter, and The Sufferings of the City of New Orleans, the latter being his first entry at the Salon.These paintings are very original and unlike any historical painting in the nineteenth century.
title: Young Spartans Exercising
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: They conformed to the rules of classicist composition, but they were also  innovative because of the freshness of his figures and the warm colours of his landscapes.The Young Spartans Exercising was reworked several times, and numerous related drawings and studies survive
title: Young Spartans Exercising
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Degas's family were related to the Italian aristocracy, among them Baroness Bellelli and Duchess Morbilli.
title: Hilaire de Gas
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: In 1856 he traveled for the first time to Italy, where he intended to make the acquaintance of his Italian relatives.
title: Hilaire de Gas
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: This journey, which was followed by another in 1858 and several more in 1859, was Degas's real education.
title: Hilaire de Gas
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: In Italy, Degas preferred the Quattrocento painters and the exponents of Florentine Mannerism.The people Degas depicted in that time were almost all members of his family, especially his sisters and brothers, and himself.
title: Hilaire de Gas
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: His early portraits achieve their culmination in his group portrait The Bellelli Family.The present painting represents Hilaire de Gas, the painter's grandfather
title: Hilaire de Gas
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Degas produced many portraits between 1865 and 1870, too, the major ones of which were Thérèse de Gas, Double Portrait, The Collector, Madame Hertel, Duke and Duchess of Morbilli, Jacques Joseph (James) Tissot, Mademoiselle Dihau at the Piano, Madame Camus at the Piano, Portrait of Hortense Valpinçon as a Child.Conventional as they may be, these portraits highlight both what is characteristic and what is casual in the personality and deportment of the sitter
title: The Collector
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Many of Degas's drawings and studies of movement after 1860 are inspired by race-course scenes.
title: The Parade
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: His paintings of horse races reflect how much he was influenced by the works of famous painters such as Théodore Géricault and Ernst Meissonier.
title: The Parade
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: He was similarly influenced by Japanese woodblock prints.
title: The Parade
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The asymmetry of this composition derives from Oriental art
title: The Parade
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Horse racing, a sport of English origin, became popular on the Continent at the end of the eighteenth century, and soon inspired such painters as Carle Vernet and Théodore Géricault, who were both influenced by English artists.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: It attracted the interest of later painters, too.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Manet emphasized the elegance of these occasions, while Degas preferred to observe the horses in motion.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: He focused on the movements of man and animal.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: His first sketches of racecourses date back to the beginning of the 1860s.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: At first he was interested  in the jockeys, but he also turned a keen eye on the spectators.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: This led to the At the Races in the Countryside.Degas never tires of the theme of the racecourse.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: On September 27, 1881, the newspaper "Le Globe" started publishing Major Muybridge's photographs of a galloping horse, and Degas used them for his sketches.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The photographs showed that traditional English prints were inaccurate when depicting galloping horses with their front legs outstretched.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: This is how Degas painted the horses racing in the background of At the Races in the Countryside of 1869.Degas exhibited this moderately colourful work at the first Impressionist exhibition in 1874.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The race itself is in the background, the foreground is occupied by a family scene centred on a baby, with the nurse, mother, father and even the dog atop the box.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The family is the Valpinçon family: the driver of the carriage is Degas's friend Paul Valpinçon, who is shown with his wife, a wet nurse, and in the nurse's lap, the couple's son, Henri.
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The people in the carriage are caught in their fashionable elegance
title: At the Races in the Countryside
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Degas produced many portraits between 1865 and 1870, too, the major ones of which were Thérèse de Gas, Double Portrait, The Collector, Madame Hertel, Duke and Duchess of Morbilli, Jacques Joseph (James) Tissot, Mademoiselle Dihau at the Piano, Madame Camus at the Piano, Portrait of Hortense Valpinçon as a Child.Conventional as they may be, these portraits highlight both what is characteristic and what is casual in the personality and deportment of the sitter
title: Portrait of Hortense Valpinçon as a Child
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The portrait of Estelle Musson, the artist's first cousin, was painted during Degas's 1872-1873 visit to New Orleans.
title: Madame René de Gas, née Estelle Muston
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Not long after marrying René de Gas, Estelle had gone blind.
title: Madame René de Gas, née Estelle Muston
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Degas shows her gaze by passing us, a vacant gaze bent upon vacancy.
title: Madame René de Gas, née Estelle Muston
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: It is a discreet and simple portrait of one woman's solitude and isolation
title: Madame René de Gas, née Estelle Muston
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: From 1870 Degas increasingly painted ballet subjects.
title: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: First he painted a series of ballet rehearsal pictures.
title: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier shows ten ballerinas being examined in the great hall.
title: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The white-clad Louis François Mérante, instructor at the opera house, is giving orders which the dancers have to follow.
title: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Those who are not busy exercising are watching the ballerina currently being examined with close attention.
title: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The work is organized around the polarity of group and single figure.
title: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The scene, remarkable for the rigour of its composition, has a distinctive energy centre in the vacant chair at the fore
title: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: From 1870 Degas increasingly painted ballet subjects.
title: The Dance Class
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: In these paintings he explored the subject's potential through variations on the theme.
title: The Dance Class
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: In The Dance Class he has grouped some twenty girls and one or two mothers too, watching or comforting their daughters.
title: The Dance Class
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Dominating the scene (and painted in as an afterthought) is instructor Jules Perrot, with the huge stick he used to beat out a rhythm.
title: The Dance Class
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: This trial session under the famed teacher is taking place in the rehearsal rooms of the old opera house in Rue Peletier, which has long since burned down
title: The Dance Class
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Horse racing, a sport imported from England, was a novelty at that time.
title: Racehorses in Longchamps
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Degas discovered racetracks as a subject for art in the early 1860s.
title: Racehorses in Longchamps
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: However, he rarely painted the course itself, he preferred to look elsewhere.
title: Racehorses in Longchamps
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: He was fascinated by preparations for a race, by false starts and the wait before the start, by the tension and the release of tension - all of them moments hardly laden with action
title: Racehorses in Longchamps
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: This painting contains an element of social criticism, similar to that in Zola's L'Assommoir" denouncing the destruction caused by alcoholism.
title: Absinthe Drinkers
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The last two customers at the café are seated in the right-hand part of the painting, with the gray reflection of the street behind them.
title: Absinthe Drinkers
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The couple is surrounded by emptiness.
title: Absinthe Drinkers
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: The actress Ellen Andrée and the engraver Marcellin Desboutin served as models, but the painting goes beyond a mere portrait.
title: Absinthe Drinkers
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: They become the symbol of a nameless destiny.Degas simply referred to this painting as In the Café, the present title was added later
title: Absinthe Drinkers
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Louis Edmond Duranty (1833-1880) was a prolific French novelist and art critic.
title: Edmond Duranty
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: He supported the realist cause and later the Impressionists.
title: Edmond Duranty
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: He was a frequent visitor to the Café Guerbois group, which included Manet, at the centre of the group, and many writers and painters.
title: Edmond Duranty
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Their vigorous debates provided Degas with an entirely new mental environment.Degas was particularly close to Duranty, and painted a celebrated portrait of him in 1879.
title: Edmond Duranty
author: Edgar DEGAS

sentence_text: Between 1875 and 1880, Degas often went to the music hall, where he sensed more than anywhere else the pulsing life of the large city

sentence_text: The first of Delacroix's paintings to achieve true notoriety, Dante and Virgil in Hell or The Barque of Dante, exemplifies a duality that pervaded his entire career.
title: The Barque of Dante
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: The shared influence of Michelangelo and Rubens is manifest here, but there is also a savour of the revolution so thunderously proclaimed by his friend and elder, Theodore Géricault, in his immortal painting, The Raft of the Medusa (1819).The Barque of Dante was submitted to the Salon in 1822, and makes clear acknowledgement of its debt to Géricault's The Raft of the Medusa.
title: The Barque of Dante
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Indeed, the influence of that painting can be traced for many years afterwards in Delacroix's work, for example, in his Christ on the Lake of Gennesaret (1854) or The Shipwreck of Don Juan (1840).
title: The Barque of Dante
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: The 'stage-setting' of The Barque of Dante looks forward to Baudelaire's pronouncement that Delacroix is an 'essentially literary' painter.
title: The Barque of Dante
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: But Delacroix had something much more important to leam from the Raft.
title: The Barque of Dante
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: In expressing the predicament of the shipwrecked everywhere in the world, Géricault had laid the foundations of an aesthetic revolution.
title: The Barque of Dante
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: The Raft of the Medusa marks the first appearance in painting of 'the ugly' and thereby proclaims its scrupulous respect for the truth, however repulsive the truth might be.
title: The Barque of Dante
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: This concern for truth is integral to the Romantic temperament.
title: The Barque of Dante
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Delacroix's experience of English artists is reflected here, alongside the influence of Venetian painting and the works of Rubens.
title: A Mortally Wounded Brigand Quenches his Thirst
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: A critic remarked: "The colour of this piece is as beautiful as some landscape imagined by Byron as the setting for the bloodstained body of one of the tyrants of Missolonghi.
title: A Mortally Wounded Brigand Quenches his Thirst
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Delacroix's grandest pictures have never left their country of origin.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Only in Paris can we fully appreciate the bold reconciliation of beauty with cruelty, sensuality with control, fantasy with observation, modernity with tradition that characterises the art of this influential painter.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: 'As Byron signifies Romantic poetry, so Romantic French art means above all Delacroix.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Like Byron he achieved his flamboyant artistic effects through intense intellectual application and a firm grasp of technique.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Pupil of an academic artist, he was essentially self-taught through the study of the great Renaissance and seventeenth-century colourists in the Louvre.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: He was fascinated by the vibrant brushwork of the Venetians and their Flemish heir Rubens, imitating their capacity to simulate brilliant daylight even in the shadows, their use of colour instead of line as the primary structural element.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: It was precisely these effects which, as employed by Constable in the Hay-Wain exhibited at the Paris Salon in 1824, caused a sensation and further exacerbated Delacroix's fashionable Anglomania.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: In 1825, having sold his picture of the Massacre of Chios to the French State, he set out for London with two English friends, the watercolourists Richard Bonington and Thales Fielding.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: They visited galleries and the theatre and read English poets.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Delacroix met other English artists, including Thomas Lawrence.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Appropriately for a painting in an English collection, the lifesize likeness of Louis-Auguste Schwiter, painted after Delacroix's return to Paris, is an essay in the portrait style of Lawrence.Schwiter, a lifelong friend of Delacroix, was himself a painter.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: He is presented here, however, as a gentleman, dressed in elegant black and hat in hand, standing on what appears to be the terrace of a great country house, as if waiting to be admitted.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: The blue Chinese vase with its heavily paint-textured flowers contrasts with the red lining of his hat.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Like the trumpet vine clippings on the paving, these touches of colour serve to relate the foreground to the brooding sunset landscape (said to have been painted in part by Paul Huet, another artist friend), thus counteracting the isolation of Schwiter's monochrome silhouette.The portrait is lit from the right, a reversal of the more usual illumination from the left, highlighting the left side of the sitter's face and perhaps helping to account for the curiously tentative impression he gives, despite his firm stance in the centre of the picture and his direct gaze.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: The unemphatic 'modern' pose, with its hint of English-style reserve, and the free 'unfinished' brushwork made this full-length portrait, at once so formal and so unconventional, unacceptable to the judges of the 1827 Paris Salon exhibition, and it was rejected.
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Delacroix later reworked the painting, finally completing it in 1830
title: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

sentence_text: The capture of Algiers in 1830 had given France the Sultan of Morocco as a neighbour.
title: The Women of Algiers
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Louis Philippe's government decided to send him an ambassador extraordinary, the Comte de Mornay; the latter wished to take an official artist with him and chose Eugene Delacroix.
title: The Women of Algiers
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: The mission left Toulon on 11 January 1832, landed at Tangiers on the 25 January, travelled through a part of Morocco, and returned via Oran and Algiers.During his visit to this country, Delacroix witnessed spectacles belonging to a noble and primitive way of life which provided material for his art until he died; but he had not been allowed to enter the jealously guarded harems of the Moslems.
title: The Women of Algiers
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: It was the chief harbour engineer at Algiers who persuaded one of the port officials, a former reis or owner of privateers, to allow Delacroix into his own harem.In these few hours Delacroix did several watercolour sketches, some of which are in the Louvre.
title: The Women of Algiers
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Using them as a basis, he painted a large picture on his return, and exhibited it in the 1834 salon.
title: The Women of Algiers
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: He wanted to show the dark tones of flesh and the subdued colours in the warm half-light of the harem.In 1849 he painted another smaller version of the same subject, now in the Musée de Montpellier.
title: The Women of Algiers
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Here the colours are softer and the atmosphere more intimate; it has a note of nostalgia absent from the 1834 Salon picture, which is still full of his first impressions, and which already foreshadows Renoir.
title: The Women of Algiers
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: The latter artist was well aware of this relationship; in 1872 he painted a large picture inspired by Delacroix's canvas and called Les Parisiennes habillées en Algériennes (Tokyo Museum).
title: The Women of Algiers
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: He had already done an Odalisque and exhibited it in the 1870 Salon.
title: The Women of Algiers

sentence_text: (Chester Dale Collection, New York.)
title: The Women of Algiers

title: The Abduction of Rebecca

title: The Abduction of Rebecca

sentence_text: Géricault had inspired in Delacroix his fascination with horses, the emblematic beasts of Romantic painting.
title: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable

sentence_text: But his love of horses was fully satisfied only in Morocco.
title: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Thereafter the Arab horses that he had seen and drawn during his voyage constituted a kind of repertoire.
title: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable
author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: For one of his last paintings, Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable, he drew on a scene that he had witnessed in Tangier, when the horses of Mornay and the English Consul were fighting.

author: Eug?ne DELACROIX

sentence_text: Delaroche's early work consists mainly of subjects from the Old Testament, while later he chose subjects from French and English history.
title: The Death of Elizabeth I, Queen of England

sentence_text: He was one of the most popular painters of his time, his paintings satisfied the need for education through art and the demand for sensibility.

sentence_text: Both his carefully researched interiors and costumes and the theatrical content made his paintings so popular.

title: The Death of Elizabeth I, Queen of England

sentence_text: But this was in keeping with contemporary taste for decorative history painting, which had gone to extremes in its meticulous attention to detail in the objects, furniture, and costumes.The painting was exhibited at the Salon of 1827/28

sentence_text: Anglomania was in fashion in France in the 1820s and 1830s.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

sentence_text: Interest in British history, fuelled by the novels of Sir Walter Scott, was further stimulated by parallels drawn between recent events in France and the turbulent accounts of Tudors, Stuarts and the Civil War.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: The pictorial representation of British history may have been pioneered in Britain, but it was the Frenchman Paul Delaroche who gained a European reputation with the grand scenes drawn from it which he exhibited at the annual Paris Salon between 1825 and 1835.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: Popularised through mass-produced engravings, these set pieces, combining ostentatious antiquarianism with the pseudo-realism of bourgeois melodrama, in turn influenced the painters of national history in mid-Victorian Britain.The painting depicts the last moments on 12 February 1554 in the life of the seventeen-year old Jane Grey, a great granddaughter of Henry VII who was proclaimed Queen of England upon the death of young King Edward VI, a Protestant like herself.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: She reigned for nine days in 1553, but, through the machinations of the partisans of Henry VIII's Catholic daughter, Mary Tudor, she was convicted of high treason and sentenced to death in the Tower of London.Delaroche, who based the painting on a sixteenth-century Protestant martyrology, has falsified the historical account the better to appeal to his contemporaries.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: Lady Jane Grey, a humanist-educated young married woman, was in fact executed out of doors.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: Attended by two gentlewomen, probably no less stoical than she, she resolutely made her own way to the block.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: She could not have worn a white satin dress of nineteenth-century cut with a whalebone corset, and her hair would have been tucked up, not streaming down over her shoulders.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: But a painting cannot be judged by the criteria of historical accuracy.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: Much more applicable to this particular picture are the standards of popular melodrama and tableau vivant.As on a stage, the heroine gropes her way towards the audience, gently guided by the elderly Constable of the Tower whose massive, dark, male presence acts as a foil to her own.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: A spotlight trained on her from above complements the dim stage lighting, reflecting from her immaculate dress and the straw which spills over into the front row of the stalls.
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey
author: Paul DELAROCHE

sentence_text: The emotions of each actor are carefully delineated and distinguished, and we are left in no doubt as to the character of each even of the lady in the background who turns her back on the terrible sight
title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

sentence_text: The aesthetically conservative principle of tables arranged strictly parallel to the horizontal edges of the painting was followed by Nicolaes Gillis and Floris Claesz van Dijck.

sentence_text: (Predecessors were probably family paintings such as Marten van Heemskerck's.)
title: Laid Table
author: Floris Claesz van DIJCK

sentence_text: Their still-lifes are classified as 'ontbijtjes' (breakfast still-lifes).
title: Laid Table

sentence_text: Onbijt(je) was a light meal which could be taken at any time of the day.
title: Laid Table
author: Floris Claesz van DIJCK

sentence_text: Strictly speaking, most of the paintings by Gillis and van Dijck are dessert still-lifes, developed at roughly the time by Osias Beert and Clara Peeters.All these artists show a table with a table runner and a carefully ironed, white damask tablecloth whose creases, regardless of the laws of perspective, run in parallel lines towards the back of the painting.
title: Laid Table
author: Floris Claesz van DIJCK

sentence_text: A relatively high viewpoint was also chosen, apparently to afford a good overall survey of the objects, which are arranged side by side, or in a circle, hardly ever touching or overlapping.
title: Laid Table
author: Floris Claesz van DIJCK

sentence_text: The precious drinking vessels and pieces of textile show very clearly that the arrangement is that of a privileged household.In accordance with etiquette, fruit, pies, nuts and confectionery were served as a dessert.
title: Laid Table
author: Floris Claesz van DIJCK

sentence_text: Cheese, which had a central role in Gillis's and van Dijck's art, was also part of the dessert.
title: Laid Table
author: Floris Claesz van DIJCK

sentence_text: Gillis and van Dijck build up pyramids of hard cheese in two or three layers: at the bottom there is half a large cheese with a rich, yellow hue, indicating that it is still very young, while on the top the cheeses are smaller and more brownish, almost grey in colour, showing that they are older and more mature.
title: Laid Table
author: Floris Claesz van DIJCK

sentence_text: The irregular traces of cuts with a knife - the only piece of cutlery on the table - are rendered extremely well
title: Laid Table

sentence_text: The meticulous finish, careful elaboration of detail and concentration of expression, especially in those compositions with single figures, are the hallmarks of a style that proved to be influential even in the late eighteenth century in the work, for example, of Jean-Baptiste Greuze.The biblical source for the painting is Matthew 14:6-11 or Mark 6:21-8, where the daughter of Herodias danced for her stepfather, Herod, on his birthday.

title: The Mother of Good Advice
author: István DORFFMEISTER

sentence_text: The cult of the Mother of Good Advice - obviously because of its anti-Islamic aspects - was encouraged by Pope Innocent XI, so in the 17th and 18th centuries it flourished not only within the order but throughout the whole Catholic Church.In Hungary the altarpieces representing the Mother of Good Advice sometimes also show the angels who, according to the legend, flew with the devotional picture and brought it to its place.The representation of this scene may come from a copperplate of Sebestyén Zeller, an engraver in Pozsony.

author: István DORFFMEISTER

sentence_text: In Sopron, however, the substitution of this usual environment for an allegorical natural landscape transmits an entirely original, thus far unknown  meaning of the iconography of the picture.

sentence_text: The literary products of the Enlightenment which spread even by way of leaflets, engendered a grave spiritual crisis, disrupting even the traditional unity of the clergy.

sentence_text: (Let the lying lips be put to silence, Psalm 31, 18) gives us a very perceptible rendering of the mood of the belivers confused in their traditional religiosity.
title: The Mother of Good Advice
author: István DORFFMEISTER

sentence_text: With the dark clouds in the background Dorffmaister presents us with a picturesque and inventive representation of the shock that befell the faith before omnipotence of reason, and makes us feel the atmosphere of the crisis caused in many contemporaries by awareness of helplessness.It is in this stormy, almost pre-Romantic landscape in this "mirror of the soul" that the gentle look of the Mother of Good Advice and that of the Child on her breast might have been an "apology" of orientation and inner satisfaction for everybody having recourse to her

sentence_text: This panel depicts a young girl at a window ledge with a cat and a mouse-trap, a hung duck and a pewter ewer beside her.Dou's genre paintings are often imbued with subtle emblematic meanings which would certainly not have been lost on his public.

sentence_text: In 17th-century paintings, and in particular in Dou's own work, certain everyday objects took on other meanings and were therefore chosen by the artist for a specific reason: a set of scales, for example, could allude to the virtues of moderation and temperance; an empty bird-cage was a conventional symbol of immorality; and the open mouse-trap and lascivious expression of the cat in this painting could equally have carried some erotic overtones

sentence_text: Instead of court ladies depicted in the guise of antique goddesses, Drouais chose to depict his ladies and gentlemen (and especially their children) in pastoral guises (say, of shepherds and shepherdesses) or as members of different, perhaps less fortunate classes such as harvest workers or Savoyards.

sentence_text: Jeanne Bécu, comtesse du Barry (1743-1793), was the mistress of Louis XV.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: She was the natural daughter of a poor woman of Vaucouleurs.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: Placed in a convent in Paris at an early age, she received a very slight education, learning little but the catechism and drawing; and at the age of sixteen entered a milliner's shop in the rue St Honoré.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: Subsequently she lived as a courtesan under the name of Mlle Lange.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: Her great personal charms led the adventurer Jean, comte du Barry, to take her into his house in order to make it more attractive to the dupes whose money he won by gambling.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: Her success surpassing his expectations, his hopes took a higher flight, and through Lebel, valet de chambre of Louis XV, and the duc de Richelieu, he succeeded in installing her as mistress of the king.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: In order to present her at court it was necessary to find a title for her, and as Count Jean du Barry was married, his brother Guillaume offered himself as nominal husband.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: The comtesse du Barry was presented at court on the 22nd of April 1769, and became official mistress of the king.Her influence over the monarch was absolute until his death in 1774 when an order of his successor banished her to the abbey of Pont-aux-Dames, near Meaux, but, the queen interceding for her, the king in the following year gave her permission to reside at Luciennes with a pension.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: Here she led a retired life with the comte de Cosse-Brissac, and was visited there by Benjamin Franklin and the emperor Joseph II, among many other distinguished men.Having gone to England in 1792 to endeavour to raise money on her jewels, she was on her return accused before the Revolutionary Tribunal of having dissipated the treasures of the state, conspired against the republic, and worn, in London, "mourning for the tyrant."
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: She was condemned to death by guillotine on the 8th of December 1793, and beheaded the same evening.By the time the comtesse du Barry had arrived at Versailles, Drouais had completed posthumously the last portrait of Madame de Pompadour, a sumptuous affair that surely qualifies as his masterpiece.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: It was fitting that the new royal paramour would choose as her official portraitist an artist who could immortalize her predecessor with such refinement and elegance.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: She commissioned him to paint for both the château and the pavilion of Luciennes a series of delightful pictures.
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry
author: François-Hubert DROUAIS

sentence_text: During the comtesse du Barry's years at court, Drouais created five distinct portraits of her, as well as additional copies of the five images
title: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

sentence_text: The painting is a portable triptych of a type that was fairly widely produced in Italy during the early fourteenth century, essentially for private worship.

author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: For the purposes of travel the wings would have closed inwards covering the centre panels and lying flush with the raised spandrel above the inner moulding.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The backs of the wings were most probably painted with imitation marble or porphyry, perhaps with decorative motifs, as opposed to narrative scenes.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The creation of a work of art of this kind was due to a combination of craftsmanship and painterly skills.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: Some of the finest surviving examples are Florentine or Sienese in origin.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The triptych in the Royal Collection is comparable with examples in the National Gallery in London, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, the Pinacoteca in Siena, and the Fogg Art Museum in Cambridge, Massachusetts, all of which, according to varying degrees of attribution, are associated with Duccio or his workshop.The exact attribution of the present triptych is unsettled owing to the multiplicity of hands at work not only in Duccio's workshop as a whole, but even on the surface of individual paintings.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The centre panel in particular is of a quality worthy of Duccio himself.

author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The same might almost be said of the lower scenes in each of the wings, certainly in their design even if the actual execution reveals evidence of assistants (for example, the gold decoration on the cloth of honour behind Christ and the Virgin Enthroned, lower right).
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The inconsistencies apparent in the architecture of Annunciation (top left) or the design of the two thrones are not unknown in Duccio's own work, as revealed in the Maestà of 1308-11 (Siena, Museo dell'Opera del Duomo) with which this triptych is comparable in date or possibly slightly earlier.The iconography of the panels is also significant.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: Paradoxically, the inner religious consistency is derived from the unusual combination of scenes, especially the pairing of enthroned figures in the lower sections of the wings.

author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The enthronement of the Virgin twice (lower left and lower right), for instance, suggests a temporal sequence before and after Christ's death as represented in the centre.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The Annunciation (top left) is comparable with the relevant scene (now in the National Gallery, London) from the Maestà, whereas both Saint Francis receiving the Stigmata (top right) and Christ and the Virgin Enthroned (lower right) recall frescoes in the Upper Church of St Francis, Assisi (the former in the nave from the Life of Saint Francis and the latter, earlier in date and by Cimabue, in the transept).
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: These connotations and the treatment of the crucifixion in a devotional, as opposed to a narrative sense, imply a Franciscan origin for this triptych.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: The quantity of blood depicted in the central scene (some of it removed in an earlier restoration) is an unusual feature in a work on this scale.Probably before it became part of the Royal Collection the triptych had been dismantled and put in a heavy gothic frame, which was removed when it was cleaned in 1930.
title: Triptych
author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: After this the triptych was displayed in a shadow box with a simpler frame.

author: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna

sentence_text: This, too, was considered to be inappropriate and the present reconstruction of the triptych was devised in 1988, although further thought has since been given to the angle at which the two wings should be positioned in order to make proper visual sense of the architecture.

sentence_text: During the second quarter of the 17th century a group of artists began to specialize in painting the life of soldiers.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: Scenes of plunder and battle were depicted but the ancient battle of sexes, where the field of action was a room in an inn or a barrack, and in which the outcome of the struggle is not much in doubt, was more frequently represented.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: Other popular subjects were soldiers drinking, smoking and gambling at cards or tric-trac, activities that contemporary predicants and moralists condemned as vices that endanger salvation.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: But it is doubtful if the painters of these scenes and their clients viewed them as pictorial reminders of the perils of sin and the inexorable need to lead a virtuous life.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: Pictures of the life of off-duty soldiers were called by the Dutch 'cortegaardjes' a corruption of the French term 'corps de garde'.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: The better ones show little movement or overt action.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: Painters of them had a special feeling for tonal values and their pictures take on a certain still-life quality.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: In their half-dark interiors the light glitters over uniforms, and a fine subdued play of colours, mostly broken and harmonized by delicate half-tones, betrays the Dutch gift for intimate pictorial qualities and a subtle rendering of textures.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: Some even anticipate the achievement of the high society painters of the following generation, when well-to-do burghers rather than soldiers and their friends became the favoured subject of genre painters.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: Specialists in this category worked in Amsterdam, Utrecht, Delft, but seldom in Haarlem.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: The leading ones in Amsterdam were Willem Duyster and Pieter Codde.What sets Duyster's rare pictures apart from those made by his contemporaries is his distinct chiaroscuro and the refinement of his colours.
title: Soldiers beside a Fireplace
author: Willem Cornelisz. DUYSTER

sentence_text: He was also better able than any of them to convey the fascinating visual drama which can take place  when people do little more than confront each other.

sentence_text: He wears fine kid gloves.Inside the room is a tall archway, partly framing Dürer's head, and to the right a window opens out onto an exquisite landscape.

author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: Lot is told that his family must not look back, otherwise they will be turned into pillars of salt.In Dürer's panel, Lot leads the way, dressed in a warm fur-lined coat and a magnificent turban.

sentence_text: He carries a basket of eggs and has a flask of wine slung over his shoulder on his stick.

sentence_text: His two daughters follow several paces behind, one bearing a bundle on her head and the other with an elegant casket and a distaff and yarn.

sentence_text: In this way, it differs from the Tucher portraits, which were intended for private use.The background, as in the Tucher portraits (Schlossmuseum, Weimar), is divided between the curtain and landscape passage, unlike those, however, it is divided rather unevenly.

sentence_text: The bright red curtain is wide and occupies most of the space on the right; the landscape, on the left, is reduced to a foreshortening that shows a small part of a river that meanders toward the back, behind a group of tall trees.

sentence_text: The figure represented, set with obvious grandiosity, is found in front of the curtain, highlighted by intense colour.The large fur-lined cloak is casually placed on the right shoulder only, to show, on the left side, the rich black garment with the puffed sleeve.

sentence_text: To the disorderly folds of the cloak correspond the parallel horizontal folds of the sleeve and the vertical ones of the garment.

sentence_text: The three-quarter position allows the painter to bring out the quality of the attire: the fur, silk shirt, and gold chain.

author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: The careful, fastidious representation of these meaningful details creates a powerful foundation for the setting of the head: vigorous, strong features, the pronounced nose and the strong-willed mouth, the furrowed eyebrows, as if from a sudden start or fright that makes him direct his gaze off to the side behind him.

author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: To the energetic expression of the face corresponds the nervous look of his left hand clutching his cloak and that of the contraction of the knotted fingers of the right hand that leans on an invisible window sill.Colour, form, and proportion heighten the expression of supreme resolution, an expression that is the result of a serious psychological study that Dürer conducted on the merchant, who was the same age as the artist and who was later to become the mayor of Lindau, his native city.The two side panels that represent two "sylvan men" are wings to the portrait.

sentence_text: At the same time as the Feast of the Rose Garlands, Dürer was working on the painting of Christ among the Doctors.

author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: The theme derives from the Gospel of St Luke (Luke 2, 41-52).On the bookmark at the bottom left of the panel, Dürer has recorded that this picture was `the work of five days', a pointed reference to his inscription on The Altarpiece of the Rose Garlands, the work of five months.

author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: Christ among the Doctors is not only a smaller panel, but the brushwork is much more spontaneous and the paint is applied with broad and fluid strokes.
title: Christ Among the Doctors
author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: Despite Dürer's statement about five days, he based it on a number of careful studies, including one of Christ's gesticulating fingers.

author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: Although not present on the original painting, two early copies of the panel have the word `Romae' added to the inscription on the bookmark and this suggests that Dürer visited Rome late in 1506.
title: Christ Among the Doctors
author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: It may also be significant that the original painting was in Rome's Galleria Barberini until its acquisition by Baron Heinrich von Thyssen-Bornemisza in 1935.The story recorded in the panel is of Christ's visit to Solomon's Temple in Jerusalem, where he debated with the learned Jewish doctors (or scribes).

author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: According to the Bible, this was the first occasion on which Christ taught.
title: Christ Among the Doctors
author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: Dürer's daring composition does not use the conventional temple setting which he earlier used in the lower left panel of The Seven Sorrows of the Virgin.
title: Christ Among the Doctors
author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: Instead he gives a close-up view of the faces of six doctors crowding round the young Jesus.
title: Christ Among the Doctors
author: Albrecht DÜRER

sentence_text: The elderly doctors, caricatured faces which may well have been influenced by Leonardo da Vinci, argue with Christ by quoting from the Scriptures and gesticulating.

sentence_text: Christ, a sober boy of 12, quietly gestures with his fingers to make a point.

sentence_text: In the conversation with his mother and Mary Magdalen, Christ refused to abandon his planned visit to Jerusalem during the Jewish Passover, and foretold his impending death.The second panel shows Christ taking leave of his mother, immediately before he and his disciples set off for Jerusalem.

sentence_text: Some of the disciples are descending into the valley on the right, with the city gate and walls of Jerusalem in the distance.The attribution of the panels to Engelbrechtsz., based partly on the correspondences in style, colouring and manner of execution with the Crucifixion triptych in Leiden, was recently confirmed by an examination of the two underdrawings using infrared reflectography.

sentence_text: The most famous work of Jan van Eyck is a huge Ghent Altarpiece with many scenes in the city of Ghent.

sentence_text: On the frame a quatrain is inscribed which states that the polyptych was begun by Pictor Hubertus Eyck, and finished by his brother Jan, at the request of Jodocus Vijd, deputy burgomaster of Ghent, warden of the church of St John, and of his wife, Elisabeth Borluut, who commissioned it.
title: The Ghent Altarpiece (wings open)

sentence_text: The verse was placed there when the altarpiece was installed on 6 May 1432.The stylistic analysis reveals that in the painting the work of two different hands can be clearly discerned.

sentence_text: The overall conception of the altarpiece is the work of Hubert, along with the execution of certain parts, such as the panels in the lower tier.

sentence_text: Here, the manner is archaic, and reflects the continuing dominance of the international style that was practised by Broederlam.
title: The Ghent Altarpiece (wings open)
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: The composition is typically unoriginal: the landscape is still conceived as a distant background, with which the figures at the front have no organic relation, an effect that is reinforced by the bird's eye point of view.This polyptych is mystical, not to say esoteric, in intention, and is imbued throughout with both spiritual and intellectual signification.
title: The Ghent Altarpiece (wings open)
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: When opened, it represents the communion of saints, which is "the new heaven and the new earth", in the words of the Revelation of St John.
title: The Ghent Altarpiece (wings open)
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Thus the central panel of the lower tier portrays the saints symbolizing the eight Beatitudes gathered round the altar where the sacrifice of the Lamb is taking place, at the centre of the heavenly garden which has sprung from His blood.To left and right, in the foreground, are two processions facing one another.
title: The Ghent Altarpiece (wings open)

sentence_text: One of these is made up of the Old Testament patriarchs and prophets, and the other of figures from the New Testament.

author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Some of them are kneeling, barefoot.

sentence_text: Behind them is assembled the hierarchy of the Church - popes, deacons and bishops, wearing sumptuous jewelry and clothes in the bright red of martyrdom.

author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: In the background are two further groups, facing each other as if they had just emerged from the surrounding shrubbery.
title: The Ghent Altarpiece (wings open)
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: These are, on one side, the Confessors of the Faith, tightly packed together and almost all dressed in blue; and on the other side, the Virgin Martyrs, holding out palm fronds and wearing in their hair crowns of flowers of a kind traditionally worn by young girls at certain holy ceremonies.
title: The Ghent Altarpiece (wings open)

sentence_text: In the middle of the panel, around the altar where the Lamb spills forth his blood, angels kneel, holding the emblems of His Passion.

sentence_text: Grace is symbolized by a radiant dove hovering in the sky, and eternal life is represented by a fountain in the foreground.

sentence_text: A paradisiacal landscape runs across all five lower panels, uniting them in a single composition.

sentence_text: It is strewn with plants from different countries and flowers of different seasons.

sentence_text: The central panel is vibrant with green, while those to the sides are more arid and rocky.

sentence_text: The horizon sits high in the frame and is closed off by groves of trees, behind which clusters of fairy-tale buildings can be made out, representing the heavenly Jerusalem.The community of saints also extends onto the side panels.

author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Magnificently arrayed horsemen, representing the Soldiers of Christ, are followed by the Just Judges.

sentence_text: Opposite them are the Holy Hermits who have renounced the world, and the Pilgrim Saints, who were favourite figures of identification throughout the Middle Ages.

sentence_text: They are led by a giant of a man, St Christopher.

sentence_text: Many later commentators have suggested that his great height would have reminded the contemporary viewer of Jodocus Vijd's brother, also called Christopher.

sentence_text: In the middle of the upper tier is God Almighty, the Word, essence and origin of the universe.

sentence_text: He is dressed in red and is crowned with a magnificent tiara.

sentence_text: At the far right and left of the composition respectively are the figures of Adam and Eve.

sentence_text: They were painted by Jan Van Eyck, and are set into trompe-l'oeil niches.

sentence_text: Light and shadow play delicately over their forms which stand out as though they had been sculpted in the round.

sentence_text: "The Arnolfini Marriage" is a name that has been given to this untitled double portrait by Jan van Eyck, now in the National Gallery, London.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: It is one of the greatest celebrations of human mutuality.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Like Rembrandt's "Jewish Bride", this painting reveals to us the inner meaning of a true marriage.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Giovanni Arnolfini, a prosperous Italian banker who had settled in Bruges, and his wife Giovanna Cenami, stand side by side in the bridal chamber, facing towards the viewer.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: The husband is holding out his wife's hand.Despite the restricted space, the painter has contrived to surround them with a host of symbols.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: To the left, the oranges placed on the low table and the windowsill are a reminder of an original innocence, of an age before sin.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Unless, that is, they are not in fact oranges but apples (it is difficult to be certain), in which case they would represent the temptation of knowledge and the Fall.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Above the couple's heads, the candle that has been left burning in broad daylight on one of the branches of an ornate copper chandelier can be interpreted as the nuptial flame, or as the eye of God.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: The small dog in the foreground is an emblem of fidelity and love.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Meanwhile, the marriage bed with its bright red curtains evokes the physical act of love which, according to Christian doctrine, is an essential part of the perfect union of man and wife.Although all these different elements are highly charged with meaning, they are of secondary importance compared to the mirror, the focal point of the whole composition.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: It has often been noted that two tiny figures can be seen reflected in it, their image captured as they cross the threshold of the room.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: They are the painter himself and a young man, doubtless arriving to act as witnesses to the marriage.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: The essential point, however, is the fact that the convex mirror is able to absorb and reflect in a single image both the floor and the ceiling of the room, as well as the sky and the garden outside, both of which are otherwise barely visible through the side window.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: The mirror thus acts as a sort of hole in the texture of space.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: It sucks the entire visual world into itself, transforming it into a representation.The cubic space in which the Arnolfinis stand is itself a prefiguration of the techniques of perspective which were still to come.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Van Eyck practised perspective on a purely heuristic basis, unaware of the laws by which it was governed.
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: In this picture, he uses the mirror precisely in order to explode the limits of the space to which his technique gives him access as soon as it threatens to limit him
title: Portrait of Giovanni Arnolfini and his Wife
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Here the visual and thematic elements are similar to those of the Chancellor Rolin Madonna.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Van Eyck is concerned with showing the presence of a vision and therefore of illustrating the reality of God in our world.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Just as Nicolas Rolin is shown in his palace, in the midst of an identifiable environment that seems to make his vision of the Virgin all the more real, so Canon van der Paele is shown in the choir of the collegiate church of St. Donatian in Bruges, where he is being presented to the Virgin by St. George and St. Donatian.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Hans Belting is of the opinion that this picture once hung in the choir of the now destroyed church.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: This would mean that the depicted location mirrored the real location.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Van der Paele would therefore have been able to see himself in the very place of his depicted vision and so "prove" to the world at large the reality of his divine experience.The exquisite brocades, furs, and silks are shown in an extraordinarily lifelike and brilliant way, a way that confirms their reality, their tangibility.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: On the other hand, the reliefs and sculptures on the capitals in the background and on the Virgin's throne all allude to Christ's salvation of humanity.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: The depictions on the throne of Adam and Eve, Cain killing Abel, and Samson fighting the lion, together with the depiction on the capitals of Abraham sacrificing Isaac, create an Old Testament framework which allows the observer to reflect on the mercy of God, who sent his son, Christ the Redeemer, into the world.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: Redemption from sin (Cain killing his brother) is possible only through the power of faith (Samson overpowering the lion).
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele
author: Jan van EYCK

sentence_text: The goodness and grace of God "at the moment of truth" (Abraham sacrificing Isaac) serves as proof of the redeeming power and presence of servants of God both celestial (St. George) and mortal (Canon van der Paele).This is how van der Paele might have expressed the message of the painting-that paradise was at hand-a message confirmed by its being set in a very real but also sacred context.
title: The Madonna with Canon van der Paele

sentence_text: The image of this famous repentant sinner, prototype of the penitent in Christian art, became one of the favourite subjects of European art in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.In a career that spanned only thirteen years, Fetti's work underwent an astonishing evolution, from objective realism to lyricism, from compact form to the erosion of space, from solid and plastic modeling to a broken and agitated kind of painting, from descriptive to tortuous brush strokes, from dry to oily and liquid tints, from local colour to tonality, and from analytical concreteness to a sweetly sentimental air.

sentence_text: In fact the painter conceived this theme in terms of a Meditation or Melancholy.It is worth remembering that Giovan Battista Andreini's drama Maddalena was published in Mantua in 1617, and may have provided the idea for the painting.

sentence_text: He assimilated many influences, ranging from Caravaggio to the German ERlsheimer.The picture by François that most shows the influence of Saraceni is the Holy Family with St Bruno and St Elisabeth, now in the Musée de l'Ain at Bourg-en-Bresse.

sentence_text: His altarpieces that survived in the Le Puy area, in the churches for which they were painted, are often surrounded by a provincial version of a sculptured and stuccoed framework in the Italian Baroque style.
