sentence_text: Although commonplace in Italy, such pictures in situ are rare in France; most seventeenth century altarpieces by the major painters are now in museums.
title: Holy Family with St Bruno and St Elisabeth
author: Guy FRANÇOIS

sentence_text: The Holy Family altarpiece has the simplified forms sometimes found in works by Saraceni and also the strong lighting suitable for a prominent position in a church, where the picture would normally be seen from a distance.The strength of some of Guy François' compositions has led some authorities to suggest that he was influenced by Nicolas Tournier, but the most likely explanations for their superficial similarity are that both artists brought back from Italy similar Caravaggesque influences, and that both of them were forced to rely on what they had experienced and learned without renewed contact with their sources.

sentence_text: The artist has chosen to depict an architectural ruin; it may testify to the sublimity of the past, but it is a monument in a graveyard.The Napoleonic invasion of Germany and the consequent War of Liberation had added a patriotic dimension to Friedrich's subjects of north German ecclesiastical buildings in ruins or, in imagination, raised again.

sentence_text: The painter's marriage took place in 1746; a very similar work, Mr and Mrs Andrews, is dated 1748.The open-air portrait is a familiar theme in the English school, whereas in eighteenth-century France the portrait is usually in an interior.

sentence_text: By 1883, and as a direct result of the collapse of the stock market the previous year, Gauguin's finances were in disarray, and he began to consider a change in career.
title: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: This painting demonstrates an attempt to align himself with the landscape Impressionist painters, perhaps from a desire to make money from the sale of his works, and is in marked contrast to the more laboured works produced while he could still consider himself an amateur.The subject of a snowy landscape was a typical Impressionist device to enable the artist to study the effects of colour reflections on a white surface and was particularly favoured by Sisley.
title: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: However, the handling in the sky and the foliage is more reminiscent of the work of Monet from this period.
title: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: The spontaneity of the brushwork and the subject matter would suggest that the canvas was painted out of doors, but there is a small related sketch without the two foreground figures, probably done in front of the motif, which presumably forms the basis for this more finished, studio painting.
title: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: This means that the two women were added later, and demonstrates that even at this date Gauguin did not feel tied to working solely from nature, and had already begun to use the subject of two conversing women which was to recur in his mature work
title: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: From November 1884 to June 1885 Gauguin lived in Copenhagen with his wife and family, and it was there that he painted this self-portrait.
title: Gauguin at His Easel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: His letters to friends in Paris chronicle what was for him a difficult period - he missed the cultural life of Paris, disliked the Danes, his wife's family in particular, and the harsh climate meant that he could do little work in the open air.
title: Gauguin at His Easel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: Increasingly he was forced to work indoors, without a model, and his subject matter betrays these constraints.
title: Gauguin at His Easel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: His work became increasingly premeditated.
title: Gauguin at His Easel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: However, in the execution, particularly in the flickering brushwork, this painting is still close to the work of his Impressionist years.Gauguin's rather romantic characterization of the solitary figure labouring in a garret establishes the tenor of much later self-portraits, in which he depicted himself as artistic martyr, culminating in the series of works of 1889 in which he increasingly identified with Christ
title: Gauguin at His Easel
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: Gauguin met Charles Laval (1862-1894) at Pont-Aven in the summer of 1886 and the younger artist became his pupil.
title: Still-Life with Portrait of Laval
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: The two were to journey to Panama and Martinique together the following year.
title: Still-Life with Portrait of Laval
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: Gauguin's role as mentor is alluded to in the way in which Laval gazes fixedly at the ceramic pot which was made by Gauguin in the winter of 1886-87, when he worked in Paris with the ceramicist Chaplet.The still-life with its piled up fruits, treated with tight diagonal brushstrokes and laid out on a white cloth, is reminiscent of Cézanne's painting Still-Life with Compotier which Gauguin owned at this date.
title: Still-Life with Portrait of Laval
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: At the same time, the oddly truncated head in the foreground is a homage to Degas, who had exhibited with Gauguin at the final Impressionist exhibition that year
title: Still-Life with Portrait of Laval

sentence_text: Things sacred are present in the background of Gauguin's portraits, which he wanted to put in expressive harmony with the faces, according to the Symbolist doctrine which inspired also Van Gogh.

sentence_text: Gauguin's Tahitian paintings celebrate the lushness and mysterious splendour of his new environment.
title: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: At the same time they are seldom correct pictures of Tahitian life, from an anthropological standpoint, but rather feature recastings and recombinations of objects and persons taken out of their normal settings, as was the case with several of his paintings done in Brittany.The most important paintings executed during Gauguin's first stay in Tahiti are the Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary) and The Spectre Watches over Her (Manao Tupapau).
title: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: In Ia Orana Maria Gauguin places the Christian story into a setting where both the figures and the vegetation are Polynesian.
title: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: A Tahitian woman, her young son, and two women standing nearby are shown in the obvious attitudes of the Virgin and Child with attendant saints or worshiping angels.Once again Gauguin has returned to the theme of the effect of profound religious faith on an apparently simple people, which had preoccupied him in some of his most important Breton works.
title: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: The apparently effortless fusion of Christian iconography with Tahitian subject matter is in fact carefully contrived, with the poses of the background figures lifted from the relief carving on the Javanese temple of Borobudur, photographs of which Gauguin had taken with him to Tahiti
title: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: In 1889 Gauguin had painted a pair of works entitled Women Bathing (Life and Death) and Woman in the Waves (Ondine).
title: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: The latter (in the Cleveland Museum of Art) depicts a naked woman, seen from behind, cast adrift in the waves, and in Fatata te miti he has reused the same subject, setting her within a Tahitian genre scene.
title: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: In Ondine, Gauguin had treated the myth of the water-sprite who can only become human after having a child fathered by a man.
title: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: Once again, he has explored the theme of the joy of sexual union as an essentially liberating activity, hinted at in the alternative title for The Loss of Virginity: The Awakening of Spring.
title: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: In Fatata te miti the sexual abandonment is seen as part of the natural rhythm of Polynesian life (the two women do not appear perturbed at the presence of the fisherman in the background of the work), a notion that was integral to the highly popular Marriage of Loti, which Gauguin had read before visiting Tahiti and which was calculated to appeal to a Parisian audience
title: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: The Moon and the Earth is Gauguin's depiction of an ancient Polynesian myth, in which Hina, the female spirit of the Moon, implores Fatou, the male spirit of the Earth, to grant humans eternal life.
title: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: It is a request Fatou resolutely denies.
title: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: The painting was included in the exhibition that Gauguin organized at Durand-Ruel's gallery in Paris in November 1893.
title: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: The works exhibited were his most recent: a few sculptures, three paintings from Brittany and 41 from Tahiti.
title: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)
author: Paul GAUGUIN

sentence_text: In the end, only 11 paintings were sold and the artist Degas bought Hina te Fatou
title: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)

sentence_text: This grisly subject was enduringly popular.

sentence_text: Once upon a time in Florence, the subject stood for the city's proud republicanism.

sentence_text: By the time Gentileschi made this work, probably for Cosimo II de' Medici, Florence was a grand duchy and the Baroque, with all its monumental and realistic cruelty, held sway
title: Judith and Her Maidservant
author: Artemisia GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: The painting depicts the appearance of an angel to Valerianus and Cecilia, a young couple who had been converted to Christianity.
title: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Cecilia had taken a vow of chastity and had persuaded her husband to do likewise.
title: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Valerianus had suspected her of secretly being in love with his f riend Tiburtius but the angelic apparition allays his doubts while also heralding their approaching martyrdom.The composition - showing the three sumptuously dressed saints as they express with dignity their astonishment over the apparition of the angel - incorporates the main elements of Gentileschi's art.
title: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: It represents a high point of his maturity, ranking with the Madonna of the Rosei family and the Annunciation in Turin.
title: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: The disciplined, orderly construction has a Neoclassical stamp that derives from the artist's Tuscan background.
title: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: The handling of the light shows the fundamental influence of Caravaggio, while the refinement of the surfaces in the gleaming satin and damask draperies and the soft warmth of the velvets are inspired by Bronzino.Typical of Gentileschi are the arrested gestures standing out against the opaque shadow of the austere interior; the figure of Tibertius, silhouetted against the light as he cautiously peers at the angel; the system of curves formed by the wings, the body and the long palm branch of the angel in flight; and the outstretched arms of St. Cecilia and St. Valerianus.
title: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: The structural elements of the composition are striking: the link between Tibertius' hand and the angel's foot; the alignment of the palm branch and the organ pipes, and the wreath of flowers, St. Cecilia's hand and St. Valerianus' knee; and the parallels formed by the figures of St. Valerianus and St. Cecilia, the organ pipes and the door frame, the keyboard and the dais.
title: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Every element is brought into complex play in this highly articulated composition, from the tips of the wings and the palm branch to the edge of the red mantle, St. Valerianus' foot and the velvet cushion.
title: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: The story of Cupid and Psyche is not a myth but a late antique fairy tale, by Lucius Apuleius (2nd century AD) in the Metamorphoses, or Golden Ass.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Psyche was a maiden so beautiful that she aroused even Venus' envy.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Cupid, sent by the goddess to arouse Psyche's love in some worthless being, fell in love with her himself.
title: Cupid and Psyche
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Orazio Gentileschi's brooding image of David contemplating the head of Goliath reflects a new type of meditative image introduced at the beginning of the seventeenth century by Caravaggio.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Traditionally David was shown either as an uncompromised biblical hero slaying Goliath or as a triumphant youth displaying the giant's decapitated head.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: In Caravaggio's David with the Head of Goliath (Galleria Borghese, Rome), which was likely to have been sent from Naples around 1609 as a gift for Cardinal Scipione Borghese, the adolescent hero gazes tenderly at his victim's head, creating a strong, almost erotic, bond.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Orazio's David does not interact with Goliath's head, rather he stands beside it lost in a moment of deep introspection, evoking a pensive atmosphere similar to the mood generated in Caravaggio's St John the Baptist.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Like the St John, David's body is pushed towards the picture plane and set off against a background of dense, dark foliage.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: This verdant background is strikingly different from the one in Orazio's small copper version (Gemäldegalerie, Berlin), in which David is framed by a rocky cliff.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: The difference has led some critics to suggest that Agostino Tassi was responsible for the landscape in the Spada picture, but there is no conclusive proof to substantiate this.Unlike the Berlin copper, where David is seen full-length, in the Spada version his body is cropped just below the knee and Goliath's head is turned upwards towards the viewer.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: It has been suggested that the Spada canvas was cut down at the bottom.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: However, technical evidence shows that instead it was extended on all four sides.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: Thus the picture would have focused more directly on the contemplative and melancholic David and the head of Goliath would have appeared to rest on the edge of the frame.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: A copy of the Berlin composition (Quadreria Arcivescovile, Milan) was paired with a version of Artemisia Gentileschi's Judith Beheading Holofernes , but there is no evidence to indicate that two pictures of such contrasting moods were originally conceived as pendants.
title: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath
author: Orazio GENTILESCHI

sentence_text: This is a case where a comparison will give a good idea of how differently the same subject was handled by Jacques-Louis David and one of his numerous pupils.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: David started the portrait of Madame Récamier in 1800 which was never finished.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: (However, incidentally, this portrait helped a contemporary item of furniture to become known under her name.)
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: When the master learned that the lady had also commissioned his pupil Gérard to paint her, he is said to have refused any further service.In David's portrait, noble simplicity, expressed by the simple dress and the Spartan decoration, is also eloquent in the open face.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: This might well appear more to the modern viewer than Gérard's version, which was judged to be more representative and flattering at the time.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: And comparisons with portraits of Madame Récamier by other artists suggest that Gérard had achieved a better likeness than David.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: The Spartan severity of David's composition, the Neoclassical sparseness of the arrangement, the cool handling of the room, the distanced pose, with the lady turning her shoulder to the viewer, were all elements with which Neoclassicism had operated for long enough.Gérard, by contrast, sets the lady in a noble park loggia, where she seems to be inviting to conversation.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: Her low-cut bodice is seductive, the red curtain flatters the subject and gives the flesh a rosy tint.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: Where David gave the beautiful woman a rather severe touch around the mouth, Gérard embellishes her features with the hint of a gentle smile, making her look younger.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: By contrast, David's portrait in the antique manner looks rather forced.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: Perhaps these were the reasons why his painting was never finished.
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: Madame Récamier gave Gérard's portrait of her to her admirer Prince Augustus of Prussia, a nephew of Frederick II, who had met the French beauty at the salon of Madame de Staël. For state reasons a marriage was impossible, but in the painting Madame Récamier was ever present in the palace which Schinkel furnished for the Prince in 1817.After the death of the Prince the portrait was returned to Madame Récamier
title: Madame Récamier
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: In 1819 Madame Récamier received as a gift from Prince Augustus of Prussia a picture by Gérard, an affecting realization of Madame de Staël as Corinne, set like Sappho on the wild shore of Cape Miseno and pausing in her recitation of an ode when interrupted by her infatuated admirer, Lord Nelvil.
title: Corinne at Cape Miseno
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: Corinne looks up heavenwards in her confusion
title: Corinne at Cape Miseno
author: François GÉRARD

sentence_text: Gérard specialized in domestic genre scenes, often depicting an idealized vision of the lives of bourgeois and upper class women.
title: Lady Reading in an Interior
author: Marguerite GÉRARD

sentence_text: Usually depicted in intimate settings, her subjects enjoy lives of leisure with their families or engage in elegant pastimes.
title: Lady Reading in an Interior

sentence_text: Her meticulous style derived from her study of the works of Dutch 17th-century masters such as Gabriel Metsu and Caspar Netscher
title: Lady Reading in an Interior

sentence_text: Géricault painted five studies of this theme for large painting which was never realized.

sentence_text: Two versions depicts the subject as a contemporary scene, to other three (one of them in the Louvre) as antique.In this composition created in Rome, the power of man struggling against beast is expressed through the study of antiquity and the forms of Michelangelo
title: Riderless Horse Races

sentence_text: Géricault seems to have felt something like an inner mission when he chose the most pitiable creatures in society for his subjects.

sentence_text: The subject is taken from Virgil's Aeneid (1:314-371).

sentence_text: The goddess Venus, the mother of Aeneas, appeared to him twice, first in the midst of burning Troy to bid him be on his way.

author: Giacinto GIMIGNANI

sentence_text: Later, when the Troyan were washed ashore near Carthage after the storm at sea, Aeneas and his friend Achates set out to explore Venus appeared once more, this time with bow and quiver disguised as a huntress, to direct them to Dido's palace.This painting depicts the moment in which Venus appears to the Trojan warriors disguised as a huntress and directs them to Queen Dido's palace

sentence_text: The campanile is represented with a temporary flat-roofed bell-chamber, which was in place from 1489 to 1511.The attribution to Giorgione is not universally accepted, some scholars attribute the painting to a painter close to Giorgione

sentence_text: Giorgione exploited the new style evolved in Venice through sensual subject matter.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: The Sleeping Venus is a case in point.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: The reclining figure was originally accompanied by a small figure of Cupid, but this figure was painted over in 1843.Giorgione placed the Venus across the whole width of the painting.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: She stretches one arm behind her head, making a long, continuous slope of body whose gentle curves echo the hills of the landscape behind and suggest some form of connection between the female depicted and nature.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: Painted at just the moment when Venice was defending its claims on the terra firma, it may, therefore, be possible to read Venus (Venere) as Venice (Venezia).Venus's sensuality is heightened by her red lips and by the deep red velvet and white satin drapery upon which her creamy body lies.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: Significantly, she is asleep, so the issue of decorum is bypassed.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: Her sleep implies dreaming and transport of the figure to another world.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: Thus the painting may be interpreted as a poetic evocation of a classical idyll.Several works of great beauty associated with Giorgione involve the collaboration of another distinctive master.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: In the Sleeping Venus a significant share has been assumed for Titian, especially in the landscape, where on the right a cupid has been painted out.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: The outstretched figure, stocky in proportions, is usually considered to be by Giorgione.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: The drawing is only approximative, with the outlines blurred to produce a gradual transition between the barely modeled flesh and the surrounding surface.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: But the edges are nonetheless legible, and they form a flattened lozenge-shaped, pale, collage-like form lying close to the picture plane, a device favoured over juxtapositions of darks and lights to conjure up an illusion of three-dimensionality.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: Giorgione fully exploited the sensuous potential of both the medium and the subject.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: There is a decidedly erotic air to the totally unselfconscious young woman whose pale flesh is contrasted to the silky cloth.If compared with Titian's Venus of Urbino the differences between the two become clear since Titian has taken over the pose and the figural type almost verbatim from Giorgione; they are differences of temperament and personality more than of time passed.
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

sentence_text: If the Sleeping Venus was actually completed by Titian, as is frequently assumed, the overall effect remains tightly connected with Giorgione's style, and one might also suppose that it falls chronologically near the end of his short career, for we should assume that it was left unfinished at his death
title: Sleeping Venus
author: GIORGIONE

author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: The sheep, as a sacrificial animal that has become superfluous, has a particularly touching effect.The rejection of Joachim's sacrifice and his expulsion from the Temple occurred because of his childlessness.
title: No. 1 Scenes from the Life of Joachim: 1. Rejection of Joachim's Sacrifice
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: Here we are dealing with a true opening picture: the closed architecture of the temple introduces the first idea of solidity, while Joachim's dual movement brings this scene to a close, on the one hand, and on the other paves the way for the rest of the series, which finds a premature conclusion in the last picture of this register, the Meeting at the Golden Gate.The action is also driven forward by the repetition of buildings.

sentence_text: In the upper section of the lunette above the chancel arch God the Father enthroned is painted, while the sides of the lunette are occupied by the scene of the Annunciation.The border between painted and real space appears to have been breached in Giotto's frescoes.
title: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

sentence_text: This characterizes the representation of God the Father at the top of the triumphal arch wall above the entrance to the choir.
title: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: The heavens have opened and ranks of angels surround God the Father on his throne.
title: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: Amongst the angels, who move elegantly, the depiction of God, with his delicately shimmering, bright robes and his hieratic face, gives the impression of his belonging to a different sphere.This particular effect is also the result of a different painting technique: God the Father is not painted as a fresco on the wall, but in tempera on a wooden panel.
title: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: This "door" was presumably opened during the mystery plays performed to celebrate the Feast of the Annunciation, in order that the dove of Annunciation could fly out.

sentence_text: The representation of the Annunciation directly below it is an indication of this.
title: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: In a magnificent way, Giotto here combines the real architecture of the church interior with feigned, painted architectural elements to create a meaningful unity.

sentence_text: To the right and left of the arch, the angel and Mary kneel in their respective buildings.
title: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: It is only through the connecting architecture that tension is maintained within the depiction of the Annunciation, even over this great, daring distance and separation of figures, and that God the Father — at the top of the triumphal arch — is also included in the action.

sentence_text: This Crucifix  (now in the Museo Civico) was painted by Giotto for the Arena Chapel in Padua.

sentence_text: It displays a striking similarity to the frescoed Crucifixion in the right transept of the Lower Church of San Francesco at Assisi.Represented on the recto is the Christus patiens, that is, with his eyes closed and in a state of abandon on the arms of the cross.
title: Crucifix (front)

sentence_text: On the extremities of the cross are: above, God the Father; on the left, the Virgin; on the right, St John; and on the foot of the cross, the skull symbolizing Golgotha
title: Crucifix (front)
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: The crucifix was first attributed to Giotto by Lorenzo Ghiberti, who in his Commentaries quoted other works of the master in the altars of the church of Ognissanti, like the Virgin of Ognissanti and the Dormitio Virginis.
title: Crucifix
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: Originally it was probably located on the presbytery, dominating the nave and the faithful, near the Virgin of Ognissanti.In poor condition, it was kept in a room adjacent to the basilica and attributed to an artist close to Giotto and possessing great pictorial capacities.The work was restored from 2005 onwards by Opificio delle pietre dura from Florence and was attributed to Giotto himself, for a date which is around 1315.
title: Crucifix
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: On November 6, 2010, the crucifix was reinstalled inside the left transept, enhanced by proper illumination.Intended for the procession, it is in conformity with the monumental representations of Christ in the cross of the time, namely: the Christ on the cross is in the suffering position; the body falling; the belly prominent on its perizonium; the head leaning forward touching the shoulder; the prominent ribs; the bloody wounds; the superimposed feet.The crucifix has small panels with scenes on the ends of the cross: the Virgin Mary on the left clothed in blue, St John on the right, hands clasped, and on top the titulus in red is surmounted by a blessing Christ accompanied by the Book.
title: Crucifix
author: GIOTTO di Bondone

sentence_text: The background contains patterned gold behind the body of Christ.The cleaning and retouching of the blackened cross has revealed individual brush strokes and the bright colour of the lapis lazuli used by the artist.
title: Crucifix

sentence_text: The major painting of Van der Goes's third period (between around 1478 and 1482) and very likely one of the last works he painted is the Death of the Virgin.

sentence_text: The panel is almost square in shape.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: The scene is set in a totally enclosed room.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: The apostles are grouped around Mary's bed.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: The Virgin's fine blue robe contrast with the purple sheets that cover the bed.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: Her livid gray face is framed by the immaculate whiteness of her wimple, and of the cushion on which her head rests.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: Her hands are joined, her fingers look quite bony.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: Her eyes have lost their lustre.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: She looks up one last time towards the heavens, where her Son appears to her in His glory with arms outstretched, to display the wounds in his hands.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: He is dressed in a blue robe and a large red cloak held up by two angels.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: The picture represents the moment at which life has already gently slipped away, but death has not yet completed its work.The painter uses the apostles to ring the changes on the different varieties of grief, and their profound sadness contrasts with the detachment of the Virgin herself.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: Their clothes have been creased into countless shifting folds which cut across one another at right angles.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: Van der Goes is revealed as a penetrating analyst of religious feeling, of grief and devotion, and of the agitation they can cause.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: This work, like all those he painted during his last period, represents the eruption of sacred experience into a profane world.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: The artist achieves this through an abundant use of colours which strike the viewer as unreal, as if they were themselves transfigured.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: In this way, Van der Goes seeks to identify his painting with the mystery of transcendence itself.To this end too, the gestures of his figures are emphatic.
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: He uses techniques or the progressive reduction of pictorial space and the transformation of figures, which he paints half-length, not full length
title: The Death of the Virgin
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: Soberly painted in monochrome, the panels are entirely occupied by the Archangel Gabriel and the Virgin of the Annunciation.

title: Portinari Triptych (closed)
author: Hugo van der GOES

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 19, JH 409.Unlike some earlier paintings which he did back in The Hague, in this painting van Gogh scarcely attempts any solidarity with the farming people's arduous labours.

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 34, JH 459.The the tower of the old ruined village church standing alone in the middle of the field appeared in the earliest works which van Gogh painted in Nuenen.

sentence_text: He was greatly attracted to this sturdy ruin, which he could see from the house and which he painted and drew on many occasions

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 30, JH 479.In Nuenen between January and August 1884, van Gogh depicted the figure of the weaver working at the loom in several pen drawings, watercolours and oil paintings.
title: Weaver, Seen from the Front
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: In this small village of Northern-Brabant, to where his parents moved in September 1882, more than four hundred people took up weaving, an activity of domestic industry during the winter months, when agricultural labour was suspended.The chronology of the series could be determined by the development in representing the loom.
title: Weaver, Seen from the Front
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: As time went by, van Gogh depicted the loom with more and more precision, abandoning the anecdotal elements and concentrating on the work process and on the machine itself
title: Weaver, Seen from the Front
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 185, JH 484.Van Gogh lived in Nuenen between December 1883 and November 1885, first in the house of his father who was the pastor of the Nuenen parish.

author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: He made drawings and oil paintings of the parental gardens as well as the street façade and the garden façade of the parsonage.From the garden of the parsonage there was a good view of the tower of the old ruined village church.
title: The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: This old tower standing alone in the middle of the field appeared in the earliest works which van Gogh painted in Nuenen.

sentence_text: He was greatly attracted to this sturdy ruin, which he could see from the house and which he painted and drew on many occasions

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 158, JH 792.Van Gogh showed, in several drawings and paintings, women absorbed in work in the solitude of their homes.

sentence_text: Sewing, spooling thread, peeling potatoes, shelling beans and preparing food were among the most frequently depicted subjects.
title: Peasant Woman by the Fireplace
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: During the day, light shone into the dark rooms through the windows, whereas lamp- or firelight illuminated the models in the evening.In the present painting the woman sitting to the right of the fire is peeling a potato.
title: Peasant Woman by the Fireplace
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: A kettle is boiling over the fire, hanging from a chain barely visible in the curling smoke.Van Gogh's Nuenen interiors of peasant women engaged in their work convey a certain timelessness and reflect the influence of 17th-century Dutch genre painting
title: Peasant Woman by the Fireplace
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 212, JH 999.This painting is in many ways the key Antwerp picture by van Gogh.

sentence_text: He was mocking the procedure in drawing classes, where a skeleton invariably served as the basis of anatomical studies.

sentence_text: The lifelessness of the skeleton represented the very opposite of what van Gogh wanted a picture to express.

sentence_text: With the burning cigarette jammed in its teeth, the skeleton, though still nothing but dead bones, has acquired a grotesquely funny hint of life

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 213, JH 1247.Van Gogh arrived in Paris in March 1886.
title: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Although he was able to see a considerable amount of contemporary French painting by the Impressionists and their followers - Seurat's Sunday Afternoon on the Island of the Grande Jatte was exhibited twice in 1886 - he took little notice for at least a year.
title: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: As a letter written to an English artist he had met in Antwerp reveals, he continued with what he had been doing in Antwerp.
title: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: He enrolled again in an atelier, where he could draw and paint the nude from plaster casts and live models.Since he could ill afford to hire models, he painted large numbers of still-lifes of flowers in order to study the colour theory of Hals and Delacroix.
title: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: He wrote that he was 'trying to render intense colour and not a grey harmony'.
title: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The present painting indicates to what extent he had accomplished this aim.
title: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: It also demonstrates the now varied ways in which he applied his paint: dashes in the background to break up the blue field of the wall, directional brushstrokes on the table, impasto highlights on the metal vase.
title: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The plant itself is virtually drawn in colour; each leaf is a separate stroke and the heads of the flowers are depicted with more voluptuous and solid sweeps of paint
title: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 313, JH 1251.This picture shows an inviting restaurant in Asnières.
title: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Van Gogh's unique facility for communicating his feelings directly by means of his brushwork is already in evidence.
title: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The light and the associated atmospheric effects have become the actual subject of the picture, very much in the spirit of the Impressionists.
title: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Although still restrained, the painting is defined in terms of colour by contrasting complementary colours: blue and orange, red and green.By the middle of 1887 a dramatic change of style has occurred in van Gogh's work.
title: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Using these characteristically 'impressionist' motifs of a restaurant on the outskirts of Paris, van Gogh seems to have been willing to experiment with Impressionist techniques as well.
title: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: However, the painting lacks a sense of substance and conviction, which reflects his difficulty in feeling himself as part of the world he is portraying.In the two years van Gogh spent in Paris he tried to assimilate French Impressionism, only to find that a new generation of painters were questioning its premises regarding both subject-matter and style.
title: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: His flirtation with Impressionist subject-matter was brief; encounters with the Neo-Impressionists led him to believe that Paris could no longer be the subject of modern French painting
title: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 363, JH 1351.The sitter in this portrait was the colour-merchant Tanguy, a Breton peasant who had settled in Paris and ran a small paint shop in the Rue Clauzel, much frequented by vanguard artists.
title: Portrait of P?re Tanguy
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: His shop had become a kind of gallery of their paintings, for Tanguy would take paintings on deposit as credit for the painting materials he supplied.
title: Portrait of P?re Tanguy
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Van Gogh painted two portraits of Père Tanguy in the autumn and early winter of 1887, both against a background composed of Japanese colour woodcuts which he had begun to collect, firstly in Antwerp and then more avidly in Paris.
title: Portrait of P?re Tanguy
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Tanguy is placed massively in the centre of the canvas, facing the spectator.
title: Portrait of P?re Tanguy
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: But the Paris merchant is presented not against an urban or even French setting, but in an imaginary context composed of Japanese seasonal scenes and costumed figures.
title: Portrait of P?re Tanguy
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Although this choice of background indicates van Gogh's evident preoccupation with Japanese prints - he also made individual copies of selected prints at this date - the painting does not indicate any profound influence of Japanese graphic styles or perspectival devices upon his work.
title: Portrait of P?re Tanguy
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: But it is important to note that the motifs represented in the prints anticipate those that van Gogh would shortly resume when he left Paris and moved once again into a more rural setting - seasonal landscapes and portraits of regional types in costume.In his portraits of ordinary people van Gogh emphasized their sadness, dignity and kindness.
title: Portrait of P?re Tanguy
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The Portrait of Père Tanguy is a good example
title: Portrait of P?re Tanguy
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 392, JH 1361.In February 1888 van Gogh left for Arles in southern France where he wanted to paint orchards in blossom.

sentence_text: As a matter of fact, the south welcomed him with snow.

title: Blossoming Almond Branch in a Glass
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 412 JH 1440.Van Gogh's production in Arles fell into a number of series, one of which comprised landscape paintings on the theme of the seasons.
title: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The original idea for a seasonal series, in which each season would be represented by a pair of complementary colours, had been put forward in Nuenen in 1884.
title: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: On arrival in Arles in March 1888 van Gogh began to paint a series of canvases of blossoming orchards in pinks and greens entitled Spring.
title: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: In June he painted Summer in blue and orange, represented by the harvest on the plain of La Crau, which lay between Arles and the ruined monastery of Montmajour.
title: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The painting is a pendant of the Haystacks in Provence (F 425).
title: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: It was an important work for van Gogh; he made two preliminary drawings of the motif and when the painting was finished he made two further drawings after it.In the painting, the viewpoint is high and thus the great plain is laid out beneath us, receding more gradually to the distant towers of Montmajour and the hills beyond.
title: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Van Gogh often described the plain of La Crau in his letters, saying that apart from differences of colour it reminded him constantly of Holland, but not of modern Holland.
title: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: In this landscape he saw the landscape paintings of the seventeenth-century artists Ruisdael and De Koninck, who were both famous for their panoramic landscapes
title: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 422, JH 1470.The plain of La Crau spreads to the southeast of Arles.

author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: It is as flat as van Gogh's native country.
title: The Sower
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: La Crau is surrounded on all sides by hills.
title: The Sower
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: These offered van Gogh an opportunity to escape the flatland, to withdraw to a greater distance from where he commanded a panoramic view of the whole region.
title: The Sower
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The figure of sower is depicted on the broad plain of La Crau.

sentence_text: This painting follows van Gogh's depictions of the harvest, just as in reality the sower does his sowing only when the reaping has been completed and the fields are fallow.The figure of the sower is quoted from an early drawing by van Gogh in which he was copying Millet
title: The Sower

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 604, JH 1656.This cheerful still-life was painted shortly after van Gogh left the hospital in Arles which he had entered after his first major attack of psychomotor epilepsy on 25 December 1888.
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The objects depicted have both an allegorical and a more personal significance.
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The lighted candle, used in the painting of Gauguin's chair, derives from the emblematic tradition of still-life and signifies light and life; its opposite, the snuffed-out candle, was used in memento mori still-life and van Gogh had included it in a still-life with books which he painted after his father's death in 1885 (Amsterdam, Rijksmuseum Vincent van Gogh).
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The optimistic note sounded by the candle flame is underlined by the presence of the sprouting onions, taken from his Yellow Chair (a 'self-portrait').
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: On the other hand, van Gogh has added his pipe and tobacco and an empty bottle, possibly once containing absinthe, all of which endangered his health.Modern research has intriguingly shown that absinthe itself can cause epileptic fits.
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Van Gogh had consumed this poisonous beverage in some quantity during the months in Arles, and many of his subsequent fits coincide with occasions on which he had access to it.
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: The drawing board on which most of these objects are placed indicates van Gogh's resumption of work.
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: He informed his brother that he was painting still-lifes to ease himself back into painting after his hospitalization.
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: However, the colours used in this painting are more tempered and less intense, more controlled and less arbitrary than those he had been using both in the summer of 1888 and under the aegis of Gauguin in the autumn preceding his attack
title: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 611, JH 1723.Living in the asylum in Saint-Rémy, van Gogh repeatedly turned his attention to the no-man's-land between the wide world out there and his own confined world.

author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: When he looked across the low wall that enclosed the asylum, he found a whole world of subjects awaiting him.
title: Mountainous Landscape behind Saint-Paul Hospital
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: There was a range of hills, the Alpilles, with countless olive trees at their feet and an occasional solitary cypress crowning them to counteract the gentle ups and downs of the hills with a bold vertical
title: Mountainous Landscape behind Saint-Paul Hospital
author: Vincent van GOGH

sentence_text: In the year before his death, Van Gogh lived in the asylum of Saint-Paul-de-Mausole. The present painting reflects an artist determined to heal himself through work.

sentence_text: On most mornings between May 1889 and May 1890, the outside world visible to Vincent van Gogh appeared much like it does in this painting: a low stone wall enclosing a wheat field, a few poplars, an old farm house, a ploughman tilling the soil.Catalogue numbers: F 625 JH 1768

sentence_text: Catalogue numbers: F 641, JH 1795.Van Gogh often painted this view from his hospital window at Saint-Rémy.Even when they are merely a background, the mountains can be menacing.

sentence_text: After a short period of study in Greece, El Greco, one of the most renowned figure in Spanish art, went to Venice in the middle of the sixteenth century, where he worked in Titian's workshop, and where he became familiar with the art of Paolo Veronese, Jacopo Bassano and Tintoretto, as well as works by representatives of the North Italian Mannerist school.

sentence_text: His penetrating insight into his subjects' motivation and personality is also evident in the portraits and self-portraits of which he made many at this time.

author: Jean-Baptiste GREUZE

sentence_text: This painting by Greuze is frankly Poussin-like.

author: Jean-Baptiste GREUZE

sentence_text: The artist wished to be recognized as a history painter; he chose an obscure subject to illustrate:  Septimius Severus Roman emperor (146-211) reproaches his son, Caracalla for trying to assasinate him.
title: Septimius Severus and Caracalla
author: Jean-Baptiste GREUZE

sentence_text: Varied emotions are at work within it: from Caracalla's angry shame to the surprise of the chamberlain, Castor, at the emperor's recklessly heroic gesture which is at once a challenge and a rebuke
title: Septimius Severus and Caracalla
author: Jean-Baptiste GREUZE

sentence_text: Abel Grimmer was a follower of Pieter Bruegel the Elder.
title: Summer
author: Abel GRIMMER

sentence_text: His series of the Four Seasons is an interesting reproduction of Bruegel's series.
title: Summer
author: Abel GRIMMER

sentence_text: Abel Grimmer continued the themes of Pieter Bruegel the Elder and evoked the four seasons in many of his paintings.
title: Summer
author: Abel GRIMMER

sentence_text: He copied the subjects produced by Bruegel while adding his own mark: a stylisation of the forms and the introduction of powerful colours.The present panel of Summer is an interpretation of the famous drawing by Pieter Bruegel the Elder.
title: Summer
author: Abel GRIMMER

sentence_text: This drawing inspired numerous artists including his son, Pieter Brueghel the Younger.
title: Summer
author: Abel GRIMMER

sentence_text: Not all refer to the drawing itself, but rather to the engraving of it made by Pieter Cock around 1570.
title: Summer
author: Abel GRIMMER

sentence_text: Engraving flourished in Antwerp in the 16th century and was an excellent means of distribution.

sentence_text: Hence, artists were familiar with the works of their contemporaries.There are other versions of this painting by Abel Grimmer

sentence_text: Grünewald's earliest datable work is the Mocking of Christ, a colourful, vehemently expressive painting demonstrating his ability to create dazzling light effects.

author: Matthias GRÜNEWALD

sentence_text: The painting depicts Christ blindfolded and being beaten by a band of grotesque men.
title: The Mocking of Christ
author: Matthias GRÜNEWALD

sentence_text: The figures are thick-bodied, soft, and fleshy, done in a manner suggestive of the Italian High Renaissance.
title: The Mocking of Christ
author: Matthias GRÜNEWALD

sentence_text: Elements of the work also show Grünewald's assimilation of Dürer, specifically his Apocalypse series.
title: The Mocking of Christ
author: Matthias GRÜNEWALD

sentence_text: Different from High Renaissance idealism and humanism, however, are Grünewald's uses of figural distortion to portray violence and tragedy, thin fluttering drapery, highly contrasting areas of light and shadow, and unusually stark and iridescent colour.
title: The Mocking of Christ
author: Matthias GRÜNEWALD

sentence_text: It is these elements, already in evidence in this early work, that Grünewald was to develop into the masterful, individualistic style most fully realized in his Isenheim Altarpiece
title: The Mocking of Christ
author: Matthias GRÜNEWALD

sentence_text: The picture shows the left wing of the second view of the Isenheim Altarpiece

sentence_text: This is one of the panels of the two-part altarpiece originally in the church at Tauberbischofsheim.

sentence_text: The Carrying the Cross was seen from the direction of the choir while the other part, the Crucifixion, from the nave

sentence_text: Girolamo Godi, organizer of a Vicenzan literary salon and friend of Pietro Bembo and Alvise Cornaro, engaged Gualtiero around 1550 to decorate the villa.
title: View of the Hall of the Sacrifices
author: GUALTIERO PADOVANO

sentence_text: In addition to the loggia, the decoration of four rooms in the right wing of the villa can be ascribed to Gualtiero: the Hall of the Gods or the Putto, the Hall of the Triumphs, the Hall of the Caesars, and the Hall of the Sacrifices.
title: View of the Hall of the Sacrifices
author: GUALTIERO PADOVANO

sentence_text: Gualtiero's sudden death in 1552 prevented him from completing the work which was taken over by Battista Zelotti and Battista del Moro, who created the frescoes in the other rooms.In the Hall of the Sacrifices allegorical figures ornament the walls.

author: GUALTIERO PADOVANO

sentence_text: The figure with elongated limbs shows the influence of Parmigianino
title: View of the Hall of the Sacrifices
author: GUALTIERO PADOVANO

sentence_text: The decoration of the Music Room is divided into two parts, one dedicated to the world of allegories, the other to the real world.
title: Apollo Conducting the Orchestra of Putte
author: Jacopo GUARANA

sentence_text: Apollo, the god of music, dominates the fresco on the back wall of the Room, which is splendidly laid out by Agostino Mengozzi Colonna in a manner that recalls the scheme employed by the elder Mengozzi Colonna to frame Tiepolo's The Banquet of Cleopatra in the Palazzo Labia.
title: Apollo Conducting the Orchestra of Putte
author: Jacopo GUARANA

sentence_text: Apollo personally directs the orchestra of young girls (the "putte") seated in his right.
title: Apollo Conducting the Orchestra of Putte
author: Jacopo GUARANA

sentence_text: Next to him, dressed in yellow, Pasquale Anfossi (1727-1797), the opera composer who was then in charge of the Ospedaletto, conducts the chorus, holding a rolled-up musical score

author: Jacopo GUARANA

sentence_text: The frescoes in this airy portego were completed by Jacopo Guarana at the end of 1772; the chandeliers are from Murano

sentence_text: Francesco Guardi was a collaborator of Gianantonio, from whom he learned the craft of painting, but he introduced into his older brothers art his own profoundly meditative personality.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: This fact is evinced by the essential differences to be discerned in the works the "workshop" produced.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: This picture, unanimously attributed by researchers to Francesco, is, in all likelihood, the fragment of a larger composition.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The whole scene is summarized in the slow and calm movement of the gondoliere in the foreground, whereas the scenery of the lagoon virtually disintegrates in the mother-of-pearl atmosphere, which is lightened here and there by some rare flashes in the background.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The lonely gondola is seen in the lagoon at the Fondamente Nuove, in front of the islands of San Cristoforo and San Michele.The emotional intensity of the painting is condensed into this brief recording of the moment, as if it were a "phrase in music", for example in Vivaldi's or Albinoni's compositions of the same theme.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The smooth lagoon and the "adagio continuo" are parallel motifs of picture and music.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The scenery becomes dissolved in musicality, as musicality disintegrates "in sorrowful weeping" (Goethe).The mournful character of the black gondola is both a forecast and a conscious experience of the future destiny of the world of lagoons — a world enclosed within its own modest boundaries.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: This is a world which has disappeared, because it was linked to a declining civilization.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The argument was not continued, and it has not been taken up again; the other lagoon painters, such as the members of the Burano school, could not disguise the emptiness — not only of form but also of content.
title: Gondola in the Lagoon
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The division between quay and water and the human activity around the market stalls and gondolas make up the theme of this view of the Molo.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The quay, which is provided with steps and jetties for mooring boats, creates a striking line in the composition running almost at a right angle to the lower edge of the image and leads the eye toward a vanishing point just below the middle of the painting.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: Depicted at the right is the column of Todaro beyond which the buildings along the Molo continue with the Library, the Zecca and the State Grain Storage Houses all the way to the Fonteghetto della Farina near the entrance of the Grand Canal.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: A market with simple stalls and awnings occupies the Fondaco del Grano.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: To the left of the entrance of the Grand Canal can be seen the Punta della Dogana and Santa Maria della Salute and in the distance, to the extreme left, the Redentore.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The composition is closed off at this end by a fishing boat which counterbalances the column of Todaro.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: As several corrections by the painter, visible to the naked eye reveal, Guardi modified the strong perspective of the buildings at the right and moved the Salute closer to the centre of the composition.The view of the Molo in the direction of the entrance to the Grand Canal was a subject frequently depicted in Venetian vedute painting.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: Initially the view functioned primarily as a setting for festive entries in the Doges' Palace, such as in Luca Carlevaris's Reception of Cardinal Cesar d'Estrees (Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam).
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: Later the view of the Molo was usually shown without the Doges' Palace and without any kind of festivity.For this painting, Guardi undoubtedly drew inspiration from a work by Canaletto (c. 1740, private collection) which he may have known through a print by Antonio Visentini from 1742.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: Not only did Guardi rely on this for his composition, he also borrowed several details from Canaletto such as the little stalls on the Molo and the gondolas floating on the water.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: However, a comparison with this source makes it clear that Guardi, despite the strong perspectival arrangement of this composition, neither subjected the cityscape to a strict perspectival system nor strove for an exact, detailed rendering of the architecture.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: For the loosely, vigorously painted figures on the Molo, Guardi more likely found an example in the work of the Genoese painter, Alessandro Magnasco.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: Furthermore, Guardi's painting is not even half the size of the one by Canaletto.Guardi's small painting and its pendant, a view of the Piazzetta in the direction of San Giorgio Maggiore (also in the Galleria Franchetti, Venice), no longer satisfied the presumably more representative function of Canaletto's painting, but were purchased instead by an individual client who was as interested in the well-known Venetian cityscapes as in Guardi's painterly rendering of them.As with many of Francesco Guardi's paintings, the dating of this work is problematic.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: It no longer displays the strong stylistic dependence on Canaletto which is characteristic of his earliest cityscapes, nor the brown tonality of his work from the 1760s.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The shimmering effects of light and colour, especially in the wall surfaces of the buildings, and the nervous treatment of the sky and the figures on the Molo are characteristic of Guardi's extremely individualistic, transparent style in the last two decades of his career.
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: Therefore, dating this painting to the second half of the 1770s seems plausible
title: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: This mature work by the artist depicts the Piazza San Marco looking towards the Basilica and the Campanile.

sentence_text: This painting is a view of the Campo San Zanipolo with the loggia temporarily erected outside the Scuola di San Marco for the benediction of Pope Pius VI on 19 May 1782.In May 1782, Pope Pius VI visited the city of Venice.
title: View of the Campo San Zanipolo in Venice
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The ceremonies and festivities on that occasion were recorded by Francesco Guardi in a series of four paintings.
title: View of the Campo San Zanipolo in Venice
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: The city council commissioned Guardi to make four paintings representing the following subjects: the arrival of the pontiff near San Giorgio in Alga, the papal mass in SS Giovanni e Paolo, the papal audience and the blessing of the people on Campo SS Giovanni e Paolo.On the occasion of the Pope Pius VI blessing the crowd a temporary wooden loggia, designed by Antonio Codognato, was erected on the façade of the Scuola di San Marco.
title: View of the Campo San Zanipolo in Venice
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: Once the Pope had finished his blessing the crowds were allowed to mount the loggia and the existence of at least three variants of this subject, including the present one, attest to the popularity of the composition
title: View of the Campo San Zanipolo in Venice
author: Francesco GUARDI

sentence_text: Guercino is one of the most interesting personalities in seventeenth-century Bolognese art, and his activity in Rome made him an important influence on all Italian painting.
title: Abraham Casting Out Hagar and Ishmael
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: More than from Venice and Correggio, his work derives from Dosso Dossi and the school of Ferrara.
title: Abraham Casting Out Hagar and Ishmael
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: This painting represents one of the high points of Guercino's mature style.
title: Abraham Casting Out Hagar and Ishmael
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: Its restoration by the Brera's laboratory has revealed the original colours and eliminated the yellowish patina that obfuscated and partially hid the composition.The painting is built up on a measured circular rhythm, and the prominent gestures of the figures are emphasized almost to the point of theatricality.
title: Abraham Casting Out Hagar and Ishmael
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: Little Ishmael is crying and leaning his head against Hagar.
title: Abraham Casting Out Hagar and Ishmael
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: As she consoles him and holds out a handkerchief, she turns toward Abraham, who stands stern and still, making a gesture of repudiation.
title: Abraham Casting Out Hagar and Ishmael
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: Sarah, seen from behind, appears to be moving away from the scene.
title: Abraham Casting Out Hagar and Ishmael
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: The low-keyed colour helps avoid any rhetorical suggestion, while the slow rhythm of the composition creates a sense of inevitability.The city of Cento commissioned this painting, which was then presented to the Cardinal Legate of Ferrara, Lorenzo Imperiali
title: Abraham Casting Out Hagar and Ishmael
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: The ceiling painting in the Sala della Fama, the central hall on the second floor, is entirely allegorical.
title: Ceiling painting
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: The central picture is designed as a fictive opening with only a few figures.
title: Ceiling painting
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: In the centre hovers the personification of Fame in billowing robes, holding in her outstretched hands an extremely long trumpet and an olive branch as a symbol of peace.
title: Ceiling painting
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: Flying in front of her is the brightly feathered phoenix of myth, which is reborn out of its own ashes every five hundred years and was therefore considered a symbol of eternal renewal, but was understood also as a link to virtue.
title: Ceiling painting
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: In the lower part of the picture space personifications of Honour (Honos) and Virtue (Virtus) are seated on a dark gray cloud.
title: Ceiling painting
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: Amor Virtutis in the form of a putto turns toward them with laurel wreath and crown
title: Ceiling painting
author: GUERCINO

sentence_text: Guérin's Napoleon Pardoning the Rebels at Cairo has a grain of truth, since Napoleon had shown clemency to the Mamluk leaders of the 1798 rising - but only after the slaughter of most of the insurgents.
title: Napoleon Pardoning the Rebels at Cairo
author: Pierre-Narcisse GUÉRIN

sentence_text: Guérin burnishes Napoleon's myth subtly, placing his hero to the rear and rather dwarfed by those he has pardoned, in a sort of inverted modesty.

author: Pierre-Narcisse GUÉRIN

sentence_text: If the rebels are allowed dignity in defeat, it is to emphasize the magnanimity of the victor.
title: Napoleon Pardoning the Rebels at Cairo

sentence_text: Hackaert specialised particularly in Italianate landscapes and woodland scenes, the present canvas depicting a wooded landscape with a shepherd and his herd is an example of the latter category.

sentence_text: Influenced greatly by the respective styles of Dutch Italianate artists such as Jan Both and Jan Asselijn, Hackaert's treatment of colour owes much to these two predecessors.

sentence_text: In this Neapolitan scene, the image is framed between two groups of trees at the far left and right, leaving a space in the centre in which the smoking Vesuvius is particularly prominent.

sentence_text: A broad panorama extends from the foreground to the volcano, while on the right is the Palace of Caserta, which stands out due to its large size

sentence_text: This signed and dated painting provides a view of the Lake Nemi from the north, with the town of Nemi and the town of Genzano beyond, with a donkey and travellers on a path in the foreground.Similar views of the Lake Nemi were painted by other 18th-century painters such as Claude-Joseph Vernet, John Robert Cozens, Joseph Wright, Solomon Delane, and  Nicolas-Didier Boguet

sentence_text: The cabinets of curiosities (also known as Wunderkammer, Cabinets of Wonder, or wonder-rooms) were encyclopedic collections of types of objects belonging to natural history, geology, ethnography, archaeology, religious or historical relics, works of art (including cabinet paintings) and antiquities.
title: Cabinets of Curiosities
author: Georg HAINZ

sentence_text: Georg Hainz was a German painter specialized in still-lifes.

sentence_text: He often used real objects for his paintings, which he then depicted with artistic freedom.

sentence_text: The present painting represents a special type of vanitas still-life

sentence_text: The portrait of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard is the first major group portrait by Frans Hals, and the first monumental civic guard painting in the new era of Dutch painting.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: Together with the leaders of public, charitable and professional associations, the civic guard societies were the main patrons to commission group portraits.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: This patronage took on considerable proportions in the course of the century.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: These group portraits are also of value as historical documents, for which lists were drawn up giving the names of the figures portrayed.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: The paintings themselves were displayed prominently on the premises of the respective association.These civic guard portraits were an expression of the Baroque will to representation, whose tradition is rooted in the medieval era.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: There had been civic guards in the Netherlands since the 13th century.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: They had played an important role in the emancipation of the cities and towns from feudal rule and had gained considerable political and military significance in the Netherlands' struggle for independence.Cornelis van Haarlem had already painted the officers of the St George Civic Guard in 1599.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: Hals, however, revolutionizes this type of painting.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: Instead of merely painting a row of individual portraits, he places them within a specific context by creating a banquet scene.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: This is not simply a moment captured at a table, but an extremely witty and calculated composition in which a scenic context is created between all the figures involved, and, on the other hand, each of the figures poses and acts independently and individually.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: Hals has found a new and persuasive solution to the problem of portraying a large group without difference of rank.Hals seems to have arranged the officers casually around the festive board.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: But this is not the case.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: The places they occupy are in strict accord with military protocol.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: The colonel, the company's highest ranking officer, is seated at the head of the table; at his right is the provost, the second ranking officer.
title: Banquet of the Officers of the St George Civic Guard
author: Frans HALS

sentence_text: They are flanked by the company's three captains and the three lieutenants are at the lower end of the table.

sentence_text: The works of Jan van der Heyden, one of the finest city-view specialists, are responsible for our general impressions of seventeenth-century Amsterdam.

sentence_text: In paintings such as his View of the Westerkerk he presented a pristine, sunny image of the city in the 1670s.
title: View of the Westerkerk, Amsterdam
author: Jan van der HEYDEN

sentence_text: These cityscapes, many of which inventively recombine actual and fictional buildings, are as interesting for their omissions as for their inclusions.
title: View of the Westerkerk, Amsterdam
author: Jan van der HEYDEN

sentence_text: Both serious and comic descriptions of Amsterdam called attention to the busy traffic of people and carts, to the crying children and fighting street dwellers, to dirt and to crime, but van der Heyden's city views edit out congestion, noise, transgression, and dust, and gloss over class distinctions.
title: View of the Westerkerk, Amsterdam
author: Jan van der HEYDEN

sentence_text: They thereby present a salutary image of a unified, prosperous city, a beautifully painted fiction affordable only to its prosperous elite.Van der Heyden's painting takes as its centerpiece the Westerkerk, a church designed in 1620 by Hendrick de Keyser, then the city's most famous architect.
title: View of the Westerkerk, Amsterdam
author: Jan van der HEYDEN

sentence_text: Although the structure owed much to earlier Netherlandish designs executed in warmly coloured local brick, its details are innovative.
title: View of the Westerkerk, Amsterdam
author: Jan van der HEYDEN

sentence_text: To contemporaries the bell tower, completed in 1638, must have looked cosmopolitan with its three levels of classical columns in stone, topped by brackets that support a fanciful bulb.
title: View of the Westerkerk, Amsterdam

sentence_text: As the largest Protestant church built up to that time, it constituted a local answer to the magnificent tradition of Catholic building.Although de Keyser's church primarily served the Jordaan, a modest neighbourhood, van der Heyden represented it as seen from the stately Keizersgracht, the new Emperor's Canal
title: View of the Westerkerk, Amsterdam

sentence_text: However, as a consequence of the small format of the panel painting, the heavy shoulder chain that the king wears in the monumental portrait is omitted here, and his sleeves are embroidered with a very delicate gold thread.This is the quintessential image of the overbearing and tyrannous monarch, from the year the dissolution of the monasteries (and the consequent appropriation of their wealth for the Crown and its servants) was instigated.

sentence_text: Holbein depicts the King at `face value', without flattery, emphasizing the small, humourless eyes and mouth, the curiously flat cheeks and chin.

sentence_text: Henry's bulky and capricious authority haunts the work despite its small size.
title: Portrait of Henry VIII
author: Hans the Younger HOLBEIN

sentence_text: Its condensation of magnificence run riot here takes the form of real gold used in the chain, jewellery and collar.The portrait is undoubtedly a tour de force; after its execution, Holbein's position at the court seems to have been secure, and he was used as a painter-ambassador when the King's marital plans unraveled in the late 1530s.
title: Portrait of Henry VIII
author: Hans the Younger HOLBEIN

sentence_text: Only his misleading portrayal of Anne of Cleves would check his popularity.The subsequent spawning of similar but less effective portraits of the king by Holbein's followers has tended to obscure the compelling mixture of simplicity and realism displayed in this design - the tilt and curve of the black and white hat, the fearful symmetry of the jewelled jacket and the modelling of the hands: imitators often managed either simplicity or realism but never both.

sentence_text: Jane Seymour (1509-1537) was the third wife of King Henry VIII of England and mother of King Edward VI.

author: Hans the Younger HOLBEIN

sentence_text: She succeeded - where Henry's previous wives had failed - in providing a legitimate male heir to the throne.Jane's father was Sir John Seymour of Wolf Hall, Savernake, Wiltshire.

sentence_text: She became a lady in waiting to Henry's first wife, Catherine of Aragon, and then to Anne Boleyn, who married the King in 1533.

sentence_text: Henry probably became attracted to Jane in 1535, when he visited her father at Wolf Hall, but, though willing to marry him, she refused to be his mistress.

sentence_text: That determination undoubtedly helped bring about Anne Boleyn's downfall and execution (May 19, 1536).
title: Jane Seymour, Queen of England

sentence_text: On May 30, 1536, Henry and Jane were married privately.During the remaining 17 months of her life Jane managed to restore Mary, Henry's daughter by Catherine of Aragon, to the King's favour.

sentence_text: Mary was a Roman Catholic, and some scholars have interpreted Jane's intercession to mean that she had little sympathy with the English Reformation.

sentence_text: The second, on 6 June 1845, was in early Georgian dress and the third, on 13 June 1851, in the style of the Restoration.Landseer has painted Queen Victoria and Prince Albert in the Throne Room on the occasion of the fancy-dress ball of 1842, standing beneath a specially designed Gothic canopy decorated with purple velvet hangings.
