sentence_text: A work that would seem to evoke the sketches of a young Leonardo freed from Verrocchio's tutelage, though nevertheless still affected by a passion and taste for the soft textures and dazzle of solid material (as practiced in the workshop of the Florentine artist), is the Madonna sometimes referred to as the Madonna of the Carnation or "Madonna of the flowers".This painting is a free variant of the Benois Madonna in the Hermitage, being more complex in its composition and spatial arrangement, though perhaps somewhat highflown and less spontaneous.
title: The Madonna of the Carnation
author: LEONARDO da Vinci

sentence_text: How it arrived at the Alte Pinakothek in Munich, after its acquisition by a private German collector, is unknown to us.
title: The Madonna of the Carnation
author: LEONARDO da Vinci

sentence_text: What is certain is that after a comprehensible, temporary attribution to Verrocchio or his shop, art critics subsequently almost universally assigned the painting to Leonardo, a jjudgment backed up by the most recent research.
title: The Madonna of the Carnation
author: LEONARDO da Vinci

sentence_text: In fact, the richness of the drapery, the vastness of the mountain scenery with purple and gold hues tingeing the foothills of peaks that fade into the sky, the vitality of the cut flowers in the crystal vase and the softness of the Child's flesh that foreshadows the tender putti of the Virgin of the Rocks, are elements that show a distancing from the more distinctive Verrocchiesque style and instead assume those formal and chromatic characteristics that would be the mature Leonardo's very own.
title: The Madonna of the Carnation
author: LEONARDO da Vinci

sentence_text: Moreover, we should not overlook the striking similarities - in facial features and other details - with the Benois Madonna already mentioned (the gem fastening the Virgin's gown over her breast) and with the Uffizi Annunciation, works that in their figurative and expressive invention quite clearly reveal the stamp of Leonardo
title: The Madonna of the Carnation

author: Judith LEYSTER

sentence_text: She probably worked in his studio around 1630 and was also a friend of his family, for one year later she became godmother to Hals' daughter Maria.Like Hals at the same time, the young Leyster adopted the style of the Utrecht Caravaggisti, with their strong chiaroscuro modelling in the manner of Caravaggio.
title: Carousing Couple
author: Judith LEYSTER

sentence_text: From the mid-1620, she concentrated more on vividly illuminated genre scenes, generally featuring half figures of merry musicians, gamblers and whores, strongly influenced by the painting of Terbrugghen and Honthorst.While the Utrecht school of painters still rounded the surfaces of their objects smoothly between light and shade, Hals and his school adopted a broad, vibrant and independent brushstroke.
title: Carousing Couple
author: Judith LEYSTER

sentence_text: Leyster's work can be distinguished from that of Hals through her generally more discordant handling of colour, her sketchier treatment of hands, the wryly distorted smiles of her figures and her altogether flightier brushwork

author: Judith LEYSTER

sentence_text: He was born in Schleswig-Holstein c. 1597, spent several years studying in the Netherlands, where he came into contact with the Haarlem painters, principally Goltzius and Buytewech, and with the Flemish followers of Caravaggio in Antwerp (Janssens, Jordaens).

author: Johann LISS

sentence_text: Together with Domenico Feti, Liss played an important part in reviving the use of rich colours, a Venetian tradition which had ended with Tintoretto.In the seventeenth century this painting was in the famous collection of the Amsterdam merchant Gerrit Reynst (died 1658), which consisted mainly of works by Venetian masters and included a companion-piece, The Vision of St Peter, which was subsequently lost.

sentence_text: Only here and there did grotesque features appear in his art; he saw his figures with the eye of a sage and a gentle and witty impertinence is to be found in many of the scenes he depicted.Pietro Longhi became, by means of his genre-painting, one of the most faithful chroniclers of his age, and one who conjured up a regrettably vanished civilization.

sentence_text: It should be borne in mind, however, that his connection with Goldoni and the teachings of Emilia encouraged him, through the observation of reality, to perform a kind of analysis of "social depths"; he did not want to cause an upheaval but only wanted to point out — perhaps tendentiously — the ineptitude of a declining class of society.

sentence_text: According to Roman legend, Lucretia, who was the wife of Lucius Tarquinius Collatinus, was raped by the son of the Roman king - a dishonour which subsequently resulted in her suicide.
title: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia
author: Lorenzo LOTTO

sentence_text: The event is supposed to have precipitated the collapse of the Etruscan royal line (510 BC) and thus to have led to the founding of the Roman Republic.In the 16th and 17th century Lucretia was frequently portrayed as a symbol of purity.
title: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia
author: Lorenzo LOTTO

sentence_text: Lotto presents us with the three-quarter view of a woman dressed in fine, richly trimmed clothes.
title: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia
author: Lorenzo LOTTO

sentence_text: Turned slightly away from the viewer, in her left hand she holds a drawing of the naked Lucretia about to stab herself in the heart.
title: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia
author: Lorenzo LOTTO

sentence_text: An inscription in Latin on the sheet on the table reads: "Following Lucretia's example, no dishonoured woman should continue to live".In the exquisiteness of its palette, the painting ranks amongst Lotto's greatest works.
title: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia
author: Lorenzo LOTTO

sentence_text: While the subject's face follows on from the tradition of Giorgione, the contrast between her brightly lit shoulders and the richly gradated reds and greens of her dress is worthy of a Titian.
title: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia
author: Lorenzo LOTTO

sentence_text: The costly pendant suspended from the gold chain, its precious stones refracting the light, is virtually without equal in 16th-century Venetian painting
title: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia

sentence_text: From the mid-nineteenth century onwards, Hungarian painters began to paint historical scenes as well as landscapes, portraits and genre paintings.
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier
author: Viktor MADARÁSZ

sentence_text: It was not merely a fashion in Hungary to follow the current Romantic Movement that originated in Paris, or the "historism" of the Munich and Vienna Academies; it went much deeper than that.
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier
author: Viktor MADARÁSZ

sentence_text: At the defeat of the fight for independence, the nation escaped into its history.
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier
author: Viktor MADARÁSZ

sentence_text: Along with Hungarian poets and writers, the painters recalled the glorious events of the past, searching for ideals of patriotism and heroism that had not been crushed by despotism.Viktor Madarász gained the first international appreciation for Hungarian painting when his picture, "The Bewailing of László Hunyadi" won the State Grand Prix at the 1861 Paris Salon Exhibition.
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier
author: Viktor MADARÁSZ

sentence_text: This rather romantic historical painting of the Hunyadi tragedy epitomizes the national grief of the 1850s, and fans the fire of revenge.
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier
author: Viktor MADARÁSZ

sentence_text: The dead body of the heroic László Hunyadi, son of the great János Hunyadi, lies in Buda Castle Chapel.
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier
author: Viktor MADARÁSZ

sentence_text: King László V, fearing for throne, had lured the popular young Hunyadi to his place with a promise of safe passage.
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier
author: Viktor MADARÁSZ

sentence_text: Then he seized him and had him beheaded in the market place at Buda on March 16, 1457.
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier

sentence_text: At the feet of body, his mother, Erzsébet Szilágyi, and his bride, Mária Gara, kneel in grief
title: László Hunyadi on the Bier

sentence_text: The Genoese Alessandro Magnasco was taught by his father Stefano and a little known Milanese painter, Filippo Abbiati, and began by painting in a conventional seventeenth-century style.
title: The Observant Friars in the Refectory
author: Alessandro MAGNASCO

sentence_text: During his stay in Florence at the beginning of the eighteenth century, however, he became acquainted with the work of Salvator Rosa and the etchings of Callot, and under their influence developed a content and style of his own.
title: The Observant Friars in the Refectory
author: Alessandro MAGNASCO

sentence_text: His themes were bizarre, different from anything to be seen in Genoa, Milan, or indeed anywhere in Italy; nor did his manner of painting resemble that of any other artist in Italy.
title: The Observant Friars in the Refectory
author: Alessandro MAGNASCO

sentence_text: He depicted imaginary scenes, capriccios in many of which monks are seen in strange settings or tiny figures in stormy landscapes.
title: The Observant Friars in the Refectory
author: Alessandro MAGNASCO

sentence_text: In his paintings, which are usually small, the figures are oddly elongated, the strokes of the brush vibrating and restless; indeed, everything seems to be in flickering movement.The number of people depicted in this painting and the richness of the decorations lead us to think that this may have been the General Chapter of the Franciscan Order
title: The Observant Friars in the Refectory

sentence_text: The sitter of the portrait is Sebastian Andorfer (1469-1537), a top mining official of Schwaz in Tirol.

sentence_text: His father held a prominent position in the mining administration at Schwaz, serving as 'Silberbrenner' (refiner of silver) from 1470 to 1499.

author: Hans MALER

sentence_text: Sebastian assumed the post in 1499 and occupied it until his death in 1537.A variant of the portrait exists, also dated 1517, in which Andorfer is depicted bearded.

sentence_text: The two portraits may exemplify the practice, which can be observed in contemporary medals, of recording a change in appearance for eternity.

sentence_text: However, no known biographical events correspond with the 1517 date of the portraits.

sentence_text: This whole tradition, from the odalisque to the black slave, continues (particularly with Ingres) throughout the nineteenth century, but what was surprising here was the absence of any exoticism, of either period or location, and the portrayal of a modern prostitute.The painting of the period was not at all averse to flowers, and Courbet, Fantin-Latour, and Manet all painted many pictures with flowers in them.

sentence_text: Among the best known bunches (this time wrapped in florist's paper, like those that later Degas placed in the hands of his dancers as they took their bow) is the one being presented by a black servant to Olympia

sentence_text: In the fertile years that followed his Déjeuner and Olympia, Manet experimented very widely.

author: Edouard MANET

sentence_text: Sometimes he focused on giving form to colour and movement in works like the Bullfight, at others he was inspired by contemporary events, such as the Battle of the "Kearsarge" and the "Alabama" off Cherbourg.

author: Edouard MANET

sentence_text: This episode of the American War of Independence made a considerable impression on public opinion.

sentence_text: The work testified to Manet's modernity, but was also an attempt to renew the theme of naval combat traditional in Dutch painting.
title: The Battle of the "Kearsarge" and the "Alabama"
author: Edouard MANET

sentence_text: It is, in fact, a battle between colour and light, where the blacks and the few dots of red enhance the tumultuous green of the waves

sentence_text: In the 1620s in Roman circles, a definite change came about in the subject matter of musical paintings.

sentence_text: Within the space of a very few years they were replaced by large numbers of representations of concerts in public places and 'popular' locations.

sentence_text: One of the earlier examples of this new trend is Bartolomeo Manfredi's Tavern Scene with a Lute Player.

sentence_text: One characteristic of the painting, besides the presence of the lute player in a non-musical context (he simply accompanies a scene in which people are eating and drinking), is the absence of a musical score, an attribute of 'cultivated' musical painting.
title: Tavern Scene with a Lute Player

sentence_text: The Confraternity of the Scuola Grande di San Giovanni Evangelista in Venice called upon the most respected Venetian painters of the period, including  Pietro Perugino, Vittore Carpaccio, Gentile Bellini, Giovanni Mansueti, Lazzaro Bastiani and Benedetto Diana to paint nine canvases for the Great Hall of their headquarters showing the Miracles of the Holy Cross, the story of the miracles performed by the fragment of wood from the Cross on which Jesus was crucified.
title: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo
author: Giovanni MANSUETI

sentence_text: This fragment had been donated to the brotherhood in 1369 by Philip de Mezières, Chancellor of the Kingdom of Cyprus and Jerusalem, and had soon become an object of great veneration and the symbol of the Scuola, one of the most important and wealthy Venetian confraternities.The canvas painted by Perugino has been lost, but the eight surviving paintings executed between 1496 and 1501, contain depictions of some of the most famous parts of Venice.
title: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo
author: Giovanni MANSUETI

sentence_text: Since the imposing series of pictures (known as 'teleri') are all in the Accademia now it is easy to compare them.The subject of this 'telero' is the miraculous healing in 1414 of the little daughter of Benvegnudo.
title: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo
author: Giovanni MANSUETI

sentence_text: Having been paralysed ever since birth, she gained the use of her limbs after touching the three candles which her father had placed on the relic of the Holy Cross.
title: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo
author: Giovanni MANSUETI

sentence_text: The interior of the richly decorated and furnished room and the animation of the watching crowd are described with inventorial precision
title: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo
author: Giovanni MANSUETI

sentence_text: Images in the cloud like this, already described in classical art theory and adopted by Alberti and Leonardo da Vinci, were ascribed to the genius of nature, which could stimulate artists and inspire them to improve on nature with their creations.The vertical inscription at the right side of the saint is the signature of Mantegna in Greek
title: St Sebastian

sentence_text: Mantegna painted monumental likenesses that combine the particularity of Eyckian physiognomy with the authority of ancient Roman busts.
title: Cardinal Ludovico Trevisan
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The portrait of Cardinal Trevisan suggests a statue come to life, a bust animated by light washing over its forceful features.
title: Cardinal Ludovico Trevisan
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: This portrait is one of the landmarks of Italian portraiture.Cardinal Trevisan was a rich, powerful, and cultured figure who proved his military prowess in the Battle of Anghiari on June 29, 1440, between Milan and the Italian League, where he lead the papal troupes.
title: Cardinal Ludovico Trevisan
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: He became cardinal in the same year
title: Cardinal Ludovico Trevisan
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The central part represents the Madonna and Child Enthroned (212 x 125 cm), the left part shows Saints Peter and Paul, Saint John the Evangelist and Saint Zeno, while the right part Saints Benedict, Lawrence, Gregory and Saint John the Baptist (235 x 135 cm each).
title: San Zeno Polyptych
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The predella paintings are copies, the originals are in the Musée du Louvre and in the Musée des Beaux-Arts of Tours.Despite the framing elements that divide them, the three main panels of the San Zeno Altarpiece form an unified picture space.
title: San Zeno Polyptych
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The central section depicts the Madonna holding her Child and surrounded by music-making angels, seated on a marble throne decorated with Roman-inspired reliefs.
title: San Zeno Polyptych
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The naturalistic trompe l'oeil garlands, seemingly affixed to the top of the picture, create a rapport with the garlands held by the putti in the marble relief at the top of the throne.
title: San Zeno Polyptych
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The borderline between the real world and the invented world here breaks down completely
title: San Zeno Polyptych
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The central section of the San Zeno Altarpiece depicts the Madonna holding her Child and surrounded by music-making angels, seated on a marble throne decorated with Roman-inspired reliefs.

sentence_text: The naturalistic trompe l'oeil garlands, seemingly affixed to the top of the picture, create a rapport with the garlands held by the putti in the marble relief at the top of the throne.
title: San Zeno Polyptych (central panel)
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The borderline between the real world and the invented world here breaks down completely
title: San Zeno Polyptych (central panel)
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The space of the room with a square plan (8,1 x 8,1 m) is essentially a cube, and in it Mantegna has created a monumental architectural reality by means of ribs on the ceiling connecting with pilasters on the walls, which are in turn supported by a marble socle.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: In the centre of the ceiling is the much-admired oculus, opening onto a painted sky.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The interplay of levels of reality elaborates ideas already set forth in his art.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Only the corbels are actually stone, the highly worked ribs, the garlands that encircle the eight busts of emperors supported by putti, and the ensembles in decorative lozenges are painted to simulate marble so convincingly that even the modern viewer is sometimes fooled.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: In the triangular spaces at the edges of the ceiling are twelve mythological scenes of Orpheus, Orion, and Hercules with backgrounds of simulated mosaics, a device that Raphael was to use in the ceiling of the Stanza della Segnatura.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Only two of the walls have figurative narrations: the north wall with a scene that is usually called the Court and the west wall, divided into three scenes, Servants with Horse and Dogs, the Inscription with Putti, and the Meeting.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The remaining two walls are painted with imitation leather draperies that encroach upon the other sides as well to create the fiction that there were curtains before all four walls and on two sides they had been opened up to reveal the events depicted.The central subject of the frescoes is Ludovico III Gonzaga, his wife, his children, and his court.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: A closed letter held by Cardinal Francesco Gonzaga in the Meeting seems to be the same one, now opened, that Ludovico, seated majestically, holds in the Court, and must be considered important for understanding the paintings.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The style of the frescoes is similar to Mantegna's previous works.
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The compositions are dominated by the narrative elements, with the figures set frieze-like, close to the picture plane within a narrow spatial shelf in front of a landscape or architectural setting
title: View of the west and north walls
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The detail of the west wall shows a grotesque self-portrai of the artist.Hidden in the foliate decor of one of the room's painted pilasters, right next to the painted plaque above the door containing the painter's dedication of the work, is a face that has been commonly identified as the artist's self-portrait.
title: Grotesque Self-Portrait
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Its resemblance to the bronze portrait bust from roughly 1490 in the church of Sant'Andrea in Mantua, is unmistakable, even though this painted likeness does not wear the arrogant and somewhat surly expression that his contemporaries tell us was characteristic of the artist
title: Grotesque Self-Portrait
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The tent-like vaulting of the Camera degli Sposi contains: in the centre the trompe-l'oeil oculus; in the diamond-shaped compartments eight busts of emperors in medallions; in the side vaults scenes from the myths of Orpheus, Arion, and Hercules.Although painted first, the painting of the ceiling, done in grisaille and imitation gold mosaics, is meant to be the logical continuation of the vertical arrangements of the space.
title: Ceiling decoration
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: It represents a tent-like roof with pointed vaults above the walls; the painting makes it appear higher than it actually is.
title: Ceiling decoration
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Broad groins ornamented with meanders rise up from the painted basket capitals, dividing the ceiling into eight lozenge-shaped fields drawn to sharp points at the bottom, like spandrels.
title: Ceiling decoration
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Each lozenge contains a round medallion in which depicted are the first eight Roman emperors.
title: Ceiling decoration
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The twelve triangular vaults above the lunettes contain scenes from classical myth and legend, all backed by gold mosaics.
title: Ceiling decoration
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: First comes three scenes from the Orpheus myth, then three relating to Arion, and finally six depictions of some of the labours of Hercules
title: Ceiling decoration
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: One the most remarkable portions of the decoration of the Camera degli Sposi is the fictive oculus, or opening to the sky, located on the room's low ceiling.
title: Ceiling Oculus
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Created with sharp foreshortenings, the oculus is ringed with figures looking down on the room below; a potted plant is precariously perched on its wooden support, seemingly ready to fall at any moment.
title: Ceiling Oculus
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: It is a brilliant tour de force that invariably engages the spectator, who must join in the game by standing directly beneath the circular trellis.The magnificent details of the ceiling and some of the busts and scenes stand among the most convincing trompe l'oeil passages of the entire Italian Renaissance
title: Ceiling Oculus
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Once owned by King Charles I of England, this painting illustrates an episode from the Old Testament which relates how the Israelite Judith by guile killed the Assyrian general Holofernes and thus saved her beleaguered city.
title: Judith
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Painted with minute detail, Judith and her handmaiden finish their deed with tragic calm.Among Mantegna's works there are several representations of Judith that, without exception, show a comparatively peaceful scene in which Judith is placing the severed head of Holofernes in a bag.
title: Judith
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: During the Baroque, in contrast, the dramatic central moment of the action was preferred, as Judith, often with great effort, decapitates Holofernes.
title: Judith
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The Madonna of Victory was commissioned by Francesco II Gonzaga To celebrate his victory over the French at Fornovo on 6 July 1495.
title: Madonna of Victory
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: On the first anniversary of the battle the altarpiece was installed with great ceremony over the high altar in the chapel of Santa Maria della Vittoria in Mantua.By the end of the 15th century, large single paintings  were being used as altarpieces, a form that reached its apogee in the works of Titian and Veronese.
title: Madonna of Victory
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The stiffly hierarchical composition of the traditional Sacra Conversazione was also discarded.Mantegna's Mary is turning slightly away from the central axis, which runs from the Tree of Knowledge on the throne pedestal up through the Christ Child to the branch of coral hanging on a chain.
title: Madonna of Victory
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Mary and the idealized, over life-size figures of the saints Michael and George form a majestic group.
title: Madonna of Victory
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Francesco II Gonzaga is depicted kneeling to the left, blessed by the Virgin
title: Madonna of Victory
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Between 1490 and 1506, the year he died, Mantegna painted several devotional paintings in which the main figures are represented as reliefs standing out against a mostly dark background.
title: Adoration of the Magi
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Inspired by reliefs on classical tombs, these figures are shown partially hidden behind stone balustrades or a frame.The subject of Adoration of the Magi was one of the most popular in all fifteenth-century art, especially for the opportunities it presented for the display of rich costumes and accessories, and of numerous subordinate figures with horses and other animals in an extensive landscape.
title: Adoration of the Magi
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Mantegna, however, restricts his composition to just six figures - with the three magi on the right converging on the three members of the Holy Family on the left - which he shows in half-length, and hence, too, in powerfully expressive close-up.
title: Adoration of the Magi
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: Four decades earlier, when still working as a young man in Padua, Mantegna had introduced this type of half-length devotional narrative into Italian painting with his Presentation in the Temple.It was suggested that this painting was executed for Isabella d'Este, the consort of Marquis Francesco Gonzaga
title: Adoration of the Magi
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: This scene shows Julius Caesar in the triumphal chariot.
title: Triumphs of Caesar (scene 9)
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The triumph of the emperor, who sits like a god in his triumphal chariot, is heralded and lauded - as shown by the presence of putti, which appear only in this painting, the laurel wreath with which Caesar is about to be crowned, the sculptures of conquered warriors on the triumphal arch, and the images of the gods
title: Triumphs of Caesar (scene 9)
author: Andrea MANTEGNA

sentence_text: The flower garland was executed by Mario Nuzzi, nicknamed Mario dei Fiori (1603-1673).

sentence_text: He painted the flowers on several other paintings by Maratti, too

sentence_text: Apart from demonstrating the favours granted by important Roman patrons, Maratti's portraits are also perhaps the most lively and penetrating part of his work.

author: Carlo MARATTI

sentence_text: He took pains to capture the exact physiognomy of his sitters in whom he sometimes seemed to uncover an incurable feeling of melancholy hiding just below the surface.
title: Portrait of Pope Clement IX
author: Carlo MARATTI

sentence_text: Here his admiration for Raphael's portraits is evident, but he has added a more stylish air to suit the tastes of the high Baroque.The painting was executed shortly before the death of the Pope who was on the throne from 1667 to 1669.
title: Portrait of Pope Clement IX
author: Carlo MARATTI

sentence_text: It is signed on the paper sheet on the table

sentence_text: Although officially considered a third member of the so-called German Romanists, Hans von Marées, long resident in Italy, moved far from the dramatic narrative of Böcklin or the ponderous perspective of Feuerbach.
title: The Oarsmen
author: Hans von MARÉES

sentence_text: The Berlin-trained von Marées was Germany's major prophet of Modernism, filling a critical role as that nation's Puvis de Chavannes, the French master who was thirteen years his senior.
title: The Oarsmen
author: Hans von MARÉES

sentence_text: Like Puvis de Chavannes, von Marées followed the Nazarene and Pre-Raphalite revival of wall painting.
title: The Oarsmen
author: Hans von MARÉES

sentence_text: His major commission was the 1873 murals for the Library of the German Marine Zoological Station on Naples.The Oarsmen is a powerful study for one of the largest Library fresco, located on the north wall
title: The Oarsmen
author: Hans von MARÉES

sentence_text: The staffage (the small figures animating the scene) in this fine veduta is ascribed to Giovanni Antonio Guardi
title: The Grand Canal with the Palazzo Labia and Entry to the Cannareggio
author: Michele MARIESCHI

sentence_text: The painting represents a capriccio of an imagined cityscape with Saint Mark's Basilica and ruins on the banks of a river.
title: Capriccio of a Riverside Town
author: Michele MARIESCHI

sentence_text: This imagined riverside town is typical of the spirited and picturesque landscapes created early in the career of Michele Marieschi.
title: Capriccio of a Riverside Town
author: Michele MARIESCHI

sentence_text: The artist includes celebrated and instantly recognizable edifices, such as Venice's Saint Mark's Basilica here, and places them side by side with fantasy buildings and crumbling ruins.
title: Capriccio of a Riverside Town
author: Michele MARIESCHI

sentence_text: The artist is not bound by rules of perspective: the ruined columns and the tower overgrown with greenery are painted to a completely different scale than the houses directly opposite them on the other side of the river at right.
title: Capriccio of a Riverside Town
author: Michele MARIESCHI

sentence_text: They dwarf the figures beneath them, who cross the bridge between the two sides
title: Capriccio of a Riverside Town
author: Michele MARIESCHI

sentence_text: Markó often interrupted his stay in Italy for the sake of paying a visit to Hungary.

sentence_text: This work, made in 1853, is considered a rarity, because, except for a few works during the earliest period of his career, he never painted Hungarian landscapes.
title: The Puszta
author: Károly the Elder MARKÓ

sentence_text: Although his art can largely be classified as late neo-classicist, this time Markó chose a romantic motif.
title: The Puszta
author: Károly the Elder MARKÓ

sentence_text: He depicted the Puszta, the region of the country which is still thought to be the most special and the most interesting, with a sweep-pole well, its mandatory symbol.

author: Károly the Elder MARKÓ

sentence_text: A rainbow glows in the stormy sky.

author: Károly the Elder MARKÓ

sentence_text: One is reminded of the anxiety felt before a storm by the ponderous, dark clouds.

sentence_text: Besides the subject of the painting, its style also shows the traits of romanticism, with special regards to its composition which is built on the contrast between light and dark.

sentence_text: This portrait of Benjamin Franklin was commissioned by Robert Alexander, of the firm of William Alexander & Sons, Edinburgh.

sentence_text: The other books and pamphlets suggest the learned evidence brought in support of a wise man's decision.

sentence_text: In the 1820s Martin produced a series of paintings depicting scenes of disaster, set in infinite, visionary spaces and full of theatrical, nightmarish lighting effects.
title: Pandemonium
author: John MARTIN

sentence_text: Their basic mood largely derived from the artist's familiarity with John Milton's epic poem Paradise Lost and with the biblical Apocalypse.The Pandemonium of 1841 goes back to a passage in the first book of Milton's Paradise Lost, in which "Pandemonium, the palace of Satan, rises suddenly built out of the deep."
title: Pandemonium
author: John MARTIN

sentence_text: In a diagonal perspective characteristic of Martin, a gigantic building complex extends along the waterfront.
title: Pandemonium
author: John MARTIN

sentence_text: This recalls fantastic reconstructions of cities of antiquity.
title: Pandemonium
author: John MARTIN

sentence_text: Martin's Satan, whose invocatory figure stands on a rocky outcrop in the right foreground, has the look of an ancient Greek hero.
title: Pandemonium
author: John MARTIN

sentence_text: Like Achilles outside Troy, he appears with shield and feathered helmet, but commanding an army not of besiegers but of demons and damned souls in their Cyclopean city
title: Pandemonium
author: John MARTIN

sentence_text: The artist seems to have represented here a young girl from the Tuscan countryside and has ennobled her aspect by dressing her in a white mantle with traces of light blue, yellow-lined and edged with a gold ribbon.

sentence_text: He made her face graceful by putting on her head a very light, impalpable white veil
title: Assumption of the Virgin

sentence_text: Masaccio's frescoes for the Brancacci Chapel in Florence's Santa Maria del Carmine  mark a milestone in the history of wall painting.

sentence_text: They enhance Giottesque traditions of naturalism with new vitality, not merely on their formal properties of space and volume, but also in the psychological intensity that permeates the narrative.The following frescoes can be seen in this view:Expulsion from the Garden (Masaccio)Tribute Money (Masaccio)St Peter Preaching (Masolino)St Peter Healing the Sick with his Shadow (Masaccio)Raising of the Son of Theophilus and St Peter Enthroned (Masaccio and Filippino Lippi)St Paul Visiting St Peter in Prison (Filippino Lippi

sentence_text: On February 19th 1426 Masaccio agreed to paint an altarpiece for a chapel in the church of the Carmine in Pisa for the sum of 80 florins.
title: Crucifixion
author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: On December 26th of that year the work must have been already completed since payment for it is recorded on this date.
title: Crucifixion
author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: Vasari gave a detailed description of the work which was the basis for art critics for the attempt at reconstruction and for the recovery and identification of the work which was dismantled and dispersed in the 18th century.
title: Crucifixion
author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: Only eleven pieces have so far come to light and they are not sufficient to enable a reliable reconstruction of the whole work.
title: Crucifixion
author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: The Crucifixion is one of the eleven panels (one of the top panels) connected with the Pisa Polyptych.As in the main panel, the Gothic arch determines the pictorial frame, the upward stress of which Masaccio modifies in his composition.
title: Crucifixion
author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: To counter the vertical trust imposed by the arch, Masaccio creates a strong horizontal effect with the rather exaggerated extension of the arms of Christ on the cross.
title: Crucifixion
author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: Although Masaccio still uses the gilt background for his representation, the atmospheric effects remain hauntingly convincing.
title: Crucifixion
author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: This painting is the central predella panel of the Pisa Altarpiece, directly beneath the enthroned Madonna and Child.

author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: Compared to Gentile da Fabriano's painting of the same subject done in Florence just a few years before, Masaccio's treatment is entirely new.

author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: Besides offering lifelike portraits of the patron and his nephew in contemporary dress at the middle right, he has given the entire scene a convincing atmosphere which surrounds the figures and the landscape.

sentence_text: In the distance, the atmosphere breaks down the clarity of the forms resulting in an effect which is referred to as aerial perspective

sentence_text: The face, defined by its sharp contour, is modeled like sculpture.

sentence_text: The three-dimensional effect of the mazzocchio (the turban) is emphasized by being cut at the right edge of the picture.

sentence_text: The portrait can be compared with various portraits by Masaccio in the Brancacci Chapel in the church of Santa Maria del Carmine, Florence, especially the bystanders in the scene of St Peter preaching.

author: MASACCIO

sentence_text: This comparison points to a date about 1426-27, making this panel the earliest surviving independent portrait in fifteenth-century Florence

sentence_text: His graceful, rather mannered style is close to that of Massys.The present scene depicting ladies making music - a kind of love allegory - includes the score of a chanson by Claudin de Sermissy (1490-1562), who composed music at the French court

author: MASTER of Female Half-lengths

sentence_text: In his Nativity the Master of Flémalle (Robert Campin) proved himself a sensitive painter of landscape, who knew how to portray the atmospheric subtleties of light and air; but he does not always use nature as the background for his compositions.

author: MASTER of Flémalle

sentence_text: In the Crucified Thief, the one surviving panel of a lost altarpiece, he resorts to the archaic device of a gold background, contrasting its abstraction with the marked individuality of the figures.
title: The Crucified Thief

sentence_text: Cecilia, behind her, has her organ, Barbara her tower, and Ursula is adorned with the arrow that pierced her heart.A number of late 15th-century  works were grouped around this picture at the beginning of the 20th century, and the artist was christened the Master of the Virgo inter Virgines after this painting
title: Virgin and Child with Sts Catherine, Cecilia, Barbara, and Ursula

sentence_text: Master Theoderic, a highly original artist, broke free of the styles that were dominated by Italian, Austrian and French art and tried to develop his own distinctive style.
title: Paintings of Saints
author: MASTER THEODERIC

sentence_text: Painted between 1360 and 1365, the 30 icon-like portraits of the saints which decorate the Chapel of the Cross at Karlstein Castle are one of the most impressive results of these efforts.
title: Paintings of Saints
author: MASTER THEODERIC

sentence_text: The robust features of the individual saints are impressively depicted.Three-dimensional objects have been added, such as carved coats-of-arms, mounted in the manner of collages on the surface of the paintings.
title: Paintings of Saints
author: MASTER THEODERIC

sentence_text: Ornamented with discs of gilded Venetian glass and strips of marble encrusted with semiprecious stones, the chapel seems like a Byzantine treasure chamber.
title: Paintings of Saints
author: MASTER THEODERIC

sentence_text: It is possible that this room and the adjacent 'privatorium' were intended by the Emperor to create a vision of his future Eastern empire
title: Paintings of Saints
author: MASTER THEODERIC

sentence_text: Matteo di Giovanni is best known for four monumental compositions of the Massacre of the Innocents, three for Sienese churches and one in inlaid stone for the pavement of the Duomo.
title: Massacre of the Innocents
author: MATTEO di Giovanni

sentence_text: In the version in Sant'Agostino, the arches and columns of Herod's palace suggest that the artist  had visited Rome.
title: Massacre of the Innocents
author: MATTEO di Giovanni

sentence_text: He has left no foreground space and every inch of Herod's hall is occupied by screaming mothers, dead or dying babies, and bloodthirsty soldiers.
title: Massacre of the Innocents
author: MATTEO di Giovanni

sentence_text: The marble pavement is covered by infant corpses.
title: Massacre of the Innocents
author: MATTEO di Giovanni

sentence_text: Impassive courtiers flank Herod's throne, while the gloating king is portrayed as a monster: one hand is outstretched to order the butchery; the other, like a claw, clutches the marble sphinx on the arm of his throne
title: Massacre of the Innocents
author: MATTEO di Giovanni

sentence_text: The Golden Legend, drawing on the apocryphal gospels, tells how the Virgin Mary was brought up as a child in the Temple at Jerusalem 'with other virgins'...and was visited daily of angels', since it had been foretold to her parents, Joachim and Anne, that their daughter was to be consecrated to the Lord as the 'chosen vessel' of Christ's Incarnation.
title: The Education of the Virgin
author: Franz Anton MAULBERTSCH

sentence_text: The theme became popular in the 16th century and remained so after the Counter-Reformation in spite of some disapproval by the Church because of its apocryphal character.
title: The Education of the Virgin
author: Franz Anton MAULBERTSCH

sentence_text: Mary is seen in earlier examples teaching her young companions, sewing the priest vestments or being ministered to by angels who bring bread and water.
title: The Education of the Virgin
author: Franz Anton MAULBERTSCH

sentence_text: But the favourite theme, especially in Counter-Reformation art, depicts her education in the strict sense, at the knee of her mother Anne, learning to read.You can view other depictions of the Education of the Virgin in the Web Gallery of Art
title: The Education of the Virgin
author: Franz Anton MAULBERTSCH

sentence_text: Maulbertsch's painting of the Last Supper is an interesting example of the Baroque style of sketching.
title: The Last Supper
author: Franz Anton MAULBERTSCH

sentence_text: The figures, which lean far forward or far back, the abrupt foreshortening and the countless diagonal lines make this scene of men grouped around a table appear disturbed and agitated

sentence_text: The painting was comissioned for the Parish Church at Balassagyarmat, Hungary

sentence_text: In this work by Mazzolino the sharpness of line typical of the North European tradition is evident.

sentence_text: Observe the 'linea serpentinata' with which the fragile figures are constructed.
title: Adoration of the Shepherds
author: Ludovico MAZZOLINO

sentence_text: Certain whimsical touches of the narrative are probably due to the influence of a painter like Aspertini, whose presence is also visible in the fairy-tale mountain landscape which can be seen in the background and in the unreal cotton-wool cloud supporting a complex composition of angels in glory

sentence_text: This work is a typical example of the artist's predilection for large, richly decorated backgrounds.The painting is distinguished by the accentuated sumptuousness of the ornamental motifs - sphinxes, voluted brackets, bas-reliefs.

sentence_text: This work shows the influence of Pietro Liberi and references works by Titian and Rubens

sentence_text: Luis Meléndez trained under his father Francisco Antonio Meléndez (1682-1752), a specialist royal portrait miniaturist, who was instrumental in the encouragement of Philip V to establish an academy of fine arts in Madrid, which he eventually founded in 1744, making the artist an honorary director of painting.
title: Portrait of the Artist
author: Luis MELÉNDEZ

sentence_text: Luis Meléndez was one of the first students admitted into the new academy (which was later named the Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in 1753), where he rapidly excelled in the art of drawing, an event celebrated in his handsome self-portrait (and remarkably the only known portrait by Meléndez) of 1746, now in the Musée du Louvre, Paris.
title: Portrait of the Artist
author: Luis MELÉNDEZ

sentence_text: The highly accomplished skill displayed in this portrait reflects the experience gained by the artist during his apprenticeship to the royal portrait painter Louis-Michel van Loo from 1738 until 1744.
title: Portrait of the Artist

sentence_text: The artist holds one of his drawings

sentence_text: The early decades of the sixteenth century in Cremona were some of the most turbulent in its political history.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: In these years of constantly changing foreign rulers, the local leaders of Cremona pursued an elaborate project of decoration with remarkable consistency.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: From 1506 to 1522 the community had the chancel and nave of the twelve-century cathedral frescoed.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: By continuing the decoration through all the changes in government, the community represented its own identity; it was an act of local self-assertion.The decoration was begun in the semi-dome vault of the apse in 1506.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: Boccaccio Boccaccino depicted, following a time-honoured scheme, the Epiphany of God in the Last Days (Christ in Majesty) as the principal and culminating image within the church space.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: Later, in 1514 Boccaccino received the commission to begin a fresco cycle of the life of Mary and Christ on the walls of the nave.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: They begin on the left wall, running from the façade to the apse and then on the right wall from the apse back to the façade.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: The left wall is dedicated to Mary and Christ's childhood; the right to the Passion.Boccaccino painted the scenes above the first four arches of the nave, and Giovan Francesco Bembo had been active above the fifth arch.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: He was not awarded another commission, the fresco cycle was continued by the Cremonese artist Altobello Melone.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: His contract regarding the frescoes above the next arch stipulated that his works should surpass in beauty Boccaccino's frescoes of the first two arches, which had been unveiled in 1515.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: Melone painted the Flight to Egypt and the Massacre of the Innocents with a wealth of motifs and drastic narrative.
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: The protagonists have left the ideal, solemnly harmonious sphere of joyful childhood that Boccaccino's style suitably mirrors and have entered into a dramatic world depicted in Melone's coarser style.Melone continued the cycle on the right wall, he painted five scenes of the Passion above the three arches next to the apse.View all images of the fresco decoration in Cremona Cathedral by various artists
title: Flight to Egypt
author: Altobello MELONE

sentence_text: This painting is the pendant of the portrait of the sitter's husband, Tommaso Portinari.
title: Maria Maddalena Baroncelli
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Both paintings probably belonged to a triptych as the side wings.It was Memling's clever innovation to place the trompe-l'oeil frame not around but behind the sitter, which caused the sitter to be projected into the viewer's space
title: Maria Maddalena Baroncelli
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Memling must have started work on his wide Adoration of the Magi triptych shortly after finishing the Portinari panels.
title: Triptych
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: This altarpiece too was probably commissioned by Abbot Jan Crabbe, as the old woman and young man from the earlier Crucifixion triptych once again appear together.
title: Triptych
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Like the Last Judgment, this triptych relies on both Van der Weyden and Lochner, despite its highly personal, peculiar and ceremonial atmosphere.
title: Triptych
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The conception of the work owes a great deal to Rogier's Columba altarpiece (Munich, Alte Pinakothek), which Memling must have seen during production in the master's workshop.
title: Triptych
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Meanwhile, the highly centralized, symmetrical composition looks back to Stefan Lochner's even earlier Dombild (Cologne, Cathedral) .The triptych depicts the Nativity (left), the Adoration of the Magi (central) and the Presentation of the Temple (right)
title: Triptych
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: After weighing and jjudgment, the majority of the resurrected are herded towards hell by black, hybrid, zoomorphic demons, who carry a variety of weapons and red-hot instruments of torture.
title: Last Judgment
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Hell takes the form of a volcanic, mountainous region
title: Last Judgment
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The closed altarpiece shows the donor and his wife kneeling in prayer, each before a niche containing respectively a statue of the Virgin and Child and St Michael battling with demons.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Their escutcheons are mounted on the polygonal base of the niches.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: These were identified as belonging to the Florentines Angelo di Jacopo Tani (1415-1492) and Caterina di Francesco Tanagli (1446-1492).
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Tani was an agent of the Medici bank in Bruges in 1450, before becoming its manager in 1455.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: He was ousted by Tommaso Portinari in 1465.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Tani married in Florence in 1466, and his wife bore a daughter (one of several) on 8 June 1471.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: He drew up his will on 12 December 1467, the same month as he was sent back north to save the London branch from bankruptcy.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The holy figures represented here evidently relate first and foremost to the devotion of the donors.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The coats-of-arms were originally reversed - in other words, the man's arms appeared in the woman's panel, and vice versa.Before departing for London in December 1467, Tani founded a chapel dedicated to St Michael at his employer's church in Fiesole and drew up his will.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: He probably also made funeral arrangements in the customary manner.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: He will then have required an altarpiece, which he ordered from Memling some time after the end of 1467 during his stay in the north.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The painting was, therefore, largely executed during his stay in London between 1467 and 1469, from where he could monitor its progress.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The iconography of the altarpiece is clarified by its destination.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: St Michael has been selected here first and foremost as the saint to whom the chapel was dedicated, and only in the second place as Tani's patron.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: This also explains the absence of the woman's patron.
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Taken together, the grisailles depict the victory of St Michael over Satan, who was threatening the Virgin and Christ Child
title: Last Judgment Triptych (closed)
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The symbolic gesture whereby Jesus places a wedding ring on the finger of St Catherine of Alexandria caused this altarpiece to be identified for many years as the Mystic marriage of St Catherine.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Nevertheless, it is clearly dedicated to the Virgin and the two St Johns.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Together with the Gdansk Last Judgment and the Lübeck Passion, this is one of the three biggest triptychs that Memling ever painted.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The three altarpieces are also distributed evenly throughout his career, and hence serve as crucial milestones in the development of his oeuvre.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The St John altarpiece is dated 1479, and is thus located precisely half-way between the Gdansk (1467) and Lübeck (1491) triptychs.The central panel focuses upon a Sacra Conversazione, a gathering of saints around the Virgin.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: However, the narrow vertical openings between the columns reveal a continuous landscape with ruins and buildings in which small episodes from the lives of the two male saints are enacted.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The two wings each depict episodes from the lives of the standing figures of the two St Johns on either side of the Virgin.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The left wing features the Beheading of St John the Baptist and the right wing St John the Evangelist on the Island of Patmos.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: In addition to these realistic portrayals, the carved groups on the two capitals above each saint also depict key moments from their lives.The composition of the triptych as a whole is not only ingenious in narrative terms, with the different components interlocking spatially and thematically; it is also new in many respects as far as the portrayal of the Virgin Mary in heaven and the Apocalypse are concerned.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The iconographical forebears of such a grouping of saints sitting and standing around an enthroned Virgin are few and far between.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The only extant examples are, in fact, the Virgo inter Virgines from the circle of the Master of Flémalle in Washington and a similar composition, this time set in a room, by Rogier van der Weyden, several fragments of which have survive.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: They are not, however, comparable in formal terms.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: This clear monumental composition, with two symmetrical standing male saints and two sitting female saints, forming a tetramorph around the Virgin, must have seemed very new.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: As is the case with the architecture, Memling appears to have developed here upon Jan van Eyck's Virgin with Canon van der Paele.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The Apocalypse is new too.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: There is no sign of any other representation prior to Memling in which the Book of Revelation is played out before St John's eyes in its entirety in a single, undivided painting.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Only in the Beheading of StJohn the Baptist did Memling prefer to paraphrase a Van der Weyden composition (St John altarpiece, Berlin, Staatliche Museen).
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: However, the stylised terseness and enclosed character of the latter give way here to dramatic action in the open air, with a high degree of realism.In view of the historical circumstances and iconography, there can be no doubt whatsoever that this triptych was painted for the High Altar of the chapel of St John's Hospital.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: An old inscription on the bottom member of the frame gives the date 1479 and the name of the artist Johannes Memling.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: With the exception of the Floreins triptych in the same hospital, this is the only work by Memling to be authenticated by an original (in this case subsequently overpainted) inscription.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The donors were also identified.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Jacob de Ceuninc was initially recorded as a monk at the hospital in 1469-70, and later as bursar from 1488 until his death in 1490.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Antheunis Seghers was first mentioned in 1455-56 and appears to have been master from 1461 to 1465, bursar from 1466 to 1468, and then master again from 1469 until his death in 1475.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Agnes Casembrood was first recorded in 1445-46, and subsequently appears as prioress from 1459 to 1463, and again from 1469 until her death in 1489.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Clara van Hulsen makes her initial appearance in the records in 1427-1428, and died in 1479.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Given that these are evidently intended as portraits, the altarpiece must have been ordered before the death of Antheunis Seghers in 1475, which means that its production may logically be linked with the expansion of the chapel's apse in 1473- 74 though we lack details of Jacob de Ceuninc and Clara van Hulsen in those years.The altarpiece is, of course, dedicated to the patron saints of St John's Hospital.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The central portrayal of the Virgin might relate to the hospital chapel's long-standing and close links with the chapter of the almost adjacent Church of Our Lady.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The two female saints, Catherine and Barbara, were frequently invoked in adversity.
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Their presence in the hospital context has frequently been explained in terms of their symbolising respectively the contemplative and active life of the hospital's monastic community
title: St John Altarpiece
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: This small triptych is the second altarpiece to be commissioned from Memling by a brother at St John's Hospital in Bruges, the first being the Floreins triptych.
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The donor has been identified as Adriaan Reins on the basis of the initials AR on the frame and the figure of St Adrian who protects him in the left wing.
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Reins was received into the Order in 1479, and died in 1490.The principal scene is a Lamentation on Golgotha beneath a glowering evening sky.
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The left wing represents the donor with his patron saint, while the right wing features St Barbara, the hospital saint par excellence.The composition is a development on an idea of Rogier van der Weyden, who was the first to reduce the Lamentation to its three principal protagonists (apart from Christ) in a number of smaller compositions.
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The body with its stiff, open arms and closed legs, knelt over by the praying Virgin, first appears in another work by the same master, namely the Lamentation in The Hague (Mauritshuis).
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The scene as a whole is portrayed in deep and sombre tones.
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The predominance of purple - including the marbling of the frame - means that the altarpiece is literally enveloped in the colour of the Passion.Two versions of this Lamentation are known: the central panel of the Kaufmann triptych in Rotterdam and the Rome Lamentation, both of which were probably painted at an earlier date.
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The former in particular may be seen as the immediate compositional predecessor of the Reins triptych.Doubts as to the authorship of the work were expressed from an early stage, probably because the figures of St John and Mary Magdalene did not meet the idealised Memling image that had been formed by the nineteenth century, and because of the lack of an inscription with the artist's signature.
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Despite these doubts, this little triptych is a masterpiece, executed with the utmost delicacy.The central panel was partially copied (landscape, Christ and St John) in the Santa Barbara Lamentation by a follower of Memling from the late fifteenth century
title: Triptych of Adriaan Reins
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The tightly framed composition of this portrait makes it one of the most compact images ever painted by Memling.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The solid head occupies virtually the entire width of the painting, with more than half of the shoulders and hands cut off the edge.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The sensation of extreme proximity is exceptionally strong.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The viewpoint is so low that the flat landscape, with a little church in the distance, can barely be discerned above the subject's shoulders, while his head stands out monumentally against the sky.

author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The broadly drawn, wispy clouds appear to be a later addition.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The man wears a dark jacket lined with white fur, flecked with brown, and an asymmetrical collar over a red waistcoat.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape

sentence_text: The wider right lapel is folded over, and if fastened would reach high above its counterpart.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: A small crucifix set with pearls hangs from a golden chain, half beneath and half on top of the collar.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape

sentence_text: The young man in London's National Gallery has a similar piece of jewellery, which he wears in the same way.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape

sentence_text: It must have been a common ornament, because a version of it also appears in the Bruges Portrait of a young woman and in the allegorical figure of a girl in New York.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The man's devotion is evidently directed towards a lost representation, probably of the Virgin and Child.When closed, this diptych would have displayed the coat-of-arms that is still to be found on the reverse.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: The man probably belonged to the Lespinette family (Franche-Comté).
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: Since its auction (as a work by Antonello da Messina) in 1894, the painting has been accepted as a Memling.
title: Portrait of a Man at Prayer before a Landscape
author: Hans MEMLING

sentence_text: It is generally compared with his portraits from the 1480s, and shows a particular similarity in its modelling to the Bruges Portrait of a young woman of 1480.It is understandable that some people should have been inclined to attribute this admirable portrait to Antonello, such is its precision and assurance of drawing and modelling of the face; but in the features, which are as though engraved, and the pointed steeple visible in the background, give a Flemish character of this picture

sentence_text: The present donor, dressed in a dark tabard, is not by Memling and conceals another figure who turns out to be none other than Abbot Jan Crabbe, who died in 1488.

sentence_text: This reversible painting would seem to have been intended for use as an aid to private meditation.

sentence_text: The room opens up to the rear at the right, giving a view of a sunny courtyard in which a market stall has been erected.Although the painting was for many years known simply as The Lovers at Breakfast, the two protagonists, quite different in type, have been identified as the artist and Isabella de Wolff, whom he married in 1658 and who was a niece of the painter Pieter de Grebber.The iconography of the painting distinguishes it as part of a painting tradition well-known to the educated contemporary viewer: the carousing, feasting couple, the ambience of the tavern with the landlady at the blackboard, the highly significant bread and fish still-life on the table.

sentence_text: In sharp contrast to Dutch still-life specialists, the Leiden Feinmalers around Gerard Dou reactivated these subjects for their small-format genre paintings, in which market goods were showed off to their best advantage in small, select groups.
title: The Poultry Seller
author: Gabriel METSU

sentence_text: Metsu's Poultry Seller depicts just such a group of varied items, arranged along the painting's lower and left-hand margins; the precision with which they have been painted testifies to a supreme virtuosity in the Feinmaler style, and is accentuated in part by the use of light and dark contrasts.
title: The Poultry Seller
author: Gabriel METSU

sentence_text: But importantly, each surface receives the same amount of attention: from different woods - a bamboo rod, basketwork, a barrel and a bare tree — to the fluffy fur of the rabbit beside the pale flesh of the plucked hen in the basket, or from the bird's skeletal head, a strong contrast with the luminous red head of the turkey, to the trader's thick wool stockings that differ so from his young customer's delicate, filmy gauze apron.
title: The Poultry Seller
author: Gabriel METSU

sentence_text: Metsu is not simply content, however, to use the Feinmalers' technique of applying flat, narrow brush strokes one beside the next.

sentence_text: The tree and the row of houses in the background reveal his command of a far more relaxed and expansive style.
title: The Poultry Seller

sentence_text: The Dutch often protected paintings with curtains, either to keep off the light and dust, or to look at them only occasionally, as is the traditional way of the Chinese and, Japanese - a practice that comes from the fine feeling that a work of art cannot be looked at continually.

sentence_text: In planning the architectural design Michelangelo first had to accommodate his program to the pre-existing building, including the windows, which were the source of light for his decoration.

sentence_text: The wreath of openings still provides the principal viewing light.Michelangelo devised a long central area framed by a fictive marble cornice and separated into nine sections by broad pilaster strips bent across the ceiling, also in imitation white marble.

sentence_text: Sections of alternating dimensions are framed between wider and narrower bands.

sentence_text: Within them Michelangelo varied the size of the actual narratives, giving only the smaller ones a marble frame.

sentence_text: Four ignudi (male nudes), among the most admired elements of the ceiling, ostensibly support ribbons attached to large medallions painted to look like bronze.

author: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti

sentence_text: Twenty in all, they are in different poses, producing, together with the Prophets and Sibyls, a "handbook" of alternatives for the seated figure for later artists.At the corners of the ceiling Michelangelo has painted four salvation subjects, including David and Goliath and Judith and Holofernes.
title: The ceiling
author: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti

sentence_text: Triangular-shaped compartments are repeated in a continuous band along the entire border of the ceiling; they contain bronze-colored nudes that alternate with the renowned Prophets and Sibyls set into marble thrones which, in turn, have paired marble putti in a variety of poses and positions that expand upon the tradition of Donatello and Luca della Robbia.
title: The ceiling

sentence_text: (Matthew 1:15-16)At the top of the entrance wall of the chapel, to the right of the viewer, next to the Eleazar-Matthan lunette, there is the one concluding the genealogical sequence of the ancestors of Christ in the Gospel of St Matthew.Sullen and perplexed, wrapped in a huge yellow ochre cloak and seemingly withdrawn, the old man - generally believed to be Jacob - dominates the family group on the left due to his expressive power and the quality of the colour.
title: Jacob - Joseph
author: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti

sentence_text: Similarly, on the right, the female figure, usually thought to be Mary, is more prominent than the other members of the Holy Family and the child holding a mirror.

sentence_text: Behind Mary in the shadow, Joseph holds the Christ child, who stretches out an arm toward the round mirror held out at the height of his face by a naked female child, possibly an allegory of the Church.The compositional schemes of the two neighbouring lunettes correspond: in both there is a female figure in the foreground seen in full, or half, profile and facing the outer wall of the chapel, and a male figure, on the internal side, with his torso seen frontally.

sentence_text: Momper is rightly regarded as the most important Flemish landscape painter between Pieter Brueghel and Rubens.

sentence_text: Brueghel's influence is clearly evident in this winter landscape, and it is quite probable that his son Jan also painted a number of the figures in this picture.Momper's personal achievement lies in his rendering of landscape as a picturesque subject matter in its own right.
title: Winter landscape

sentence_text: What we see here is no longer a great universal landscape full of symbolically charged allusions, but a scene whose aesthetic appeal is valued for its own sake.
title: Winter landscape
author: Joos de MOMPER

sentence_text: Momper's painting is divided into various planes by a kind of backdrop, against which silhouettes are highlighted by a pale light or dark, thundery clouds.
title: Winter landscape
author: Joos de MOMPER

sentence_text: People are making their way along tortuous paths on terrain that seems to be hazardous.Rain-laden stormclouds, sunshine and snow set the atmosphere of the painting.
title: Winter landscape
author: Joos de MOMPER

sentence_text: In this respect, Momper has taken an important step towards emancipating the landscape painting as an autonomous genre in which the landscape is not merely a setting for some event, but is treated as a subject matter in its own right

author: Joos de MOMPER

sentence_text: The Palazzo Grassi, overlooking the Grand Canal opposite the Ca' Rezzonico in Venice.

sentence_text: was built for the Grassi family by Giorgio Massari between 1749 and 1766.
title: Decoration of the grand staircase
author: Michelangelo MORLAITER

sentence_text: The architect adopted an innovative solution on the ground floor, with its two-story high main hall, large colonnaded courtyard, and "imperial style' main staircase, which proceed with grand theatrical effect from the Grand Canal façade through to the back of the building.For the decoration of the first staircase landing, Massari turned to his trusted sculptor, Giovan Maria Morlaiter, who is responsible for the large bas-relief that depicts Concord.
title: Decoration of the grand staircase
author: Michelangelo MORLAITER

sentence_text: It was the celebrated sculptor, who suggested his own son, Michelangelo, to execute the frescoes on the second landing.

sentence_text: The architecture was painted by Francesco Zanchi (active 1734-1772).Morlaiter's decoration develops along the walls of the staircase space, at the level of the second landing.
title: Decoration of the grand staircase
author: Michelangelo MORLAITER

sentence_text: Inside seven large arches delimited by Ionic pilasters, he painted a large faux loggia, closed off at the back by a marble wall, against which statues of goddesses stand inside aedicules surmounted by rectangular tympanums.
title: Decoration of the grand staircase
author: Michelangelo MORLAITER

sentence_text: A carnival-like reception is under way on the loggia, and the participants include a number of elegant ladies and noblemen, some in wigs, some in three-cornered hats, as well as a prelate and an Eastern figure, all busy conversing amiably, or sipping coffee and liquors served by efficient waiters in livery.In spite of the fact that Morlaiter's authorship is well documented, in the nineteenth century the frescoes were attributed to several painters, among them Pietro Longhi
title: Decoration of the grand staircase
author: Michelangelo MORLAITER

sentence_text: Usually he painted them at work with the tools of their particular trade: the scholar is seen holding a book or writing implements, the tailor is about to cut his cloth.According to a later inscription at the top right, this is a portrait of Jacopo Contarini, Podesta of Padua.

author: Giovanni Battista MORONI

sentence_text: However, Padua never had a Podesta of this name and, since it is known that Jacopo Foscarini filled that office when the picture was painted, we can only assume that the inscription is inaccurate and that the portrait is indeed of Foscarini.

sentence_text: He is shown as a distinguished man of middle age with an air of seriousness that commands respect.

sentence_text: In the 1890s, such work came into its own with divisionist or pointillist paintings.In the work of Pellizza, the most important Lombard Neo-Impressionist, the goals of the leading French pointillist, Seurat, were most consistently pursued.

sentence_text: This painting of a basket of flowers and its pair (Madrid, Museo del Prado) follow closely a type of flower piece made popular by Juan de Arellano in which the flowers occupy an open weave wicker basket placed on a rough stone ledge.

sentence_text: Although the paintings have been considered early works by Pérez for reasons of their closeness to the typology of Arellano s works, they show that the painter was evidently in full possession of the technical resources that distinguish his mature style.In the 17th century, flower paintings commonly made up the decoration of chapels and monastic institutions.

sentence_text: While it does not appear that symbolism played a significant role in Spanish flower paintings, viewers of a more sombre cast of mind could have read a Vanitas message in such pictures, in which the brief life of the flowers was a metaphor for human existence.

sentence_text: The fresco is from the cycle of the life of Christ in the Sistine Chapel, it is located in the fifth compartment on the north wall.Likely in charge of the entire project of the fresco decoration on the walls of the Sistine Chapel, Pietro Perugino retained for himself not only representations on the altar wall (which eventually were replaced by Michelangelo's Last Judgment) but also other significant scenes, such as Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter, a most fitting subject for Pope Sixtus' chapel.

sentence_text: On the unrailed staircase of the imposing cylindrical building to the right, Joseph takes one of his children by the hand; higher up, the other is greeted affectionately by his mother.
