author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: Lastly, Joseph and his sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, are portrayed inside the room at the top of the building, where Jacob, now old and near to death, imparts his paternal blessing.
title: Joseph in Egypt
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The curious combination of all these elements confers to the painting an anomalous and intriguing quality
title: Joseph in Egypt
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: This painting was painted after a cartoon executed by Michelangelo in the early 1530s.
title: Noli Me Tangere
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The panel painting was intended for the private collection of the artist's close friend Vittoria Colonna, who was particularly devoted to the penitent Magdalen
title: Noli Me Tangere
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The portrait represents Maria Salviati in a widow's veil with a little girl.
title: Maria Salviati with Giulia de' Medici
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: Salviati's only child was Cosimo I de' Medici, the girl was identified as one of Alessandro de' Medici's illegitimate daughters - either Giulia or Porzia -  who after their birth were placed in Salviati's care.
title: Maria Salviati with Giulia de' Medici
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The younger of the two, Porzia, was placed in the Augustinian convent of San Clemente, therefore Giulia is more likely the girl depicted in the painting.
title: Maria Salviati with Giulia de' Medici
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The mother of Alessandro's children is not known.The medal that Salvia holds is probably one of the pieces depicting Alessandro produced by Francesco del Prato or Domenico de' Vetri
title: Maria Salviati with Giulia de' Medici
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The Deposition can perhaps justly be described as the artist's masterpiece.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The compositional idea is extravagant and totally unprecedented: an inextricable knot of figures and drapes that pivots around the bewildered youth in the foreground and culminates above in the two lightly hovering figures emerging from vague background.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: This complicated bunch of forms arranged in the shape of an upturned pyramid defies any attempt at a rational exploration or identification of planes.The compositional complexity is accompanied by a significant and probably deliberate ambiguity in the representation of the subject, which may be interpreted as halfway between the theme of the Deposition and that of the Pietà or Lamentation over the Dead Christ.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The painting appears to represent the moment in which the body of Christ, having been taken down from the cross, has just been removed from the mother's lap.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The Virgin, visibly distraught, and perhaps on the point of fainting, still glazes longingly towards her Son, and gestures with her right arm in the same direction.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: In the centre of the painting, the moment of the separation is underlined by the subtle contact of Mary's legs with those of Christ, now freed from his Mother's last pathetic embrace.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The twisted body of Christ is reminiscent of Michelangelo's Vatican Pietà (1498).An intense spiritual participation in the grief of the event profoundly affects the expressions and attitudes of all the figures present, even that of the woman turned away from the onlooker, probably Mary Magdalene, who communicates her anguished psychological condition by reaching out sympathetically towards the swooning body of the Virgin.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: Some scholars have interpreted the two young figures holding up the deceased's body as angels in the act of drawing Christ away from the main group and leading him finally into the arms of his Father.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The general direction of the movement is, in fact, a rising one, and is created by the ethereal quality of the weightless figures, and their slow, almost dance-like rhythm.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The two presumed angelic presences, moreover, seem to be unaffected by the weight of the lifeless body, and the figure in the foreground appears to be in the act of raising himself up by lightly pressing down on the front part of his foot.The intricately connected group of figures, involved in a highly dramatic atmosphere, takes on the appearance of a rich frieze in the harmony of highly refined colour tones of pinks, blues and greens.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: The transparent shadows do not annul the colours, but actually become them, in the flesh tones invested with subtle shades of pink and green.The cloaked man wearing a strange hat, almost imperceptible against the background of the painting behind the arm of the Virgin, may possibly be the artist himself.
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: Staring at something beyond the confines of the painting and looking as though he were about to leave the pictorial space, he presents us with this complex and refined decoration of colours, forms
title: Deposition
author: Jacopo PONTORMO

sentence_text: Pordenone's enormous artistic freedom compared to the main Venetian school is beautifully expressed in this altarpiece.
title: Madonna and Child Enthroned with Saints
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: The traditional layout of the scene is subverted by the asymmetrical architectural backdrop behind the group.
title: Madonna and Child Enthroned with Saints
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: It is also upset by the uneasy but effective way that each member of the group is gesticulating
title: Madonna and Child Enthroned with Saints
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: The decoration was executed by Pordenone and Bernardino Gatti.Domes, which vault the crossing and altar of countless churches, lend themselves well to being transformed into paintings of the sky.
title: Decoration of the main dome
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: The round shape above our heads seems to  open onto a higher world, so that God and the things of heaven become visually present at the church holiest spot.Astonishing dynamic effects in dome decorations were achieved by Pordenone.
title: Decoration of the main dome
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: In the large ribbed dome of Santa Madonna di Campagna in Piacenza, in 1530-32, Pordenone began to fresco a complex theological program.
title: Decoration of the main dome
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: God the Father floats in the cupola, mysteriously illuminated by invisible windows.
title: Decoration of the main dome
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: Putti, animals, and illusionistic reliefs of Old Testament stories decorate the ribs.
title: Decoration of the main dome
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: In between them heroic sibyls, prophets, and other Old Testament figures are seen against views of the heavens.
title: Decoration of the main dome
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: In 1543 Bernardino Gatti added apostles on the pilasters of the drum below, stories from the life of Mary on the next level, and finally evangelists on the pendentives
title: Decoration of the main dome
author: PORDENONE

sentence_text: Along with Giuseppe Recco and Giovan Battista Ruoppolo, Paolo Porpora was one of the leading figures in Neapolitan still-life painting during the Baroque.
title: Underbrush with Tortoise and Crab
author: Paolo PORPORA

sentence_text: In his first period in Naples he painted fish and kitchen still-lifes in great variety.
title: Underbrush with Tortoise and Crab
author: Paolo PORPORA

sentence_text: In the late 1640s he moved to Rome and, after coming into contact with the Northern European masters Matthias Withoos and Otto Marseus van Schrieck, active in the city at that time, he began to produce his famous underbrush paintings.
title: Underbrush with Tortoise and Crab
author: Paolo PORPORA

sentence_text: The painting in Nancy is one of the few examples of these works that remained
title: Underbrush with Tortoise and Crab
author: Paolo PORPORA

sentence_text: Frans Post was the first trained European artist to depict the landscape of South America.
title: Brazilian Landscape
author: Frans POST

sentence_text: As a young man he traveled to the north-east of Brazil with Johan Maurits, Count of Nassau-Siegen, who was Governor General of the Dutch colony there.
title: Brazilian Landscape
author: Frans POST

sentence_text: A very few paintings that he made there have come down to us, but the drawings that he must have made there (though very few survive), and above all his own recollections of the seven years he spent there, served as the basis for his entire output over the remaining 35 years of his life
title: Brazilian Landscape
author: Frans POST

sentence_text: This Brazilian landscape with labourers, an armadillo and a tamandua (two exotic creatures) was painted in the period when the artist enjoyed his strongest commercial success.
title: Brazilian Landscape with Labourers
author: Frans POST

sentence_text: The carefully staged composition includes many of the diverse elements employed by Post during this phase of his career
title: Brazilian Landscape with Labourers
author: Frans POST

sentence_text: The building to the left is almost certainly the end of a sugar mill, probably a structure erected by the Portuguese and taken over by the Dutch colonists.
title: Landscape in Brazil
author: Frans POST

sentence_text: Similar sugar mills, constructed of local limestone arcading with open gable-ends, can be see in many of Post's paintings of Brazil.
title: Landscape in Brazil
author: Frans POST

sentence_text: A colonel, three captains, two lieutenants, three sergeants, a reserve officer and the troop's servant are portrayed on the staircase of their shooting gallery, the St Adrian Gallery.
title: Officers of the Civic Guard of St Adrian
author: Hendrick Gerritsz POT

sentence_text: A small part of the guard portrait painted by Cornelis van Haarlem in 1583 is visible through the window
title: Officers of the Civic Guard of St Adrian
author: Hendrick Gerritsz POT

sentence_text: The initials "HP."
title: The Miser

sentence_text: with which the painting is signed for a long time deceived critics into thinking its author was Horatius Paulyn.

sentence_text: At the beginning of the twentieth century the painting's attribution was changed in favour of Pot

sentence_text: Both documentary and dramatic, The Bull by Paulus Potter is painted as a fact of life
title: The Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: In the work of Paulus Potter views of nature and animals are seen for their own sake, and not as a backdrop for human action.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: Potter can paint equally well the bright sunlight and the cool air, but his real fame lies with his penetrating portraits of animals.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: His best-known work is the life-size Young Bull, an unusual heroization of a single animal, a counterpart to the monumental trend of Ruisdael and Cuyp.Although at first sight it appears to be a portrait of a prize young bull Potter most probably composed his famous beast from studies of more than one animal since its dewlap, horns, and teeth belong to bulls of different ages.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: The ancient Greek painter Zeuxis used a similar method; when he painted his portrait of Helen in the city of Croton he chose five beautiful virgins, in order to copy the finest features of each, for in one woman he felt he could not find perfect beauty.What makes this painting so special is the fact that Potter painted something as ordinary as a bull on such a grand scale - which had never been done before.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: And despite this large size, he paid great attention to the smallest details.During the nineteenth century the Young Bull by the twenty-two-year-old Potter ranked close in fame to the Night Watch of Rembrandt.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: Later generations have been less captivated by Potter's fidelity to nature when he worked life-size.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: Although the shapes of the farmer, the tree, and the bull against the light sky are impressive and the textures of the animals have been convincingly represented by the use of an original impasto which approaches relief, the entire foreground of this huge canvas seems airless.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: Atmosphere enters the picture only in the lovely distant view on the right, where a sunny light plays upon the cattle in the meadows and on the woods, making this passage one of his loveliest landscapes.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: Potter is more consistent on a small scale, and his cabinet pieces show him at his best.
title: The Young Bull
author: Paulus POTTER

sentence_text: This painting is the pendant of the Portrait of a Man, also in the Hermitage
title: Portrait of a Woman
author: Frans the Elder POURBUS

sentence_text: In 1599, the childless marriage between Marguerite de Valois and Henri IV, king of France, was annulled.
title: Portrait of Louis XIII of France at Age Ten
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: Early in 1600, Henri wed Maria de' Medici, and later that year Louis, heir to the throne, was born.
title: Portrait of Louis XIII of France at Age Ten
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: Henri was assassinated in 1610; Louis became king, but Maria ruled as regent until he came of age seven years later
title: Portrait of Louis XIII of France at Age Ten
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: Two Flemish court painters of Bruges descent who earned their reputation abroad, Frans Pourbus the Younger (1569-1622) and Marcus Gheeraerts the Younger (1562-1636), were active at the close of the sixteenth century and especially in the first quarter of the seventeenth.
title: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: They are linear descendants of famous Bruges painter families.
title: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: Their solid, old-fashioned technique and the rigid, immovable expression of their figures seem more like an extension of the sixteenth century than a herald of the seventeenth.Frans Pourbus the Younger was Pieter Pourbus' grandson.
title: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: He was trained in Antwerp and worked briefly for the Archdukes Albert and Isabella before going on to become court painter at Mantua, under Duke Vincenzo Gonzaga, and in Paris, under Marie de' Medici and Louis XIII.
title: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: Until about 1600, Pourbus painted in the smooth and technically brilliant style established by his grandfather, which he augmented with an analytical realism attributable to Adriaan Key.
title: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: The Portrait of Petrus Ricardus, a famous doctor and professor at the University of Leuven, is a good example of his first period
title: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
author: Frans the Younger POURBUS

sentence_text: Poussin's scenes, created in his early years in Rome, require of the viewer an extensive acquaintance with ancient mythology.
title: Bacchic Scene
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: At Cupid's command, the goat-legged shepherd-god Pan has knelt and taken Venus, the goddess of love, on his shoulders.
title: Bacchic Scene
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: A little winged putto is giving a hand, and the group is accompanied by a sturdy faun bearing a basket of fruit on his shoulder.
title: Bacchic Scene
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The lively ensemble has been set in an Arcadian landscape
title: Bacchic Scene
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: In Greek legend Midas was a king of Phrygia who was granted a wish by Bacchus in return for a good deed he had done to Silenus, a follower of the god.
title: Midas and Bacchus
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Midas wished that everything he touched be turned to gold, but soon realized his mistake when all food became inedible.
title: Midas and Bacchus
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Bacchus ordered him to wash in the River Pactolus in Lydia.
title: Midas and Bacchus
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Hence the popular aetiology of the gold-bearing properties of the river, thought to have been the source of wealth of the kings of Lydia, of whom Croesus was the last.Midas is depicted penitently before Bacchus, a drunken Silenus sleeping nearby.
title: Midas and Bacchus
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Another version of the subject by Poussin (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York) depicts Midas washing in the river, while the river god reclines on his urn
title: Midas and Bacchus
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Poussin showed a preference to dealing with subjects such as the sentimental and melancholic scenes from Tasso's "Gerusalemme Liberata", for example the strange encounter Tancred and Erminia in dusky twilight.
title: Tancred and Erminia
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The scene is played out between two attentive horses - one bay the other white
title: Tancred and Erminia
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The Triumph of Pan was one of several paintings commissioned from Poussin, in 1636 the leading French artist in Rome, by Cardinal Richelieu.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: They were intended for a room in his château in Poitou which would also house mythological pictures by Mantegna, Perugino and Costa.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Poussin must have been advised about the scale not only of the canvases but also of the figures, for although he never saw the Renaissance paintings his personages are much the same size as theirs.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: He must also have been told that the pictures were to be set above a high dado, divided by gilt caryatids, gold fleur-de-lys against a blue ground, and marine battles, all under a gilt ceiling.The Cabinet de la Chambre du Roy in Richelieu's château celebrated the cardinal's 'gift' to Louis XIII of mastery of the seas.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The room, with its 'Combat of Wealth and Art', as a contemporary panegyric puts it, and furnished in addition to paintings and panelling with porphyry vases and ancient busts, must have presented a formidable challenge to Poussin.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Not only would he be competing with some of the foremost Italian Renaissance artists, his pictures also had to contend with the glittering décor - hence the colours here are among the most brilliant he ever lavished on a painting.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Sadly, the room was dismantled long ago and the pictures dispersed, so we can judge the full effect only in our mind's eye.Poussin carefully allowed for the spectator's point of view.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Nimble visitors to the Gallery can sit on the floor to look at this picture in order better to appreciate its spatial construction, and thus its full significance.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The revellers occupy a raised stage extending back to where rocks and vine-hung trees screen off the backdrop of sky and distant mountains.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Propped up vertically against this earthen stage are a timbrel and two masks - an ancient satyr mask and a modern Italian Columbine.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Behind them a Punchinello mask joins a still life drawn from the imagery of ancient bacchanals: thyrsoi - staffs wreathed with ivy and surmounted by pine cones - the crooked stick and pipes of Pan, wine in a metal bowl or crater, and a Greek wine jar showing the god Dionysus, the Roman Bacchus.The composition is indebted to an engraving after Giulio Romano, a pupil of Raphael, but Poussin also demonstrates his first-hand access to antiquarian lore.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The mixture of modern and ancient masks, and the stage-like construction, allude to the origins of theatre in bacchic rites.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The main scene represents the 'triumph' or worship of the armless bust of a horned deity mounted on a pillar, his face smeared red with the juice of boiled ivy stems.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: This is the 'term' of Pan, Arcadian god of shepherds and herdsmen, and Priapus, a phallic god of fertility, protector of gardens, whose cult was imported into Greece from the Near East.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Confused with each other, both were associated with Dionysus/Bacchus: Dionysus, god of the grape-vine, who died, descended into Hades then rose again was himself identified with seasonal decay and rebirth.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: All the participants are members of his entourage (as we find them in Titian's Bacchus and Ariadne): nymphs and their lewd playmates the satyrs; maenads who rend deer limb from limb or strew flowers from the winnowing basket sacred to Dionysus.
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: A world of pagan imaginings is brought to life in all its cruel and seductive charm, without a hint of anachronistic moralising
title: The Triumph of Pan
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: It was already apparent to Poussin's contemporaries that the artist had given much thought, in The Israelites Gathering Manna, to the means by which painting could unfold a sequence of events before the eyes of the viewer.
title: The Jews Gathering the Manna in the Desert
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The artist combines selected aspects of the biblical story into one scene, so as to illustrate the scale of the Israelites' divine rescue from hunger and misery.This painting can be considered a variation on the Raphael fresco, The School of Athens, in the Vatican.
title: The Jews Gathering the Manna in the Desert
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Moses in particular, in his draperies and pointing gesture, directly cites the figure of Plato in Raphael's fresco.
title: The Jews Gathering the Manna in the Desert
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Poussin has simply transformed the latter's architectural backdrop into a rock formation and rotated the setting - which in the fresco lies parallel to the pictorial plane - as if on a turntable towards the right, so that it now leads away at a diagonal into the depths
title: The Jews Gathering the Manna in the Desert
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The huge altarpiece was painted for the Sainte-Chapelle in Saint-Germaine-en-Laye
title: The Institution of the Eucharist
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: This picture marks the beginning of Poussin's final period, that in which poetry rises to an all-embracing feeling for the world - still, however, interpreted through a mythological guise.The subject was borrowed from "Metamorphoses" by Ovid.
title: Landscape with Polyphemus
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: A terrible one-eyed giant Polyphemus anamoured of nymph Galathea is singing of his love on a pipe
title: Landscape with Polyphemus
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: This painting is an extremely fine seventeenth-century copy of the original painting by Poussin in the Cleveland Museum of Art.
title: Holy Family on the Steps

sentence_text: The copyist was a contemporary artist who, although exhibiting different artistic sensibilities, nevertheless demonstrates a certain familiarity with Poussin's working methods
title: Holy Family on the Steps
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: This is perhaps the most popular painting of the artist.
title: The Assumption of the Virgin
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: There are many copies, enlarged or adapted versions from the 19th centuries in various churches in France
title: The Assumption of the Virgin
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: This painting, the latest and grandest of Poussin's three versions of the theme, was acquired by the National Gallery jointly with the National Museum of Wales in 1988 and is shown alternately in London and Cardiff.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Poussin illustrated events from the life of Moses at least nineteen times.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: It has been pointed out that when he could, he avoided painting scenes of saintly visions or martyrdoms, the stock-in-trade of seventeenth-century religious art.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: He concentrated instead on the central themes of Christianity, relating them both to their historical context in the ancient Near East and to the basic tenets of other religions, following an intellectual fashion of the day.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Of the Old Testament subjects which he painted, the majority belong to the category of types, or prefigurations, of Salvation.From Early Christian times the Old Testament was read by Christians for its analogies with the New.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Thus the waters of the Nile to which the infant Moses is consigned by his mother in 'an ark of bulrushes', following Pharaoh's cruel order to drown all the male Israelite babies (Exodus 1:2), were likened to the waters of baptism.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: But Poussin's interest in Moses may have been prompted also by his identification with pagan deities; as a contemporary writer influenced by these ideas wrote of this picture: 'He is Moses, the Mosche of the Hebrews, the Pan of the Arcadians, the Priapus of the Hellespont, the Anubis of the Egyptians.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: 'All these ideas reverberate throughout the painting.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The baby on whom Pharaoh's daughter has taken pity resembles the Christ Child blessing the Magi or the shepherds in a scene of the Adoration.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: In the background on the left an Egyptian priest worships the dog-shaped god Anubis (barely visible now that the surface paint has grown thin and transparent).
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: We know we are in Egypt because on the rock above the main scene a river god, symbolising the Nile, embraces a sphinx, palm trees stand on the shore and an obelisk rises up behind a stately temple.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: (Curiously, the many-windowed buildings with which Poussin, who had never been there, endows Pharaoh's country now resemble modern resort hotels.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: )The main interest and beauty of the painting, however, do not reside in its possible symbolism, but in the wonderful grouping of the figures, all women to contrast with an analogous group of men in Christ healing the Blind Man (now in the Louvre), painted for the same patron the year before.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Each plays her role in the dramatic tale, the princess generous and commanding, the maids curious and delighted.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: The humbler figure in a white shift at Moses' head may be his sister who watched from nearby to see what would happen to him, and recommended their mother to Pharaoh's daughter as a wet nurse.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: It is tempting to see their brilliant draperies as a compliment to Poussin's patron, the Lyon silk merchant Reynon.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: Bodies and colours, each distinct and separate, combine in ample rhythms across the picture surface, echoed by the rocks beyond.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: It is at once solemn and joyful, as befits a scene in which a child is rescued from death, and through him an entire people is saved.
title: The Finding of Moses
author: Nicolas POUSSIN

sentence_text: This spectacular composition is almost an inventory of Baroque architectural ceilings and their final triumph.
title: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work
author: Andrea POZZO

sentence_text: According to Jesuit ideas, the space within a church was a single area in which the faithful congregated.
title: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work
author: Andrea POZZO

sentence_text: In Sant'Ignazio space is stretched (Pozzo was clever at the illusion of "doubling" the perspective of the real architecture) before exploding into light and glory.
title: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work
author: Andrea POZZO

sentence_text: Saints, angels, allegories, and floating clouds accentuate the virtuoso effect.
title: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work
author: Andrea POZZO

sentence_text: The impression is one of exuberance and freedom.
title: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work
author: Andrea POZZO

sentence_text: In reality, it was worked out using scientific criteria.Designed to be viewed from a point in the centre of the nave, which is marked by a white stone, Padre Pozzo's ceiling produces the illusion of a palace opening on the sky.
title: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work
author: Andrea POZZO

sentence_text: The effect of the simulated cupola rests largely on the figural groupings on the pendentives, which were executed immediately after the canvas with the painted cupola was put in place.
title: Painting on the pendentive: Samson
author: Andrea POZZO

sentence_text: Painted on actual concave pendentives, they make the sham cupola more believable, especially when viewed from the entrance.

sentence_text: The pair of paintings of identical size, Roman Figures under an Arcade and Roman Figures in a Cave, were executed by Robert during his stay in Rome.

author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: They recall the work of Pannini, one of Robert's teachers, in their subject matter and colourful, classically draped figures amongst Roman ruins
title: Roman Figures under an Arcade
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: French painting in the second half of the 18th century displays the overlapping or intermingling of pre-Romantic and Neoclassical pictorial ideas, and nowhere is this clearer than in the work of the 'painter of ruins', Hubert Robert.
title: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: He obtained his ideas from Italy, where he admired the paintings of ruins by Giovanni Paolo Pannini, and witnessed the first excavations in Pompeii.
title: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: Praised by Diderot, he was immediately consulted when antique pieces were to be placed in the park of Versailles.
title: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: But his great work was the realization of the Louvre Museum.
title: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: A comparison of two of his paintings, the first showing a ruined barrel-vault hall, and the second the Grande Galerie in the Louvre, immediately reveals the source of the idea for the top lighting and the "antique effect" that the newly designed gallery is open to the sky.
title: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: The sublimity of antique ruins was to be transferred to the real building, and this in turn was to be a treasure chest of art and a worthy successor to its antique models
title: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: Hubert Robert painted many views, both real and imaginary, of the Grande Galerie of the Louvre.
title: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: His imaginary vies really constitute a set of designs for an ideal museum.
title: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: When he painted this picture (the finest in the series) in 1796, the Galley was nothing but an interminably long corridor, lit only by side windows, which linked the Louvre to the Tuileries.
title: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: The architects who were later responsible for the lighting and redecoration of the Grande Galerie were merely executing the original ideas of Hubert Robert.
title: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: In this painting several of the masterpieces of the Museum Central can be recognized, notably Raphael's Holy Family of François I and Titian's Entombment
title: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre
author: Hubert ROBERT

sentence_text: This painting belongs to a series depicting partly imaginary, partly later realized plans to transform the Grande Galerie of the Louvre into an exhibition space.

sentence_text: But she soon alleviated his lot by making him her lover.

sentence_text: While in her service he grew effeminate, wearing women's clothes and adornments, and spinning yarn.

sentence_text: In the 12th century, Pürgg was a seat of the margraves (from 1180 on dukes) of Styria.

sentence_text: The fresco depicting a battle between mice and cats is part of an extensive "Romanesque Bestiary"  whose images are distributed amongst numerous medieval churches and codices.

sentence_text: The animals featured often have a basis in zoological reality; but there are just as many cases where they are depicted as monstrous, bizarre and fantastic creatures

sentence_text: In St. Stephen's Chapel in the crypt of Saint-Germain in Auxerre, the visitor is confronted by a surprising composition: the stoning of St. Stephen is depicted in a tympanum.
title: Stoning of St Stephen
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: It illustrates, inspired by the text from the Acts of the Apostles (6:12), the final phase of the appearance of St. Stephen before his judges.
title: Stoning of St Stephen
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: In the middle of the trial he has a vision and declares that God has appeared to him.
title: Stoning of St Stephen
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: Then accused of blasphemy, he is stoned to death.Nearly all of the left-hand half of the picture is taken up by the representation  of a town which is scaled down in size in proportion to the figures.
title: Stoning of St Stephen
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: St. Stephen has just been dragged through this city gate and onto the place of his execution.
title: Stoning of St Stephen
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: Towering behind the humble St. Stephen, his torturers are depicted with their arms raised up ready to throw the stones.
title: Stoning of St Stephen
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: The figure of St. Stephen himself projects into the right half of the picture which otherwise consists of an empty space, broken up to great effect by the appearance of the hand of God
title: Stoning of St Stephen

sentence_text: The fresco cycle in the vault of the monastery church of Saint-Savin-sur-Gartempe narrates stories from the Old Testament in a rather confusing sequence.
title: Noah's Ark
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: When establishing the narrative composition, priority was given to the arrangement of narrative events rather than to the continuous narrative flow.
title: Noah's Ark
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: Thus, popular subjects, such as Noah's Ark, were made to stand out in spectacular fashion.As was common in the Middle Ages, the artist who created this picture showed the ark as a lateral elevation.
title: Noah's Ark
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: Judging by its hull, the ark is a Viking ship with a stem fortified by monsters, and a three-story superstructure and small wheel-house just as described in the Bible.
title: Noah's Ark
author: French ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: Animals look out through the round-arched windows, and Noah's family crouch above

sentence_text: In the small apse niche one can see a depiction of Christ in his glory, surrounded by angels and the symbols of the Evangelists.The picture in the vault of the Chapelle Conventuelle shows the mandorla depicting Christ enthroned on a bench covered with cushions and with his arms raised in blessing.

sentence_text: The church of St. Georg in Oberzell on Reichenau Island is the home of one of the few narrative picture cycles on the subject of Christ's miracles to have survived as a complete set from the Ottonian period.
title: The Storm on the Sea of Galilee
author: German ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: It was certainly painted by Byzantine-trained artists who continued their travels after completing their work in Oberzell.The continuous painted cycle running around the walls of the nave was designed from the very beginning as a narrative cycle.
title: The Storm on the Sea of Galilee
author: German ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: With a single exception, Jesus enters each scene from the left, thus establishing the direction of reading from left to right.
title: The Storm on the Sea of Galilee
author: German ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: The viewer entering the space will also start on the left side, the north wall.
title: The Storm on the Sea of Galilee
author: German ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: There we have the Gerasene demoniac, followed by the Healing of the Sick, the Storm on the Sea of Galilee, and the Healing of the Man who was Born Blind.
title: The Storm on the Sea of Galilee
author: German ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: The south wall contains the following scenes: the Healing of the Leper, the Raising of the Young Man, the Healing of the Woman of her Bloody Issue, the Raising of the Daughter of Jairus and the Raising of Lazarus from the Dead.The picture shows the third scene on the north wall: The Storm on the Sea of Galilee.
title: The Storm on the Sea of Galilee
author: German ROMANESQUE PAINTER

sentence_text: The second scene includes a building on the right with a white wall made of ashlars.
title: The Storm on the Sea of Galilee

sentence_text: The same wall can be seen on the left-hand side of the adjoining scene, The Storm on the Sea of Galilee, then suddenly stops.

sentence_text: This is where the Sea of Galilee begins.

sentence_text: Also visible is the boat which is soon to find itself in a storm.

sentence_text: In this devotional image, painted with brilliant palette, Romanino seems to have been interested in German art, especially in its expressivity
title: Christ Carrying the Cross

sentence_text: It is already clear in this, his first definitely dated work, that Girolamo Romanino, like Lotto and Savoldo, was reluctant to enter fully into the tradition of Venetian figurative art.
title: Piet?
author: Girolamo ROMANINO

sentence_text: The panel was painted for the Chapel of the Holy Passion in the old church of San Lorenzo in Brescia and in it we can see Romanino's predilection for Titian's sonorously rich colour transposed onto a plane of popular narrative strengthened by a romantic, imaginative pathos.
title: Piet?
author: Girolamo ROMANINO

sentence_text: Against the background of a landscape which itself seems constricted in its atmosphere of profound anguish, the figures of the foreground seem to float to the surface in sharply cadenced groupings painted in timbres of a blazing quality.
title: Piet?
author: Girolamo ROMANINO

sentence_text: The influence of Lombard style which can be noted in the roundish faces painted after the fashion of Bramante, are accompanied by the influence of Northern European painting which can be seen in the view of the town glimpsed through the steamy, stormy atmosphere, in the objective quality of the portrait of the man, in the expressionistic deformation of the little human figures moving around the crosses at Golgotha.In this earliest attributable work by Romanino, the characteristic quality of the artist's style is already evident: an expressionistic realism which seems to offer an extremely personalized reflection of the political, social and religious crises that shook the Western world in the first half of the sixteenth century
title: Piet?
author: Girolamo ROMANINO

sentence_text: Antonio Rossellino and his workshop played an important role in the creation of the burial chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal.
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: This elaborate undertaking was the result of the collaboration of an architect (Antonio Manetti), four sculptors (Antonio Rossellino, his brothers Bernardo and Giovanni, and Luca della Robbia), three painters (Alesso Baldovinetti, Antonio and Piero del Pollaiuolo), their workshops, and other craftsmen as well, and yet the chapel today - which looks exactly as it must have looked in the 1470s - is a stylistically unified totality rather than a demonstration of the diverse talents of a number of individuals.James (Jaime), a prince of the Portugal royal family who was made a cardinal at twenty-two, died of tuberculosis in Florence when he was only twenty-five.
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: He had expressed a desire to be buried at San Miniato, and immense sums poured in for his funerary chapel.The chapel was designed by Antonio Manetti, a pupil of Brunelleschi, and the architectural detail was carved by Giovanni Rossellino, third of the five Rossellino brothers.
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: The tomb was designed by Antonio Rossellino, who was helped in the execution by his brother Bernardo, and several assistants.
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: On the altar wall Antonio del Pollaiuolo's frescoed angels pull back curtains that can be related to the curtains that surround Rossellino's tomb on the right wall.
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: The painted altarpiece representing three saints is a work by Antonio del Pollaiuolo (presently a copy, the original being in the Uffizi).
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: On the left wall facing the tomb (not shown in this picture), Alesso Baldovinetti's Annunciation is placed.
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: Baldovinetti decorated also the lunettes and spandrels of the chapel.
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: The inlaid marble floor copies the Cosmati work found in the adjacent church; this pattern is echoed in the composition of Luca della Robbia's enamelled terracotta dome above, which has five medallions representing the Cardinal Virtues and the Descent of the Holy Ghost
title: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
author: Antonio ROSSELLINO

sentence_text: Pietro Rotari, born in Verona, was one of the Venetian Settecento masters who travelled extensively.
title: Young Girl with Distaff

sentence_text: His enchanting genre pieces, his half-length portraits of young girls enjoyed wide popularity, particularly in Vienna, Dresden and later in St. Petersburg, where the artist stayed for several years.
title: Young Girl with Distaff
author: Pietro Antonio ROTARI

sentence_text: He also painted large religious compositions and mythological scenes, but his fame rested on the small pictures usually produced in series, in which, as in the Budapest painting, a pretty young girl was represented with a distaff or reading a letter, perhaps slumbering or leaning over her book.
title: Young Girl with Distaff
author: Pietro Antonio ROTARI

sentence_text: In these works an appealing pose was coupled with fine, pure design and warm colouring
title: Young Girl with Distaff

sentence_text: The central section on paper is by Rubens, and this is fixed onto canvas and connect- ed to a generic background comprising a tree and curtain hanging on the right, by a late seventeenth-century painter probably from the Veneto.Despite its critical vicissitudes over the centuries, there is no lack of elements substantiating the author of the painting and its very high quality: the brilliant quality of the afresh tones, especially in the children; the emotional intensity of the looks; the material richness and the expert technique evident in the several tones of Titian-style red on which the chromatic distribution of the entire fragment is based.

sentence_text: The creation of a cycle of tapestries had, in a sense, been Rubens' technical apprenticeship for this demanding task, the composition of a cycle of vast narrative paintings dedicated to a living queen who had already entered history.Giving epic treatment to this biographical subject, Rubens was also able to give free rein to his fertile invention.

author: Peter Paul RUBENS

sentence_text: The entire commission was completed in only three years.All of his prodigious culture was drawn on for these works: his encyclopaedic knowledge of classical mythology was exploited to the full in transforming the queen's entire career - Henri slipped rather into the background - into a kind of operatic sequence largely of Rubens' own invention.

sentence_text: During the years from about 1650 to about 1655, the heroic quality of Ruisdael's landscapes increases.

sentence_text: Giant oaks and beeches as well as shrubs acquire an unprecedented abundance and fullness.

author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: Colours become more vivid, space increases in both height and depth, and there is an emphasis on the tectonic structure of the compositions.
title: Bentheim Castle
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: He strove to achieve heroic effects without sacrificing the individuality of a single tree or bush.
title: Bentheim Castle
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: An outstanding example of this tendency is his mighty view of Bentheim Castle.Ruisdael visited Bentheim, a small town in Wesphalia near the Dutch-German border, when he travelled to the region with his friend Berchem in the early fifties.
title: Bentheim Castle
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: Bentheim's castle is, in fact, on an unimposing low hill, but in his painting Ruisdael enlarged it into a wooded mountain providing the castle with a commanding position.
title: Bentheim Castle
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: His invention is a superb expression of his aggrandizement of solid forms during this phase.
title: Bentheim Castle
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: The dense mass of the mountain, obliquely stretching away into depth, and the coulisses on either side of the front edge of the painting are reminiscent of compositional schemes used by the generation of his teachers, but the spatial clarity is new, as are the strong colours, the energy of the brushwork, and the way he unifies the close view of a nearly overwhelming wealth of detail with the most distant parts of the landscape into a consistent whole.
title: Bentheim Castle
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: The impact of the broad prospect is as intense as the vegetation seen close up.
title: Bentheim Castle
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: Ruisdael continued to include Bentheim Castle in his landscapes, seen in various settings and from different viewpoints, until his very last years

sentence_text: Besides the Bentheim Castle, another motif Ruisdael discovered on his trip to the Dutch-German border region was the water mill.

sentence_text: The half-timbered overshot and undershot mills he favoured were found in the eastern provinces of the Netherlands and in the area near Bentheim.

author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: Of course, earlier artists included watermills in their pictures but he was the first to make them the principal theme of a painting.
title: Two Watermills and an Open Sluice
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: The subject became one of the specialities of his pupil Meindert Hobbema, and today, when we think of them, his paintings not Ruisdael's come to mind.
title: Two Watermills and an Open Sluice
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: But in judging their respective accomplishments it is helpful to recall that Ruisdael painted powerful ones, such as Two Water Mills and an Open Sluice, which impresses by the cohesion of its forms and clear daylight effect, before Hobbema held a brush in his hand

sentence_text: The combination of their conspicuous tombs, ruins, large dead beech trees, broken trunks, and rushing streams alludes to the familiar themes of transience and the vanity of life and the ultimate futility of human endeavour, while the burst of light that breaks through the ravening clouds in each painting, their rainbows and the luxuriant growth that contrasts with the dead trees offer a promise of hope and renewed life.The masterliness of the Dresden painting lies in the artist's clear and concentrated presentation of these ideas.
title: The Jewish Cemetery
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: The eye focuses on the three tombs in the middle distance, where the light is centralized.

sentence_text: They present a truthful picture of the actual, identifiable sarcophagi as they can still be seen in the Portuguese-Jewish Cemetery at Ouderkerk on the Amstel River near Amsterdam.

sentence_text: Most remarkable is the barren beech tree in the Dresden picture that gestures toward the three tombs and heavenwards.
title: The Jewish Cemetery

sentence_text: If ever a tree was capable of seducing a viewer to accept the pathetic fallacy of endowing natural forms with human feelings and emotions it is this dead beech.The iconographical programme of Ruisdael's two versions of the Jewish Cemetery leaves no doubt that they were intended as moralizing landscapes.
title: The Jewish Cemetery

sentence_text: He made no others that can be given a similar unmistakable reading.

sentence_text: None of his other existing paintings include tombs; those done by his contemporaries are rare, and some of them are based on his depictions of the sarcophagi at Ouderkerk.
title: The Jewish Cemetery
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: However, Ruisdael made numerous pictures that include identifiable or imaginary ruins, dead and broken trees, rushing streams, rivers, and waterfalls.
title: The Jewish Cemetery

sentence_text: Were these motifs invariably intended by the artist as symbols of transience and the vanity of life, and does the handful of them that include rainbows allude to hope?

sentence_text: It has been argued that this is indeed the case, and that these motifs not only offer the iconographical essence of Ruisdael's landscapes but offer the key to the meaning to seventeenth-century landscape painting.

sentence_text: Panoramic views of the flat plains in Holland are often said to be the most distinctive contribution of Dutch landscape painting.
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: They differ from the 'world panorama' of earlier Flemish art by seemingly recording the momentary view of a single scene, rather than being composed of a collection of separate visual memories.
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: Formally, they are characterized bb a low horizon line, implying a low viewpoint.
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: Although Ruisdael, perhaps the greatest and the most versatile Dutch landscape specialist, did not invent this type of picture, he became one of its most distinguished practitioners.This painting may represent a view in Gooiland, a district to the east of Amsterdam; there are, however, at least four other, smaller landscapes by Ruisdael that show the same view or part of it with considerable variations, and it is clear that he was not attempting strict topographical accuracy.
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: Despite the pretence of spontaneity, this work, like all landscape paintings of the time, is a synthetic product of the artist's studio.Its dominant feature is the sky, to which two thirds of the picture surface is devoted and which is also reflected in the water of the foreground.
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: This is the real, moisture-laden sky of Holland billowing with clouds, the sun breaking sporadically through scattering shafts of light across the countryside - effects which Constable was later to emulate.
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: Almost more remarkable than the truthful record of the shape, density and illumination of the clouds is the illusion that they are moving through space and over our heads (we tend to think that perspective does not govern cloudscapes, but these seem to taper towards the horizon and broaden at the upper edge of the painting).
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: The long horizon too seems to extend beyond the frame, broken only by church spires and the tiny white sails of a windmill.
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: But our sense of inhabiting the landscape is compromised by our viewpoint in relation to the foreground.
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: By letting us look down into the bastion standing below the horizon line, the painter suggests that we are viewing it from some improbably high place, higher also than the shore on which the peasants graze their flock (both figures and animals were painted by Adriaen van der Velde, a division of labour quite common in Dutch landscapes).
title: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church
author: Jacob Isaackszon van RUISDAEL

sentence_text: This implied detachment, however, strengthens the elegiac mood aroused by the sight of overgrown ruins, melancholy reminders of a distant and more heroic past

sentence_text: Particularly noteworthy is the contrast of the dark background and the brilliantly yet softly illuminated figures in the foreground

sentence_text: This large tondo featuring the Triumph of Fame on its front side was painted to celebrate the birth of Lorenzo de' Medici who was later known as Lorenzo il Magnifico.
title: Triumph of Fame (a Birth Salver)
author: SCHEGGIA

sentence_text: This is one of many examples of such two-sided tondi painted for Florentine families, although exactly how they were used is still uncertain.The theme chosen for this one derived from the Triumphs of Petrarch and Boccaccio's The Vision of Love.
title: Triumph of Fame (a Birth Salver)
author: SCHEGGIA

sentence_text: Trumpets announce the arrival of Fame from the globe on which the allegorical figure stands and knights arrive to honour her.The feathers on the frame are a reference to Lorenzo's father Piero de Gouty, and the reverse of the tondo features other references to the Medici, as well as to the family of Lorenzo's mother, Lucrezia Tornabuoni
title: Triumph of Fame (a Birth Salver)

sentence_text: Of these figures, St Agnes is the most striking in her charming classical pose and the sheer, gauzelike chiton she wears.

sentence_text: On the outsides of the wings (not shown here) the donor and his family are presented, kneeling in front of their patron saints

sentence_text: It is a painting with an official, doctrinal message, based on the association of the three Johns.

author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

sentence_text: Chrysostom is sitting side on, not in compliance with any mannerist idiosyncrasy but simply to enable us to see and read the book of his golden Word.The altarpiece has at the centre an old man reading, oblivious of the saints around him.

author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

sentence_text: It is a tightly knit and crowded group, the slightly yearning figure of St John the Baptist on the right looking inwards is balanced by a trio of grandly assured, superb Venetian beauties looking forwards and outwards at the spectator.

author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

sentence_text: The figures are in an architectural setting.This altarpiece is the major work of Sebastiano executed in Venice before he removed to Rome permanently in 1511
title: San Giovanni Crisostomo Altarpiece
author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

sentence_text: Of the many painters who assimilated and vulgarised the contemplative, romantic manner of Giorgione, Sebastiano del Piombo was inspired by the monumental form and by the possibility of making it solemn with the use of colour.
title: Death of Adonis
author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

sentence_text: It is precisely in this contained plasticism that we find the result of the integration of the two pictorial cultures.
title: Death of Adonis
author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

sentence_text: This painting shows a still Giorgionesque atmosphere - the view of the lake and the sunset - in which three superb examples of sculptural nudity are inserted: a doleful Venus, and her attendant maidservants, who turn abruptly to silence a bearded Pan who is continuing to play his flute
title: Death of Adonis
author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

title: Polyphemus
author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

sentence_text: He is looking longingly at the sea, out to the right, where in the adjacent field of the wall Raphael depicted the voyage of the nereid Galatea.
title: Polyphemus
author: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO

sentence_text: Sebastiano's Polyphemus is a Venetian painting of mood, rich in atmosphere, treated in an airy and loose style

sentence_text: In his years in Italy, Gerard Seghers conformed to the ideas of the 'Tenebrosi'.
title: Denial of St Peter
author: Gerard SEGHERS

sentence_text: After his return to Antwerp he could take full advantage of the fashionable interest in Caravaggist painting, which had become an international phenomenon.
title: Denial of St Peter
author: Gerard SEGHERS

sentence_text: He became celebrated for his monumental half-length genre scenes.
title: Denial of St Peter
author: Gerard SEGHERS

sentence_text: But he was highly regarded in the 1620s for his large religious and allegorical pictures, conceived in a genre style, and mostly done in landscape format.
title: Denial of St Peter
author: Gerard SEGHERS

sentence_text: These paintings, such as the Denial of St Peter, contain scenes with numerous characters, depicted with lively poses and facial expressions, grouped compactly together against an undefined background; they are painted half-length or are cut off by the edge of the painting.
title: Denial of St Peter
author: Gerard SEGHERS

sentence_text: The concealed candlelight casts a flickering and sharply contrasting gleam on the multi-coloured, theatrical clothing of the figures creating a powerful dramatic effect.These Caravaggist group compositions differ only in subject from contemporary secular genre paintings and just like them are ultimately derived from the compositions of Caravaggio's pupil Bartolomeo Manfredi.
title: Denial of St Peter
author: Gerard SEGHERS

sentence_text: There is also a strong relationship with the style of Gerrit van Honthorst of Utrecht, who must have known Seghers in Rome
title: Denial of St Peter
author: Gerard SEGHERS

sentence_text: Hercules Seghers was a gifted contemporary of Rembrandt.

sentence_text: His view of Rhenen demonstrates a low horizon and incipient drama that, along with Seghers's unique etching style, were very well known to Rembrandt.
title: View of Rhenen
author: Hercules SEGHERS

sentence_text: Both artists' landscapes seem far more than just what meets the eye, becoming transcendental visions reflecting eternity and mutability alike
title: View of Rhenen
author: Hercules SEGHERS

sentence_text: The centre panel was flanked by panels depicting St John the Baptist (Perkins Collection, Sacro Convento di San Francesco, Assisi), and St John the Evangelist (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York).When intact, the altarpiece would have resembled Duccio's polyptych in the Pinacoteca Nazionale, Siena (the so-called polyptych 47).
title: St Silvester Gozzolini
author: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE

sentence_text: The pairing of Sts John the Baptist and John the Evangelist - the forerunner of Christ and the beloved disciple - to either side of the Madonna and Child is not uncommon and may relate either to the dedication of the chapel or to the name of the patron.
title: St Silvester Gozzolini
author: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE

sentence_text: On the other hand, the presence of Sts Benedict (c. 480–543) and Silvester Gozzolini (1177–1267) virtually assures that the altarpiece was painted for a monastery of the Silvestrine order, which was founded by Silvester in 1231 and followed the rule of St Benedict
title: St Silvester Gozzolini

sentence_text: The Grote Kerk in Weesp was originally a Catholic church consecrated to St Lawrence, in 1582 it became Protestant and its name was changed from Laurentiuskerk to Grote Kerk.For Dutch architectural painters the people in the church served as staffage to enliven the stone setting.

sentence_text: About seventy can be counted, a few of whom seem to be portraits.

sentence_text: Certain elements, such as the dogs, bring a genre scene to mind.

title: Empedocles
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: On a small tablet set in among the grotesques, the painter's initials "LS" can be seen.If we look carefully at the anthropomorphic decorations, crowded with naked bodies in an incredible variety of poses, or the convulsive violence (that Scarpellini has compared to action painting) that runs through some of the foliage patterns or the groups of tritons and naiads like an electric current, we can really begin to understand Signorelli's great ability as a draughtsman, a talent that is further confirmed by his drawing production
title: Empedocles
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: The man lying on the ground and biting his hand in the badly damaged fragment on the altar walls thought to represent Cain.
title: Fresco fragment
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: In fact, biting one's hand is a traditional symbol of envy, one of Cain's seven sins.
title: Fresco fragment
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: In the medallion of the grotesque decor below, a murder scene with Triton-like creatures is depicted.
title: Fresco fragment
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: Here the murder weapon is the jawbone of an ass, the one used by Cain in killing his brother Abel.This fresco fragment was discovered during a recent restoration
title: Fresco fragment
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: In the predella that Signorelli probably painted with the help of his assistant, Gerolamo Genga, four scenes from the Passion of Christ are represented: The Prayer in the Garden; The Last Supper; The Capture; The Flagellation.This picture shows the scene of the Flagellation
title: The Flagellation
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: The individual apostles cannot be identified with the exception of Peter and John, who stand in the panel to the left of the Christ-Thomas grouping.
title: Pair of Apostles in Dispute
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: The idea of presenting pairs of apostles in debate is borrowed from the bronze doors that Donatello created for the Old Sacristy at San Lorenzo, Florence.
title: Pair of Apostles in Dispute
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: Signorelli borrowed not only some of the compositional features of Donatello's reliefs but also specific iconographic details.
title: Pair of Apostles in Dispute
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: Like Donatello, he depicts his apostles barefoot and draped in classical garments, eschewing any identifying attributes and even halos
title: Pair of Apostles in Dispute
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: Very few portraits survive from Signorelli's hand.
title: Portrait of an Elderly Man
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: Indubitably his finest is the Portrait of an Elderly Man, probably of a humanist.
title: Portrait of an Elderly Man
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: It is often said to be of a jurist, that profession and humanism considered practically inseparable.
title: Portrait of an Elderly Man
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: Victories before a temple approach athletes in front of a triumphal arch, these all'antica themes pertinent to the sitter's scholarly calling or pretensions.
title: Portrait of an Elderly Man
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: The action taking place in the background may be on his mind, as suggested by his downcast eyes.
title: Portrait of an Elderly Man
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: The hard-won balance between hat, head, V-shaped scarf, and the far-smaller figures is among the major triumphs of his great portrait
title: Portrait of an Elderly Man
author: Luca SIGNORELLI

sentence_text: After a few years of Duccio's Maestà, Simone painted his Maestà for the Palazzo Pubblico in Siena, as the ideal of the good and just government.
title: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: This is the oldest painting that can be safely attributed to him.
title: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: The end wall of the Sala del Mappamondo is entirely covered by this fresco.
title: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: Surrounded by a frame decorated with twenty medallions depicting the Blessing Christ, the Prophets and the Evangelists and with smaller shields containing the coat-of-arms of Siena, the fresco shows a host of angels, Saints and Apostles, with the Madonna and Child in the centre.
title: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: The whole scene, set against a deep blue background, is surmounted by an imposing canopy of red silk.The most obvious innovations present in Simone's style are his ideas of three-dimensional space.
title: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: The supporting poles of the canopy are placed in perspective, thus giving a sense of depth to the composition.
title: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: Under the canopy there is a crowd of thirty people: no more processions of people in parallel rows, but concrete spacial rhythms and animated gestures
title: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: On the underside of the entrance arch of the Cappella di San Martino eight full-length saints are painted in four pairs.
title: St Anthony of Padua and St Francis
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: They are Saints Francis, Clare, and Anthony of Padua  - tributes to the Order that administered the Basilica - as well as other saints connected to Robert of Anjou: Louis of Toulouse, his older brother; Elizabeth of Hungary, the aunt of his mother, Mary; Louis IX, King of France, his great-grandfather; Mary Magdalene and Catherine of Alexandria, saints his father Charles II was particularly devoted to
title: St Anthony of Padua and St Francis
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: The two Madonnas in the Siena Pinacoteca, one from Castiglione d'Orcia and the other from Lucignano d'Arbia, are clearly related and must date from more or less the same period.
title: Madonna and Child (from Castiglione d'Orcia)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: But we have no dates, no signatures and no documents containing any information at all regarding the dating of these works: stylistic analysis is the only element that critics have been able to use.
title: Madonna and Child (from Castiglione d'Orcia)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: This justifies the widely varying opinions that have been expressed on the subject: some scholars believe that they are totally autograph, while others think that Simone is responsible only for the drawings or for certain sections of the painting, while others still consider them entirely the work of the workshop assistants.Nonetheless, there are many analogies between the various paintings from this period, such as for example, the features of the Madonna in the San Domenico Polyptych, with her gentle and slightly dreaming eyes, repeated almost exactly in the Madonna in the Orvieto Polyptych; or the lively pose of the Child in the panel from Castiglione d'Orcia which is exactly the same as that of the Child in the Boston painting
title: Madonna and Child (from Castiglione d'Orcia)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: A great deal has been written about the iconography of the Madonna from Lucignano d'Arbia, very unusual in Sienese painting.
title: Madonna and Child (from Lucignano d'Arbia)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: Mary is shown looking to the right, instead of to the left, and she holds a Child who is not yet a "puer" (as was the case in all the earlier paintings) but still an "infans" in swaddling clothes.
title: Madonna and Child (from Lucignano d'Arbia)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: The reason that led Simone to choose this iconography has yet to be explained, and it may have been a specific request from the client; but scholars do agree on the attribution of the panel to Simone
title: Madonna and Child (from Lucignano d'Arbia)
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: The fresco of Guidoriccio da Fogliano, depicting the conquest of the castles of Montemassi and Sassoforte in 1328, formed part of a fresco cycle "Castelli" which occupied the upper part of the wall opposite to the Maestà in the Sala del Mappamondo.
title: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: The cycle, commemorating the castles conquered by the Sienese, was initiated in 1314 by the representation of the Castle of Giuncarico, it was continued by the Guidoriccio and in 1331 by the Castles of Arcidosso and Piano.
title: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: The latter were destroyed in 1361 when Lippo Vanni painted the Battles of Valdichiana and Poggio Imperiale.
title: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: In the 1970s, the famous fresco, which had always been, considered the greatest example of Martini's artistic excellence, was re-attributed to a much later artist.
title: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano

title: Entombment

sentence_text: It presents several problems, both in terms of stylistic analysis and dating.Some scholars, stressing the fact that it is so different stylistically from all the other works of Simone's Avignon period (nervous lines and expressions), think that it may have been painted earlier and then transported to France; others believe that it may be a late work, commissioned by Napoleone Orsini, who died in the Curia in Avignon in 1342.
title: Entombment
author: SIMONE MARTINI

sentence_text: Arachne was in fact so adept at weaving that she became arrogant, and claimed that her ability rivaled that of the goddess Athena.

sentence_text: A contest was arranged, and having been bested by the mortal Arachne, the infuriated goddess cursed the girl, turning her into a spider in punishment for her effrontery.Strozzi's depiction of Arachne is part of a group of bust length depictions of female allegorical and historical figures and of saints that he began to create early on, perhaps in response to the visit to Genoa of Simon Vouet in 1620-22.

sentence_text: The painting is dominated by the delicate and sensitive beauty of the model's face, radiating from the background of warm colours.
title: Portrait of the Artist's Wife
author: Pál SZINYEI MERSE

sentence_text: In Szinye's pictures, the women are often shown wearing in their hair or on their hats colourful flowers, or as in the case of "Portrait in Shawl", laces and ribbons.
title: Portrait of the Artist's Wife
author: Pál SZINYEI MERSE

sentence_text: We can almost be certain that he did not use them just to conform with the fashion of the age.
title: Portrait of the Artist's Wife
author: Pál SZINYEI MERSE

sentence_text: These colourful patches were necessary to emphasize the beauty of the face and the fine rosiness of the skin, as well as to produce a definite separation from the dark background
title: Portrait of the Artist's Wife
author: Pál SZINYEI MERSE

sentence_text: This painting is above the antechoir passageway in Sant'Andrea della Valle.
title: Arrival of the St Andrew Relic in Ancona

sentence_text: It belongs to the scenes from the martyrdom of St Andrew painted by Mattia Preti on the choir walls.
title: Arrival of the St Andrew Relic in Ancona

sentence_text: Originally Preti was also supposed to paint the smaller panels above the passages to the presbytery chapels.
title: Arrival of the St Andrew Relic in Ancona

author: Emilio TARUFFI

sentence_text: The scenes - St Andrew Condemned by Aegeus, and Arrival of the St Andrew Relic in Ancona - produced jointly by the two young Bolognese artists completed the cycle
title: Arrival of the St Andrew Relic in Ancona
