sentence_text: Abraham van den Tempel painted a series of three allegorical history pieces for the governors of the Lakenhal, or Clothmakers' Hall in Leiden between 1648 and 1651.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: The commission was a prestigious one, not only because of the size of the pictures, but also because they were history pieces to be displayed in a high ranking public building.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: The governors who commissioned the work were men of considerable stature, too.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: They were entrusted by the city fathers with the day-to-day management of one of Leiden's nine textile sectors, known in Dutch as 'neringen'.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: In this capacity they were responsible for the manufacture of and trade in worsted, a sector that was booming at the time.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: Their seat of office was the brand-new building which has been known to this day as the Lakenhal.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: They wanted classicist decorations worthy of their modern building.Regarding the series, Minerva Crowns the Maid of Leiden originally served as the overmantel, while the other two, Mars Banishes 'Nering' and The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering' hung on the long wall beside one another.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: The latter two paintings form pendants, being the same size and related in subject-matter.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: The theme that connects them is 'nering', the term formerly used in Leiden for the production of and trade in textile.Whereas the Mars Banishes 'Nering' illustrates the misfortune caused by war, the painting The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering' embodies the antithesis, where freedom, justice and peace foster trade and industry.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: Here Minerva and Mercury return as witnesses of the principal scene in which the Maid of Leiden stands on a step in her purple gown and crimson mantel and extends a hand to Nering, while Liberty, with her broken weapons and the hat symbolising freedom, kneels at her feet.
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: Under her arm Nering clutches a bound volume containing the statutes establishing the worsted nering in 1638
title: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'
author: Abraham van den TEMPEL

sentence_text: This painting renowned work in the eighteenth century, partly due to its dissemination through engravings.
title: A Cobbler in his Workshop
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: It was the source of inspiration for a number of French artists, perhaps most notably Jean-Siméon Chardin.
title: A Cobbler in his Workshop
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: There is a direct connection between the present painting and one of Chardin's work in the Louvre, The Canary, which shows a woman teaching her canary to sing.
title: A Cobbler in his Workshop
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The two works not only share thematic similarities, but also compositional ones.The painting is signed and dated lower right, on the work bench: 'D: TENIERS · FEC A 1671'
title: A Cobbler in his Workshop
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The huge collection owned by Archduke Leopold Wilhelm of Austria (1614-1662), Governor of the Spanish Netherlands from 1646 to 1656, was dominated by 16th-century Italian painting but contained a fair proportion of contemporary Flemish works by Van Dyck, Rubens, and others.
title: The Art Collection of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: When he stepped down as governor, he took his collection back to Austria where it is now the nucleus of the collections of paintings in the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna
title: The Art Collection of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The painting shows an interior with an old man with a pipe and a flagon seated at a table, other figures smoking by a fireplace beyond.This painting is known in several old copies, some perhaps produced in Teniers' own studio.
title: Old Man with a Pipe
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The present work is now known to be the signed original - the large number of replicas testament to both its immediate and enduring popularity as a quiet but powerful image
title: Old Man with a Pipe
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: In a large, open, barn-like structure, which serves as a guardroom, groups of monkeys wearing soldiers' uniforms are grouped around tables playing cards and back-gammon.Pictures of monkeys had been popular from the sixteenth-century and it was Teniers who developed the theme in the seventeenth-century.
title: Guardroom with Monkeys
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The primary role of the monkey in visual and literary sources of the sixteenth-century was to represent the irrational and foolish side of man's nature, but monkeys also were symbols of sinfulness and seen as devils
title: Guardroom with Monkeys
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: Depictions of the 'kermis' or rural fair belong to an iconographic and compositional tradition founded in the Netherlands in about 1550 by Pieter Brueghel the Elder.
title: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: So when David Teniers painted his first country fair in i637, his native town of Antwerp could already look back on an almost century-long tradition in this genre.The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn shown here demonstrates how Teniers had grown away from Adriaen Brouwer and developed his own style, distinguished primarily by a lighter overall tone and warmer, more radiant colours.
title: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The scale of his figures is somewhat reduced in his village scenes, so that they fit more convincingly into his broad, expansive landscapes with their subtly shaded atmospheres.
title: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The festivities are being held here in a square, bounded on two sides by a wooden fence, in front of a village tavern similar to that in many other Flemish kermis paintings.
title: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: A path leads off to the left in the direction of Antwerp Cathedral, which gives the rural festivities a local and municipal frame of reference.
title: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The sky, with its vivid stretches of cloud and the gold-tinged light of the evening on the left, is given a special weight, which lends the scene a cool, airy atmosphere and a festive mood.The joyful, lively antics of the farmers are not based on Teniers's own observations, but are pieced together from the handed-down repertoire of motifs for this genre, which were constantly varied and modified.
title: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: They include the musicians standing on their podium, the three couples doing a round dance in the foreground, the drunk who is being helped home by two farmers, and the man who is leaning by the fence in an attack of nausea.
title: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: At the end of the canvas on the right edge we also see the motif of the 'unequal couple': Teniers had already used lecherous old farmers hugging young girls as a single motif for a painting
title: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The depiction of village festivals was one of Teniers' most popular subjects.
title: Country Kermis
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: A large group of standing figures provides an opportunity to deploy a range of poses, gestures and relationships
title: Country Kermis
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The picture shows a countryside inn with revellers enjoying an afternoon's drinking, the innkeeper chopping wood in the foreground, and a pastoral landscape beyond.
title: Countryside Inn with Revellers
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: Teniers delighted in the portrayal of peasant revelry for the scope of characterisation and gesture that it afforded him.
title: Countryside Inn with Revellers
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: Drink is always present in his peasant scenes, and usually the cause of the subject at hand.It is noteworthy that the figures in the present image are larger than usual.The painting, which formerly belonged to the Hermitage in St. Petersburg, is signed and dated on a rock lower centre left: D.TENIERS.
title: Countryside Inn with Revellers
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: This is one of the many versions of this subject painted by Teniers.
title: The Temptation of St Anthony
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: St Anthony in his blue habit, crouched over a low table, book in hand, the temptress hag behind and a surrounding array of astonishing and unnatural creatures, such as the hideous ecorché dog, barking at the saint in the foreground
title: The Temptation of St Anthony
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The Witches' Initiation was a popular subject in the circles of the Saftleven brothers in Rotterdam.
title: Witches' Initiation
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: In Teniers's version the witching is taking place in the distant background, where a young, naked witch with a broomstick between her legs is being anointed before she flies off through the gaping hearth.
title: Witches' Initiation
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: In the foreground two ladies are studying books in a civilised fashion.
title: Witches' Initiation
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: The assemblage of objects at right retains the character of a still-life
title: Witches' Initiation
author: David the Younger TENIERS

sentence_text: This painting having the popular title of Parental Admonition (another version in the Staatliche Museen, Berlin) was the subject of a charming passage by Goethe.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: In his "Die Wahlverwandtschaften" Goethe notes the delicacy of attitude of the figures.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: He remarks how the father quietly and moderately admonishes his daughter who is seen from behind.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: The woman in black, sipping from a glass, Goethe interprets as the young woman's mother, who lowers her eyes so as not to be too attentive to the 'father's admonition'.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: This moralizing title, however, is without foundation and not in accordance with Ter Borch's usual themes.The authoritative biographer of the artist interprets the picture in the opposite sense, as a brothel scene, assuming that the seated gentleman holds a coin in his right hand, offering it to the girl.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: In fact, the detail of the coin is not visible.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: (The coin is omitted in the engraving Goethe knew).
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: In the Berlin version the passage is rubbed; a former owner may have had it painted over because she or he found it an embarrassing allusion.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: The Amsterdam version does not show the coin either, but its original paint surface is generally abraded; thus it is impossible to tell if it ever included the tell-tale coin.Ter Borch's psychology is so delicate that the  common scenes he repeatedly painted are raised to the level of highly civilized life.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: That Goethe's interpretation was possible at all shows the refinement of Ter Borch's treatment.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: Even if he made a mistake, Goethe had the right feeling for the way Ter Borch treated his subjects.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: Psychologically and pictorially he retains a sensitive touch and delicacy.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: The young woman is seen from behind; thus her face is averted.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: The only flesh visible is her neck, which is modelled with tender, silvery grey shadows.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: We have, however, opportunity to admire the silver-grey satin and black velvet of her gown.Ter Borch's minuteness and nicety of handling concentrate largely on painting stuffs.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: Contrary to Vermeer's paintings, the dim light and the subdued chiaroscuro do not allow a forceful grasp of the whole field of vision.
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: The light comes mostly from the front and stops at the glossy surfaces of the costumes and other textures
title: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)
author: Gerard TERBORCH

sentence_text: An officer set against a dark undefined background, stands on the left, looking down on a young man opposite him, who is seated with his legs apart at a simple low table writing a letter, and leaning forward in deep concentration.

sentence_text: In Dutch seventeenth-century art it was usually the women who were represented in the act of writing letters, associated with love and courtship.

sentence_text: Terborch depictions of officers writing or receiving letters is without precedent.

sentence_text: Earlier scenes with officers and soldiers were set in guardrooms.

sentence_text: In addition to the paintings by Caravaggio, Terbrugghen was also inspired by Northern imagery from the sixteenth century and by the subject matter and figure style of his contemporary, Dirck van Baburen.
title: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass
author: Hendrick TERBRUGGHEN

sentence_text: The two artists probably shared a studio in Utrecht, and around 1620 both artists produced series of genre scenes with single figures - musicians, singers, smokers and drinkers.
title: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass
author: Hendrick TERBRUGGHEN

sentence_text: These genre scenes were often produced in pairs.Terbrugghen's figures have often been interpreted as allegories of the Five Senses.
title: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass
author: Hendrick TERBRUGGHEN

sentence_text: The present painting has been seen as interpreting Taste.
title: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass
author: Hendrick TERBRUGGHEN

sentence_text: It was only partly executed by Terbrugghen, the painting was completed by another, inferior hand in his workshop
title: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass
author: Hendrick TERBRUGGHEN

sentence_text: This painting, which was altered by the artist and later cropped at the corners, depicts an almost claustrophobic interior, featuring a bare-chested prostitute clutching the fur garment of a man wearing a mask and pince-nez, both of which make him appear much older than he actually is.
title: Unequal Couple
author: Hendrick TERBRUGGHEN

sentence_text: This churlish whore smiles at us knowingly, uncouthly exposing her discoloured teeth in the process
title: Unequal Couple
author: Hendrick TERBRUGGHEN

sentence_text: On returning from his sojourn in Italy, Terbrugghen developed in Utrecht a light, colourful Caravaggism inclined to musical and gallant themes.
title: Woman Playing the Lute
author: Hendrick TERBRUGGHEN

sentence_text: The fanciful garb of the figures, framed in half-length, recalls the theatrical world.

sentence_text: Through Cassiano dal Pozzo, secretary of Cardinal Francesco Barberini and the patron of Nicolas Poussin, Testa gained access in Rome to the circle around Poussin.

sentence_text: In the second half of the 17th century all of Europe admired - though no one really imitated - France's various academies: art (established in 1648), science (1666) and architecture (1671).
title: Colbert Presenting the Members of the Royal Academy of Sciences to Louis XIV in 1667
author: Henri TESTELIN

sentence_text: These academies were not only repositories of knowledge, they also backed extensive operations such as factories (tapestries, mirrors)and specialized workshops directed by superintendents and their agents.
title: Colbert Presenting the Members of the Royal Academy of Sciences to Louis XIV in 1667
author: Henri TESTELIN

sentence_text: Never had artistic life been organized so thoroughly, so precisely, so extensively.
title: Colbert Presenting the Members of the Royal Academy of Sciences to Louis XIV in 1667
author: Henri TESTELIN

sentence_text: This was the work of Colbert and his circle

sentence_text: Our gaze roams from the vineyards on the slopes of Loessnitz into the far distance, where the city of Dresden appears as a silhouette, the tower of the Hofkirche still incomplete.
title: View of Dresden from the Loessnitz Heights
author: Johann Alexander THIELE

sentence_text: The striking outlines of Alpsandsteingebirge can be seen on the horizon, with the fortress of Königstein standing out most noticeably.Thiele is at the peak of his abilities in this painting: the landscape swings rhythmically with the river and the chains of hills, until the contours all dissolve in the background.
title: View of Dresden from the Loessnitz Heights
author: Johann Alexander THIELE

sentence_text: A feeling of distance is produced by the dark brown passages at the front.
title: View of Dresden from the Loessnitz Heights
author: Johann Alexander THIELE

sentence_text: Late seventeenth-century landscapes, such as those of Pieter Gysels, perhaps, may have stimulated this view
title: View of Dresden from the Loessnitz Heights
author: Johann Alexander THIELE

sentence_text: The represented figures are Francis of Assisi, the Archangel Michael and John the Baptist

sentence_text: In this scene Odysseus escapes drowning.

sentence_text: He is rescued on the isle of Calypso.
title: Odysseus and Ino Leucothea (scene 8)

sentence_text: When he left Calypso on a raft of his own making, he once again encountered Neptune's storm.

author: Pellegrino TIBALDI

sentence_text: The sea nymph Ino Leucothea gave him her veil, which carried the hero safely through the waves.Ino was a mortal queen of Thebes, who after her death and transfiguration was worshiped as a goddess under her epithet Leucothea, the "white goddess.

sentence_text: The young Pellegrino Tibaldi, who was one of Daniele da Volterra's assistants in Rome, executed two murals in the newly constructed chapel of Cardinal Giovanni Poggi in San Giacomo, Bologna.
title: The Sermon of John the Baptist
author: Pellegrino TIBALDI

sentence_text: The chapel, which is dedicated to John the Baptist, has an elaborate system of architectonic articulation.
title: The Sermon of John the Baptist
author: Pellegrino TIBALDI

sentence_text: Tibaldi's frescoes (The Sermon of John the Baptist; Annunciation of the Birth of John the Baptist) are restricted to one large field each on the left and right walls.
title: The Sermon of John the Baptist
author: Pellegrino TIBALDI

sentence_text: The frescoes are distinguished by unconventional iconography, learned allegory, and newly invented moments in history, that are at the same time commented on by painted manifestations in the heavens.In the left-hand mural John is baptizing and preaching repentance, while angels in heaven are putting devils into chains
title: The Sermon of John the Baptist
author: Pellegrino TIBALDI

sentence_text: The central ceiling painting in the Gallery depicts the sacrifice of Isaac.

sentence_text: Accompanied by a shaft of divine light, an angel floats down on a cloud to stay Abraham's hand just as he is about to slay his son as commanded by God.

sentence_text: The ram, which is to be sacrificed in Isaac's place can already be seen on the lower edge of the picture

sentence_text: On the ceiling of the staircase the image of Time Revealing Truth and Casting Out Envy is depicted.

sentence_text: The walls of the staircase ramps contain two polychrome scenes, Vigilance Triumphing over Sleep and Innocence Casting Out Deception, alluding to the Loschi family virtues

author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: The frescoes decorating the main hall of the villa in Massanzago in the Province of Padua were attributed until the 1980s to various eighteenth-century painters, such as Jacopo Guarana, Giovanni Battista Crosato or Giambattista Pittoni.
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: However, it turned out that the frescoes are the early works by Giovanni Battista Tiepolo.
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: Obvious stylistic and iconographic similarities between these frescoes and other early Tiepolo works were pointed out.The work at the Villa Baglioni began immediately after the wealthy Venetian publisher Giambattista Baglioni acquired in 1718 the seventeenth-century villa in Massanzago.
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: The frescoes cover the entire wall surface of the main hall, illusionistically breaking through the walls and creating a boundless space, thanks to the faux architectural structure conceived by Girolamo Mengozzi Colonna, who henceforth would be Tiepolo's most frequent collaborator, working on almost all of his large-scale decorative projects in Venice and the Veneto.The theme of the frescoes is the Myth of Phaethon, based on Ovid's Metamorphoses.
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: The principal episode, Phaethon Asking His Father to Let Him Drive the Chariot of Sun, is staged on the east wall.
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: The opposite wall is divided into two parts by the doors that lead into the hall from the monumental staircase.
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: The right portion of the wall contains the Fall of Phaethon, the left part shows the Heliads, sisters of Phaethon.
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: The frescoes on the short walls depict monochrome figures of the Four Regions of the World.
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: The ceiling, which opens up to a faux sky, contains a depiction of The Triumph of Aurora
title: View of the main hall
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: The fresco is the largest version of this subject in European art, and it combines two different iconographic traditions: in the upper part of the picture, the Rosenkranzbild, in which Mary gives the Rosary to mankind, and, in the lower part, a depiction of the beneficence of the Rosary on earth, represented by St Dominic.
title: The Institution of the Rosary
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: As well as the Madonna of the Rosary, the fresco also extols St Dominic, the founder of the Dominican order, to whom the dog is a reference (lat.
title: The Institution of the Rosary
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: domini canes, God's hounds).
title: The Institution of the Rosary
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: All manner of people are portrayed - represented among others by the Doge, a Turk, a nun, and a mother and child, a symbol of Christian charity - so that the viewer, whether rich or poor, could identify with them
title: The Institution of the Rosary
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: Magnificent, brightly lit palace architecture is the setting for Cleopatra's banquet.
title: The Banquet of Cleopatra
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: However, the historical event of the meeting between the Queen of Egypt and the Roman Anthony takes second place to the creation of an opulent banqueting scene in the manner of Veronese.
title: The Banquet of Cleopatra
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: It is therefore the sumptuous costumes, the magnificent receptacles and the rich variety of foods which draw most attention as they are proffered by the servants of the court, who include moors, a dwarf and a dog - a collection of elements typical of the work of Veronese
title: The Banquet of Cleopatra
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: This painting was originally a gift to the major collector Heinrich Brühl, the powerful prime minister of Elector Frederick Augustus II of Saxony, also King Augustus III of Poland.
title: Maecenas Presenting the Liberal Arts to Emperor Augustus
author: Giovanni Battista TIEPOLO

sentence_text: In presenting an ancient example of patronage of the arts, Tiepolo was extolling one of the characteristics of an enlightened monarchy

title: View of the Pulcinella Room

sentence_text: The frescoes were painted over a fairly long period of time: between 1759 - the date shown on one of the monochrome scenes from the chapel - and 1797 - according to a now lost inscription read at the beginning of the twentieth century in a mural scene in the Pulcinella Room.
title: View of the Pulcinella Room
author: Giovanni Domenico TIEPOLO

sentence_text: Almost all the frescoes in the small Zianigo villa were detached in 1906 and in 1936 they were moved to the Ca' Rezzonico and placed in small rooms, in a recomposition that closely repeats the original one, though with some differences and overlapping.The frescoes in the villa depict the stories of Pulcinella (also Punchinello, a classical character that originated in the Commedia dell'arte of the 17th century), scenes of villa life, games, the wars and affections of satyrs and fauns.
title: View of the Pulcinella Room
author: Giovanni Domenico TIEPOLO

sentence_text: It is a comprehensive cycle which Giovanni Domenico painted for himself in successive stages in the non-monumental rooms of the country house.
title: View of the Pulcinella Room
author: Giovanni Domenico TIEPOLO

sentence_text: When completed, the whole Zianigo work was a kind of grand recapitulation of many aspects and idiosyncrasies of Giovanni Domenico's art, while also representing the cultural passing of a period and a style.
title: View of the Pulcinella Room
author: Giovanni Domenico TIEPOLO

sentence_text: It is almost a pictorial testament which, while valuing the past, did not conceal the drama of the present nor the uncertainty of the future

sentence_text: The painting is the first of a series of works, painted in 1548 for the Scuola Grande di San Marco while Marco Episcopi, his future father-in-law was Grand Guardian of the School.The subject of the huge canvas is the miraculous appearence of St Mark to rescue one of his devotees, a servant of a knight of Provence, who had been condemned to having his legs broken and his eyes put out for worshipping the relics of the saint against his master's will.
title: The Miracle of St Mark Freeing the Slave
author: TINTORETTO

sentence_text: The scenes takes place on a kind of proscenium which seems to force the action out of the painting towards the spectator who is thus involved in the amazement of the crowd standing in a semi-circle around the protagonists: the fore-shortened figure of the slave lying on the ground, the dumbfounded executioner holding aloft the broken implements of torture, the knight of Provence starting up from his seat out of the shadow into the light, while the figure of St Mark swoops down from above.In keeping with the drama of the action is the tight construction of the painting, the dramatic fore-shortening of the forms and sudden strong contrast of light and shade

author: TINTORETTO

sentence_text: While the figure of God the Father is reminiscent of the Creator in the frescos of the Sistine Chapel, his encounter with the rising St Roch suggests Titian's famous Assunta, the epoch-making altarpiece of 1516/18 in the nearby Frari church, showing the Assumption of the Virgin.

sentence_text: Titian was neither such a universal scholar as Leonardo, nor such an outstanding personality as Michelangelo, nor such a versatile and attractive man as Raphael.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: He was principally a painter, but a painter whose handling of paint equalled Michelangelo's mastery of draughtsmanship.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: This supreme skill enabled him to disregard all the time-honoured rules of composition, and to rely on colour to restore the unity which he apparently broke up.We need but look at Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family which was begun only some fifteen years after Giovanni Bellini's Madonna with saints to realize the effect which his art must have had on contemporaries.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: It was almost unheard of to move the Holy Virgin out of the centre of the picture, and to place the two administering saints - St Francis, who is recognizable by the Stigmata (the wounds of the Cross), and St Peter, who has deposited the key (emblem of his dignity) on the steps of the Virgin's throne - not symmetrically on each side, as Giovanni Bellini had done, but as active participants of a scene.In this altar-painting, Titian had to revive the tradition of donors' portraits, but did it in an entirely novel way.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: The picture was intended as a token of thanksgiving for a victory over the Turks by the Venetian nobleman Jacopo Pesaro, and Titian portrayed him kneeling before the Virgin while an armoured standard-bearer drags a Turkish prisoner behind him.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: St Peter and the Virgin look down on him benignly while St Francis, on the other side, draws the attention of the Christ Child to the other members of the Pesaro family, who are kneeling in the corner of the picture.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: The whole scene seems to take place in an open courtyard, with two giant columns which rise into the clouds where two little angels are playfully engaged in raising the Cross.Titian's contemporaries may well have been amazed at the audacity with which he had dared to upset the old-established rules of composition.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: They must have expected, at first, to find such a picture lopsided and unbalanced.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: Actually it is the opposite.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: The unexpected composition only serves to make it gay and lively without upsetting the harmony of it all.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: The main reason is the way in which Titian contrived to let light, air and colours unify the scene.
title: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: The idea of making a mere flag counterbalance the figure of the Holy Virgin would probably have shocked an earlier generation, but this flag, in its rich, warm colour, is such a stupendous piece of painting that the venture was a complete success.

sentence_text: Returning to Venice from Rome in 1546 Titian created a remarkable group portrait of the male members of the Vendramin.

author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: Here he domesticizes official work such as Bellini's votive portrait of Doge Agostino Barbarigo as well as frescoes he had seen in the papal apartments in Rome.
title: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: While the painting has the look of an impromptu gathering, it is rooted  in prestigious models that betray political motives on the part of Titian and the Vendramin.Titian adapted elements such as the steps, massive altar and flickering candles from Raphael's Mass of Bolsena as a suitably impressive setting for the Vendramin family's adoration of a reliquary of a fragment of the True Cross.
title: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: Although the relic was owned by the Scuola Grande di San Giovanni Evangelista, the Vendramin family was closely associated with it: one of their ancestors had donated the relic to the Scuola, and an Andrea Vendramin, namesake of Titian's patron, was famous for having rescued it when it fell into a canal.
title: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: Titian suggests the intimacy of the family's relation to the relic by placing the current head of family (also named Andrea) in the centre of the composition, with one hand on the altar as he looks out of the picture, inviting the viewer's participation.
title: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: At the left two other family members, dressed in senatorial red, pay their eloquent devotion to the relic, the middle-aged man reaching out as if to share his adoration with others.
title: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross
author: TIZIANO Vecellio

sentence_text: Titian records and contrasts the emotions of his subjects; the sober obedience of the adolescents at left and the innocent play of the children at right serve to underscore the maturity and depth of the adults' piety, as civic, as well as personal virtue.Titian is supposed to have said a painter only needed three colours: white, black and red.

sentence_text: Of the Hungarian kings St Ladislas is perhaps the one most often represented in post-medieval frescoes, altar paintings and statues.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: In the Middle Ages he was associated with the ideal of chivalry and the legends which gathered around him determined the manner of his representation.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: Thus the knightly armour and the battle-axe have become permanent attributes, in addition to the crown and the orb.The painting illustrated here, dating from the late sixteenth century, is only superficially linked with medieval portraits of St. Ladislas.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: The king is shown seated on a throne wearing an ample, richly embroidered cloak studded with pearls round the hem.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: In the foreground is a voluted and foiled shield with the national emblem, stylized in harmony with the throne.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: The background is designed to suggest the interior of a Renaissance palace.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: Through opening on either side of the wall behind the throne - draped with embroidered hangings - there is a view of landscape.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: A similar motif was often used to fill in the background in north Italian Madonna paintings of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: The monochrome landscape on the left is a topographic reference to one of St. Ladislas' most important church activities, the foundation of the Cathedral in Nagyvárad, while the one on the right shows his legendary defeat of the Cumanian abductor.
title: Saint Ladislaus, King of Hungary
author: Hungarian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: This evocation of two popular episodes from the story of the king's life is intended partly to identify St. Ladislas as a rule of worldly power, and partly to indicate the ideal unity of the Christian king and the Christian knight.St Ladislas is shown as a historical personage, without a halo - a fact indicating that the painting was destined for a secular building.

sentence_text: The episodes from the king's life or, to be mere accurate, from legends associated with his name, are treated as historical facts.

sentence_text: Originally venerated in the convent church of Santa Maria in Campo Marzio (Rome) this painting is an icon: its miraculous powers are attested by Bombelli, in his 1792 engraving of the panel.

sentence_text: Iconographically, the image is connected to the Constantinopolitan "Haghiosoritissa", a type of image in which the Virgin is represented in the act of interceding with Christ on behalf of the human race.
title: The Madonna as Advocate (Haghiosoritissa)
author: Italian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: The proposed dating of the painting to the middle of the twelfth century is generally accepted on the basis of stylistic similarities to a panel of the Last Judgment in the Pinacoteca of the Vatican Museums.Stylistically different from other Roman panels that depict the same subject, the painting has been assigned to the same hand that executed the Blessing Christ (Vatican Museums, Pinacoteca), a picture that also originally decorated Santa Maria in Campo Marzio.
title: The Madonna as Advocate (Haghiosoritissa)
author: Italian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: The two works are characterized by an accentuated linearism typical of Byzantine style and a monumental quality that is distinctly Roman.
title: The Madonna as Advocate (Haghiosoritissa)
author: Italian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: They show identical treatments of chiaroscuro effects, simplified folds of the drapery, and effects light.
title: The Madonna as Advocate (Haghiosoritissa)
author: Italian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: Also shared by the two paintings are the brown intonations in the face, which give little concession to colorism, and certain signature characteristics like the rapid brushwork with which the artist defines the folds of Christ's neck or the dark triangle that divides the eyebrows of the Virgin.The inscription at the bottom: "SCA VIRGO VIRGINUM"
title: The Madonna as Advocate (Haghiosoritissa)

sentence_text: The exact identification of the names of the two painters, active in Umbria during the middle of the thirteenth century was discovered in 1948.

sentence_text: Because it is one of the very few dated crosses from its period, this panel is an important reference point for the chronological reconstruction of thirteenth century central Italian workshop activity.Stylistically, the design follows the Giunta Pisano Crucifix in the church of San Domenico in Bologna, datable to around 1250 and the known prototype for a number of late thirteenth century crosses.

sentence_text: Yet though they adhere strictly to the model of Giunta, especially in iconographic aspects, Simone and Machilone show some original characteristics, above all in the attenuation and hardness of line in the figure of Christ, less severe and more human in the National Gallery cross.

sentence_text: Other panels of this work are in the Musée Jacquemart-André, Paris; the Galleria Sabauda, Turin; and the Friedenthal collection, Ingenheim.St Colomba, the virgin of Sens, was martyred during the reign of the Emperor Aurelian.

author: Italian UNKNOWN MASTER

sentence_text: Finally, the Emperor - instigated by the devil - had her dragged out of town, where she was beheaded by the soldiers.In the three small panels in the Brera, the main episodes in this legend are represented with subtle variations in composition and rhythm.

sentence_text: Painted on the walls and entrance arch of the chancel of this church, the scheme includes narrative scenes from the life of the Virgin, such as the Presentation of the Virgin in the Temple, the Annunciation, the Betrothal of the Virgin, and the Assumption of the Virgin (over the chancel arch, now badly damaged)
title: The Betrothal of the Virgin
author: Lippo VANNI

sentence_text: In this painting Varotari depicts a scene from the biblical story of Jacob.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: It shows Jacob telling Rachel and Leah that he wishes to leave Laban's service.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: Jacob urges Rachel and Leah to leave with him.According to the Bible, Leah becomes Jacob's wife through a deception on the part of her father, Laban.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: In the Biblical account, Jacob is dispatched to the hometown of Laban - the brother of his mother Rebekah - to avoid being killed by his brother Esau, and to find a wife.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: Out by the well, he encounters Laban's younger daughter Rachel tending her father's sheep, and decides to marry her.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: Laban is willing to give Rachel's hand to Jacob as long as he works seven years for her.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: On the wedding night, however, Laban switches Leah for Rachel.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: Later Laban claims that it is uncustomary to give the younger daughter away in marriage before the older one.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: Laban offers to give Rachel to Jacob in marriage in return for another seven years of work.
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: Jacob accepts the offer and marries Rachel after the week-long celebration of his marriage to Leah
title: Scene from the Story of Jacob
author: Dario the Elder VAROTARI

sentence_text: The Studiolo is a tiny chamber in the Palazzo dei Priori (Palazzo Vecchio), accessible by a hidden spiral staircase.
title: View of the Studiolo
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: It was dedicated to the geological, mineralogical and alchemical interest of Francesco I de' Medici, son and successor of Cosimo I.
title: View of the Studiolo
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: Its walls are lined with two tiers of oil paintings on slate or panel that act as doors for cupboards containing Francesco's scientific books, specimens, and instruments.
title: View of the Studiolo
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: Two doors, not distinguished in any way from the cupboard doors, cover the only windows: Francesco preferred to work by candlelight.The intimate scale of the project allowed Vasari and his pupils to develop their imaginative abilities, technical skill, and jewel-like delicacy of colour.
title: View of the Studiolo
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: Eight sculptors made the bronze statuettes, and the paintings were by twenty-four artists.
title: View of the Studiolo
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: This precious chamber is the only sixteenth-century room in Europe to survive with its oil paintings intact
title: View of the Studiolo
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: This fresco is part of the paintings decorating the house of Vasari in Florence.It is characteristic of Vasari's self-confidence that the artistic and intellectual effort he invested in designing his own home was comparable to that which he expended on the residences of those who commissioned his work.
title: The Studio of the Painter
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: He decorated his house in Arezzo between 1542 and 1548; toward the end of his life he also frescoed his Florentine house, which had been given to him by Duke Cosimo I in 1561.
title: The Studio of the Painter
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: In both cases the paintings refer to the role of the painter, who saw himself in the tradition of ancient painters (to whom individual episodes of both cycles are devoted)
title: The Studio of the Painter
author: Giorgio VASARI

sentence_text: The Sala dello Scrutinio (Voting Hall) is the second largest hall of the Doge's Palace.
title: Conquest of Tyre
author: Antonio VASSILACCHI

sentence_text: The balloting and secret votes of the magistracies and the doge took place in this hall with the very complicated systems that the Venetian Republic had created to avoid intrigues and subterfuge during the elections and, above all, to ensure that the vote could not be bought especially from the poor nobility in favour of its richer equivalent.The iconographic theme of the hall of the Sala dello Scrutinio was inspired by the Venetian naval victories on the Eastern seas shown in the numerous ceiling canvases depicting virtues and symbolic figures.
title: Conquest of Tyre
author: Antonio VASSILACCHI

sentence_text: Vassilacchi's Conquest of Tyre on the wall of the Sala del Scrutinio depicts a historical event which occurred in 1123 under the rule of Doge Domenico Michiel, who commanded the Venetian fleet in the East
title: Conquest of Tyre
author: Antonio VASSILACCHI

sentence_text: The picture represents a still-life of roses, carnations and other flowers in a sculpted urn with fruit and other flowers below
title: Still-Life
author: Nicolaes van VEERENDAEL

sentence_text: Originally this painting, together with an Immaculate Conception (now in private collection), was in the Carmelite Convent in Seville
title: St John the Evangelist at Patmos

sentence_text: The subject of the painting is the Greek philosopher Democritus expressing his amusement at the world, which stands on the table in front of him in the shape of a globe.
title: Democritus
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The man in the picture stands there smiling, shown half-length, turned to one side but with his face towards us.
title: Democritus
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: His right hand is placed on his hip, in an attitude setting off the heavy folds of a red cloak.Democritus, who lived around 470-360 BC, taught that cheerful and moderate contentment was the way to happiness.
title: Democritus
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: European painting of the Renaissance and Baroque periods repeatedly portrayed him as the "laughing philosopher", contrasting him with other intellectual types such as the pessimist, the stoic and the cynic
title: Democritus
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The painting, asssumed by some art historians to be a self-portrait - is unfinished, the hands are only sketched in
title: Young Man
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: In this painting the restriction of surrounding areas and the general pose found in earlier portraits of the king are still present, but the subject's whole attitude is more relaxed, the flesh tints, probably under the influence of Rubens, are painted with more fluidity, the accents of colour - eyes gleaming like black tortoiseshell, the golden lights on the waves of the hair - are placed with more emphasis, and shapes conveying Baroque dignity, such as the profuse folds of the red curtain, have made their way into the formerly sparse interior.
title: Philip IV in Brown and Silver
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Above all, Velázquez's new delight in luxuriant colour is reflected in his depiction of the silk embroidery and the silver and brown tones of the king's clothing.The king is holding in his right hand a paper with the inscription "Senor/Diego Velázquez/ Pintor de V. Mg" - the opening words of a petition to him from Velázquez.The unattractive matt white of the stockings is the result of an unskilful restoration of the picture in 1936, but otherwise the work is a good example of the skilled manner that Velázquez had now mastered
title: Philip IV in Brown and Silver
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Philip IV was a bold and enthusiastic huntsman, it was usual for the king to ride out with a small retinue in the extensive game preserves of the densely wooded Pardo.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Emperor Charles V had built a watchtower on the way to the mountainous hunting grounds of the Sierra, as a place to stop and rest before the most strenuous stage of the journey.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: This tower was known as the Torre de la Parada, and Philip, who was particularly fond of it, extended it to make a comfortable hunting lodge.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: He was in haste to see it furnished, and commissioned Rubens to provide a large collection of new pictures on mythological subjects.After 1638, when the building itself was completed, it was the task of Velázquez to decide how they should be hung, and to contribute a series of hunting portraits himself, to hang with other appropriate works already in existence and with pictures by Dutch masters.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: This project cost him a great deal of time and trouble, but it also won him increasing appreciation at court.Velázquez's three extant hunting portraits (Philip IV as a Hunter, Prince Baltasar Carlos as a Hunter, and Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter) are life-size.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Don Fernando, the king's younger brother, despite his spiritual calling, did not hesitate to indulge his passion for hunting.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: In this painting, showing him with his gun at the ready, he looks even more of a huntsman than his relations.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: His expressive outline balances the silhouette of the cinnamon-coloured dog sitting in front of him, a figure once again illustrating the court painter's skill in depicting animals.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: He pays them as much careful attention as he expends on human beings; while he is of course aware of the differences between animals and humans, he is also conscious of the dignity shared by all living creatures.
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The natural elegance of a horse's head or the body of a dog, their fiery or faithful natures - few painters have captured the beauty and individuality of animals as unforgettably as Velázquez
title: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: As a court painter, Velázquez was required to paint group portraits as well as these actual or fictional portraits of individual figures.
title: Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: He organized a workshop of competent artists, and in 1633 recruited the services of his son-in-law Juan Bautista Martínez del Mazo.
title: Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Mazo probably did a good deal of work on the picture of around 1636 showing Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews.
title: Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The Count-Duke stands in the middle ground to the right of the picture, with his master-at-arms; figures on the balcony above him include Philip IV, Queen Isabel and several courtiers who cannot be identified for certain.The belly of the horse on which the little prince is mounted is disproportionately convex and in fact so coarsely depicted that one suspects the unskilful hand of an apprentice rather than a deliberate distortion
title: Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: In a manner that is always striking and sometimes curiously moving to modern observers, Velázquez shows human nature in all its diversity when he presents the gallery of dwarfs and jesters who lived at court and whose task it was to preserve the king from boredom in the midst of routine etiquette.Under cover of joking, the court jesters or buffoons, in Spanish truhanes, would often tell their lords and masters the home truths openly discussed by the ordinary people.
title: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: They could move freely in the king's presence, trying to amuse the naturally melancholic Philip IV with their caustic remarks.
title: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: To judge by their salaries, their position in society was quite high.
title: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Velázquez himself, on entering the service of the palace as a court painter, had at first been classed with the royal servants, and as a result shared the life of these truhanes.Velázquez painted a masterly picture of the buffoon Don Cristóbal de Castañeda y Pernia, who was first in rank among the court jesters.
title: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: He gave himself airs as a great military expert, thus earning the nickname of Barbarroja (Barbarossa or Red-beard).
title: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The ambitious buffoon aspired to military roles and he even acted as toreador in the arena although he was ill-fitted for doing it.
title: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: His red robe is almost Turkish in style, and his head-dress suggests a fool's cap.
title: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: He glares fiercely into space, and while he grips the sheath of his sword firmly, the sword itself is held in a relaxed position
title: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: It was customary at the courts of Europe during the seventeenth century for monarchs to keep dwarfs.
title: Court Dwarf Don Antonio el Inglés
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Velázquez's sympathy for the fools and dwarfs of the Spanish court is obvious: in the pathos and humane understanding demonstrated by the single portraits with which he (and he alone) paid tribute to them
title: Court Dwarf Don Antonio el Inglés
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: One of the tasks required of Velázquez, the court painter, was the painting of altarpieces, though to a lesser extent than painting portraits.
title: The Coronation of the Virgin
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The Coronation of the Virgin was painted around 1645, possibly for the queen's oratory in the Alcazar in Madrid.
title: The Coronation of the Virgin
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Angelic putti carry the virginal Madonna up to heaven on clouds; Christ and God the Father hold a wreath of roses over her head, and the dove of the Holy Ghost hovers above her in an aureole of light.
title: The Coronation of the Virgin
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The glory of the coronation of the Mother of God and her perfect features are signs of her virginity.
title: The Coronation of the Virgin
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The virginal face of the Madonna reflects the emotions aroused in Spain between 1613 and 1620 by the postulated Immaculate Conception of the Virgin.
title: The Coronation of the Virgin
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: In this context Pacheco encouraged painters to create emphatically youthful depictions of Mary

sentence_text: "Las Meninas" is a Portuguese word used to name the Maids of Honour of the Royal children in the 17th century.Las Meninas or The Royal Family is one of the great problem pictures in the history of art.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: An almost infinite number of interpretations have now been proposed for the scene it shows.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: At first sight, however, Las Meninas seems to present no problems at all, and indeed appears perfectly straightforward in its sober geometry and good-humoured clarity.It is set in a room in the Alcázar, equipped by Velázquez as a studio, and shows the heiress to the throne, the Infanta Margarita, with her court.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Palomino names all those present.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The queen's maid of honour, Dona Maria Agustina Sarmiento, one of the meninas, is kneeling at the Infanta's feet, handing her a jug of water.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The other maid of honour, Dona Isabel de Velasco stands behind the princess, and beside her we see the grotesquely misshapen female dwarf Mari-Bárbola and the male dwarf Nicolasico Pertusato; the latter, as Palomino points out, is placing his foot on the mastiff lying in front of the group to demonstrate the lethargic animal's good temper.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Further back, almost swallowed up in the shadows, are a man described only as guardadamas - a guard or escort to the ladies - and the lady in waiting Doña Marcela de Ulloa.Velázquez is standing with brush and palette in front of a tall canvas; we can see only the back of it.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: There are some large pictures hanging on the back wall of the room.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Two of them were painted by Velázquez's son-in-law, Mazo, from models by Rubens, and show scenes from Ovid's Metamorphoses, one of them another version of the punishment of Arachne.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The princess's parents, the king and queen, appear in a dark frame below these pictures, probably the glass of a mirror.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: To the right of the mirror, on a flight of steps leading up to a doorway and a brightly lit adjoining room, stands Jose Nieto, the queen's palace marshal.There are several basic questions that have been asked again and again about this picture.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: What is Velázquez painting on the front of the canvas that is hidden from us?
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Where did he stand in order to paint the scene and himself in it?
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: What is the source of the image in the mirror - that is, just where in the room must the royal couple have been standing for their reflection to appear?
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: And finally, is there any significance in the fact that the red cross of the Order of Santiago is prominently applied to the artist's clothing?It was long thought that Velázquez was creating a picture without any metaphysical or speculative reference, and was merely recording a fleeting moment in permanent form, as if in a snapshot.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: According to this theory the subject was no more than an ordinary scene of palace life.A different hypothesis is put forward by art historians, who believe that intellect and keen perspicacity, as well as the artist's eye and hand, were involved in the painting of Las Meninas.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: The largest number of interpretations have been put forward for the mirror on the back wall, sometimes also thought to be a painted canvas.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Much learned industry has also been applied to the question of location: in which room in the palace is this scene taking place?
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Despite the riddles hidden in the painting of Las Meninas we must not overlook its artistic mastery, particularly as expressed in the figure of the Infanta Margarita surrounded by people of lesser birth.
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: For it was on the princess that the dynastic hopes of the Spanish Habsburgs rested after the death of Prince Baltasar Carlos
title: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: At the end of the 1640s Velázquez was on the threshold to his late work and the peak of his artistic achievement, to which his likenesses of the Spanish Habsburgs, not least, made a considerable contribution.
title: Infanta Margarita
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: They are among the finest examples of court portraiture ever painted.
title: Infanta Margarita
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: This picture represents Infanta Margarita, born on 12 July 1651, daughter of Philip IV and his second wife, Mariana.

sentence_text: The Infanta is the central figure of Velázquez's famous composition, Las Meninas, painted three years later
title: Infanta Margarita

sentence_text: There are several versions of this late portrait of the king executed between 1655 and 1660 by Velázquez or his workshop
title: Philip IV
author: Diego Rodriguez de Silva y VELÁZQUEZ

sentence_text: Since the publication in 1925 of the contents of Velázquez's private library, which contained 156 learned works, it has been obvious that he did have an extensive fund of knowledge.

sentence_text: His references to classical mythology, for instance in the painting Mercury and Argus of around 1659, should be viewed in this light

sentence_text: The young prince was a sickly child from birth, and he died at the age of four.

sentence_text: The most famous admiral in Dutch history, Michiel de Ruyter, enjoyed an international reputation and received numerous honours from other countries.

sentence_text: As vice-admiral of the fleet he took part in the numerous sea battles the Dutch fought against England.

sentence_text: He won a number of victories, but the pinnacle of his career was undoubtedly the Third Anglo-Dutch War (1672-1674), in which his superior tactics enabled him to keep a large Anglo-French fleet away from the Dutch coast.

sentence_text: It necessitated the wholesale renovation of the pictorial decoration, and artists received explicit instructions about subject and even composition, the idea being to emulate the visual authority of the destroyed works as closely as possible.In the redecorated room the thirty-five ceiling canvases, some of them by Veronese, celebrate the glory of Venice allegorically and illustrate the Republic's military history.

sentence_text: It is one of the thirty five panels on the ceiling.Rising above the bank of clouds, the royally garbed personification of Venice sits enthroned between the twin towers of the city's Arsenal, about to be crowned with laurel by flying victories.
title: Apotheosis of Venice
author: Paolo VERONESE

sentence_text: Arrayed at her feet and offering her wise counsel are personifications of peace, abundance, fame, happiness, honour, security, and freedom.

sentence_text: An especially splendid triumphal arch, fronted by twisting columns, marks the top of an enormous balcony which seems to burst through the ceiling into the ether beyond in order to accommodate the multitudes of celebrating people stipulated in the commission.

sentence_text: At the base, Venice's smiling subjects seem undisturbed by the enormous size and energy of careening horsemen in their midst reminder of Venice's considerable military might.

author: Paolo VERONESE

sentence_text: Illusionistic foreshortenings and dramatic light effects serve to give political allegory a previously unimagined dynamism and visual excitement

sentence_text: The heavy plasticity of Bartolomeo Vivarini and Andrea da Murano was soon surpassed by the more balanced and harmonious three-dimensional quality of the works of Antonello da Messina.

title: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)
author: Alvise VIVARINI

sentence_text: One of the first to be inspired by it was Alvise Vivarini, son of Antonio and follower of his uncle Bartolomeo, who soon went on to become a major exponent of Antonello's theories of crystalline form and colour.
title: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)
author: Alvise VIVARINI

sentence_text: His major work coming from the first and much-admired studio of Messina is the Sacra Conversazione dated 1480, originally in the church of San Francesco in Treviso.The painting is composed with geometrical symmetry: the two groups of saints, Louis of Toulouse, Anthony of Padua and Anne on the left and Joachim, Bernardino and Francesco Gioacchino on the right, face inwards towards the enthroned Virgin.
title: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)
author: Alvise VIVARINI

sentence_text: In their gestures immobilized by the cold light which comes from the top left-hand corner, the three-dimensional figures appear to form a kind of architecture the centre of which is the throne, a construction of cylinders and parallelepipeds, behind which the curtain falls heavily excluding from sight all natural elements apart from two small fragments of a cold, clouded sky.
title: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)
author: Alvise VIVARINI

sentence_text: Shadows appear to cut into the floor, confirmation of the geometrical relationship between space and figures, while the clear line delineates areas of pure enamel-like colour.
title: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)
author: Alvise VIVARINI

sentence_text: This theory of formal abstraction was to become during the last few years of the 15th century still more monumental, in contrast to the ideas of colourization and sublime naturalness represented by Giovanni Bellini.Recent examination has revealed that the green curtain in the background was added at a later date.

sentence_text: Ortensia Mancini (1646-1699), was the fourth of the five celebrated Mancini Sisters (Laure, Olympe, Marie, Marie Anne and Ortensia), daughters of the sister of Cardinal Mazarin, the chief advisor of the young King Louis XIV of France and reputed lover of his mother, Anne of Austria.
title: Portrait of Ortensia Mancini
author: Jacob Ferdinand VOET

sentence_text: After their father's death in 1650, the Mancini girls were brought to France by their mother, who hoped that her brother would help find rich and titled husbands for her brood of girls.The five Mancini girls were to become the talk of Paris thanks to their sumptuous dark haired, olive skinned beauty and wild, flamboyant manners, with the young Ortensia (Hortense in Paris), her uncle's favourite niece being the most badly behaved of them all as she grew up into a bold eyed beauty, who was absolutely impossible to resist.At the age of fifteen Hortense was married to one of the richest men in all Europe, the Duc de Meilleraye, with the couple being declared Duc and Duchesse de Mazarin after their wedding day
title: Portrait of Ortensia Mancini
author: Jacob Ferdinand VOET

sentence_text: Antonius Anselmus, an alderman of the city from 1580 to 1582, and his wife Joanna Hooftmans, the daughter of a wealthy merchant, are placed in front of a neutral background, accompanied by their two children, both born in Antwerp, Gillis in 1575 and Joanna in 1576.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: A third child was to be born in Hamburg, where the family sought refuge for a time after the city of Antwerp was returned to the Catholics.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: The Anselmus family, like the Hooftmans, were Calvinists.The family's high social ranking is immediately visible in the various items of decor: the carved furniture, the silver inkwell on the table, and the fragile Venetian glass vase, as well as the costly lace on the parents' garments and the children's aprons.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: The little girl holds a sumptuous vermeil rattle, a prestigious object symbolising the wealth of the newly born child.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: This object was offered to very young children by a godfather or an important person.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: The one represented here has at one end a whistle and at the other a wolf's tooth, to which popular belief attributed the double power of protecting children against the evil eye and reducing teething pain.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: On the table between the couple are the marriage gloves and a rose, symbols of the love that unites them.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: The children express the prosperity of the couple as does the fruit being held by the elder.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: At the same time the tame bird on his shoulder is a metaphor for a successful education.Maerten de Vos, who excelled in the portrait genre, was also known for his religious paintings, producing, among other works, six paintings of episodes from the life of St Paul for the dining room of Gillis Hooftmans, Joanna's father.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: It is possibly following this commission that he painted the family portrait.
title: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children
author: Marten de VOS

sentence_text: By creating a unified and enveloping space around the figures, the artist succeeded in given a new dimension to the genre, intensifying both the psychological study and the allegorical significance.

sentence_text: It may perhaps be identifiable with the Magdalene cited with an attribution to Sacchi in the 1648-49 inventory of the Palazzo Barberini at Monterotondo.The painting, which shows some stylistic and typological connections with the Vouet's David in Palazzo Bianco in Genoa, could date from the years (c. 1623-27) in which the French artist was in close contact with the Barberini, ending with his departure for France.

sentence_text: Though the canvas is certainly rich in Caravaggesque qualities, Vouet is already showing himself as a full participant in the new classicism that was on the rise in the Roman art scene.

sentence_text: At the same time he also shows signs of sympathy with the first fully baroque works that were being created in Rome.This painting poses interesting problems on account of its close compositional connections to the Magdalene by Guido Reni, dated to 1631-32 (also in the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Rome).

sentence_text: Sir Joseph Banks (1743-1820) was a naturalist and patron of science.

sentence_text: From an early age, his declared passion was natural history, and in particular, botany.

sentence_text: He joined Captain Cook's 1768 expedition on the Endeavour to Tahiti for astronomical observations (to observe the transit of Venus).In West's portrait he wears a Maori cloak and stands beside other trophies from New Zealand and Polynesia, as if in rebuke of his more conventional contemporaries who were portrayed in Rome with their purchases of classical antiquities
title: Joseph Banks

sentence_text: The genre in which English painters were least happy in the second half of the 18th century was history painting; the efforts of Reynolds in this direction are strangely petrified for so living a painter.

sentence_text: Yet it was through history painting that Neo-Classicism invaded the art in England.

author: Benjamin WEST

sentence_text: A Scot, Gavin Hamilton (1738-1820) and an American, Benjamin West, who enjoyed a prodigious success, were in advance of the French painter Jacques-Louis David in the conception of a painting as a scene from Classical history, based upon thorough archeological research.West was most successful when least pretentious; his illustrations of English historical events are simply illustrations, simply composed, uneffectedly direct.

sentence_text: Neo-classicism had trained West to give value to the facts of the scene depicted, removing anything merely decorative or liable to spoil the sense of witnessing an actual event

sentence_text: The Louvre Annunciation is the central panel of a triptych the wings of which are most probably not the work of Rogier.

sentence_text: Its style is quite different from that of the Descent from the Cross and shows closer affinities to that of Jan Van Eyck.
title: The Annunciation
author: Rogier van der WEYDEN

sentence_text: It even reproduces certain details familiar to us from the Arnolfini Marriage, including the red of the bed clothes and hangings and the carved copper chandelier.
title: The Annunciation
author: Rogier van der WEYDEN

sentence_text: Instead of the famous convex mirror, the painting features a copper medallion glinting in the background.
title: The Annunciation
author: Rogier van der WEYDEN

sentence_text: This is also a picture replete with symbols in typical Campin style: lily, ewer and basin for purifying water, representing the purity of the Virgin Mary; a phial traversed by a ray of light evoking the miraculous birth; an orange or "Chinese apple", fruit of the forbidden tree, reminding us of the necessity of Redemption; extinguished candles, awaiting the coming of the Light, i.e.
title: The Annunciation
author: Rogier van der WEYDEN

sentence_text: the Word made flesh.The painting seems to have been designed to suit the Flemish taste for intimate domestic scenes, according to which painters were expected to portray religious themes in familiar bourgeois interiors.
title: The Annunciation
author: Rogier van der WEYDEN

sentence_text: Yet, this does not derive from any concern for the minutiae of realist detail, but from properly theological reasons.The new religious tendency in Flanders at that time was the "devotio moderna".
title: The Annunciation
author: Rogier van der WEYDEN

sentence_text: This doctrine urged the believer to meditate on Christ's humanity, by representing it to himself in the context of his present life.
title: The Annunciation
author: Rogier van der WEYDEN

sentence_text: In Rogier's painting, the contemporary setting, underlined by the absence of haloes, is meant to draw the viewer in so that he effectively participates in the scene before him.

sentence_text: This is why the angel Gabriel appears before Mary dressed in an immaculate alb and magnificent brocade cope, as if he had come to celebrate mass, rather than deliver a message
